title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: Brief examples shown using dataset data_ge contains data two variables assessed 10 genotypes growing 14 environments.

title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: First , check data possible problems function inspect(). , details multi-environment trial can obtained function ge_details(). Note apply function numeric variables quickly, can use select helper everything() argument resp. can create plot show performance genotypes across environments ge_plot().  obtain means genotypes, environments genotype-environment interaction ge_means(). Note function round_cols() provided metan round numeric columns data frame two (default) significant figures.

# A tibble: 10 × 3 #    Parameters GY                  HM               #    <chr>      <chr>               <chr>            #  1 Mean       "2.67"              "48.09"          #  2 SE         "0.05"              "0.21"           # title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: cross-validation procedures implemented metan based splitting original data training set validation set. model fitted using training set predicted value compared validation set. process iterated many times, say, 1000 times. lesser difference predicted validation data, higher predictive accuracy model. information may found .

title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: well-known AMMI2 biplot may obtained using function plot_scores(). ggplot2-based graphics obtained. Please, note since performs_ammi() , waas() functions allow analyzing multiple variables time, e.g., resp = c(v1, v2, ...), output ammi_model list case two elements, (GY HM). produce AMMI2 biplot IPCA1 IPCA3, example, use argument second change default value y axis.
code: a <- plot_scores(ammi_model) b <- plot_scores(ammi_model,                  type = 2,                  second = "PC3") c <- plot_scores(ammi_model,                  type = 2,                  polygon = TRUE,                  col.gen = "black",                  col.env = "gray70",                  col.segm.env = "gray70",                  axis.expand = 1.5) arrange_ggplot(a, b, c, tag_levels = "a", ncol = 1)

title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: S3 method predict() implemented objects class performs_ammi may used estimate response genotype environment considering different number Interaction Principal Component Axis (IPCA). example, predict variables GY HM use four six IPCA (number significant IPCAs, respectively). addition, create two way table make_mat() show predicted values variable GY.

title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: implementation linear-mixed effect models predict response variable MET made function gamem_met(). default, genotype genotype-vs-environment interaction assumed random effects. Use argument random change default. following example model fitted numeric variables data_ge.
code: model2 <- gamem_met(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, everything()) # Evaluating trait GY |======================                      | 50% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait HM |============================================| 100% 00:00:01  # Method: REML/BLUP # Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV # Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) # Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #     model       GY       HM #  COMPLETE       NA       NA #       GEN 1.11e-05 5.07e-03 #   GEN:ENV 2.15e-11 2.27e-15 # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction

title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: WAASB index (Olivoto, Lúcio, Da silva, Marchioro, et al. 2019) quantitative stability measure based weighted average absolute scores singular value decomposition BLUPs genotype-vs-interaction effects. can obtain statistic function waasb() combined get_model_data() using = "WAASB". function blup_indexes() can used compute harmonic mean genotypic values (HMGV), relative performance genotypic values (RPGV) harmonic mean relative performance genotypic values (HMRPGV). See Alves et al. (2018) details. use function get_model_data() get HMRPGV (default) analyzed variables.
code: model3 <- waasb(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, everything(), verbose = FALSE) get_model_data(model3, what = "WAASB") %>%    round_cols() # Class of the model: waasb # Variable extracted: WAASB # # A tibble: 10 × 3 #    GEN      GY    HM #    <chr> <dbl> <dbl> #  1 G1     0.13  0.38 #  2 G10    0.46  1.03 #  3 G2     0.21  0.79 #  4 G3     0.1   0.36 #  5 G4     0.25  0.6  #  6 G5     0.22  0.88 #  7 G6     0.17  0.41 #  8 G7     0.32  0.68 #  9 G8     0.26  0.44 # 10 G9     0.37  0.56 index <- blup_indexes(model3) get_model_data(index) %>% round_cols() # Class of the model: blup_ind # Variable extracted: HMRPGV # # A tibble: 10 × 3 #    GEN      GY    HM #    <chr> <dbl> <dbl> #  1 G1     0.97  0.98 #  2 G10    0.9   1.01 #  3 G2     1.02  0.97 #  4 G3     1.1   0.99 #  5 G4     0.99  1    #  6 G5     0.95  1.02 #  7 G6     0.95  1.01 #  8 G7     1.03  1    #  9 G8     1.12  1.02 # 10 G9     0.92  1

title: Multi-environment Trial Analysis
text: generic function plot() used generate biplot using input fitted model class gge. type biplot chosen argument type function. Ten biplots type available according {Yan Kang (2003)}. type = 1 basic biplot. type =  2 Mean performance vs. stability. type =  3 -won-. type =  4 Discriminativeness vs. representativeness. type =  5 Examine environment. type =  6 Ranking environments. type =  7 Examine genotype. type =  8 Ranking gentoypes. type =  9 Compare two genotypes. type =  10 Relationship among environments.
code: f <- plot(gge_model) g <- plot(gge_model, type = 2) arrange_ggplot(e, f, tag_levels = list(c("e", "f")), ncol = 1)

code: library(metan) insp <- inspect(data_ge,                 verbose = FALSE,                 plot = TRUE) print_table(insp)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: suggested check genotype-vs-environment interaction significant proceeding AMMI analysis. within-environment ANOVA considering fixed-effect model computed function anova_ind(). environment Mean Squares block, genotypes error shown. Estimated F-value probability error also shown block genotype effects. measures experimental precision calculated, namely, coefficient variation, \(CV = (\sqrt{MS_{res}}/Mean) \times 100\); heritability, \(h2 = (MS_{gen} - MS_{res})/MS_{gen}\), accuracy selection, \(= \sqrt{h2}\). joint ANOVA performed function anova_joint(). genotype-vs-environment interaction highly significant. ’ll proceed AMMI analysis.
code: indiv <- anova_ind(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY) # Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:00  print_table(indiv$GY$individual) library(metan) joint <- anova_joint(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, verbose = FALSE) print_table(joint$GY$anova)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: estimate response variable ith genotype jth environment using Additive Main Effect Multiplicative interaction (AMMI) model, given follows: \[ {y_{ij}} = \mu  + {\alpha_i} + {\tau_j} + \sum\limits_{k = 1}^p {{\lambda _k}{a_{ik}}} {t_{jk}} + {\rho _{ij}} + {\varepsilon _{ij}} \] \({\lambda_k}\) singular value k-th interaction principal component axis (IPCA); \(a_{ik}\) -th element k-th eigenvector; \(t_{jk}\) jth element kth eigenvector. residual \(\rho _{ij}\) remains, p IPCA used, \(p \le min(g - 1; e - 1)\). AMMI model fitted performs_ammi() function. first argument data, example data_ge. second argument (resp) response variable analyzed. function allow single variable (case GY) vector response variables. arguments (gen, env, rep) name columns contains levels genotypes, environments, replications, respectively. last argument (verbose) control code run silently. Note using arguments correct order, model may fitted cleanly :
code: AMMI_model <- performs_ammi(data_ge,                             env = ENV,                             gen = GEN,                             rep = REP,                             resp = GY,                             verbose = FALSE) AMMI_model <- performs_ammi(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, verbose = FALSE)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: following comand creates well-known ANOVA table AMMI model. Note since Nine interaction principal component axis (IPCA) fitted four significant 5% probability error. Based result, AMMI4 model best model predict yielding genotypes studied environments.

what: Estimating the response variable based on significant IPCA axes
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: response variable two-way table (example, yield m genotypes n environments) may estimated using S3 method predict() applyed object class waas. estimation based number multiplicative terms declared function. naxis = 1, AMMI1 (one multiplicative term) used estimating response variable. naxis = min(g - 1; e - 1), AMMIF fitted. summary possible AMMI models presented . Procedures based postdictive success, Gollobs’s test (Gollob 1968) predictive success, cross-validation (Piepho 1994) used define number IPCA used estimating response variable AMMI analysis. package provides . waas() function compute traditional AMMI analysis showing number significant axes according Gollobs’s test. hand, cv_ammif() function provides cross-validation AMMI-model family, considering completely randomized design (CRD) randomized complete block design (RCBD). following values presented: ENV environment; GEN genotype; Y response variable; resOLS residual (\(\hat{z}_{ij}\)) estimated Ordinary Least Square (OLS), \(\hat{z}_{ij} = y_{ij} - \bar{y}_{.} - \bar{y}_{.j} + \bar{y}_{ij}\); Ypred predicted value OLS (\(\hat{y}_{ij} = y_{ij} -\hat{z}_{ij}\)); ResAMMI residual estimated AMMI model (\(\hat{}_{ij}\)) considering number multiplicative terms informed function (case 5), \(\hat{}_{ij} = \lambda_1\alpha_{i1}\tau_{j1}+...+\lambda_5\alpha_{i5}\tau_{j5}\); YpredAMMI predicted value AMMI model \(\hat{ya}_{ij} = \bar{y}_{.} + \bar{y}_{.j} - \bar{y}_{ij}+\hat{}_{ij}\); AMMI0 predicted value multiplicative terms used, .e., \(\hat{y}_{ij} = \bar{y}_{.} + \bar{y}_{.j} - \bar{y}_{ij}\).
code: predicted <- predict(AMMI_model, naxis = 4) print_table(predicted)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: waas() function computes Weighted Average Absolute Scores (Olivoto, Lúcio, Da silva, Marchioro, et al. 2019) considering () principal component axes significant (\(p < 0.05\) default); (ii) declaring specific number axes used, according following equation: \[         WAAS_i  =         \sum_{k = 1}^{p} |IPCA_{ik} \times EP_k|/ \sum_{k = 1}^{p}EP_k \] \(WAAS_i\) weighted average absolute scores ith genotype; \(PCA_{ik}\) score ith genotype kth IPCA; \(EP_k\) explained variance kth IPCA \(k = 1,2,..,p\), considering p number significant PCAs, declared number PCAs. following functions may used .
code: waas_index <- waas(data_ge,  ENV, GEN, REP, GY, verbose = FALSE)

what: Number of axes based on F-test
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: example IPCAs P-value < 0.05 considered WAAS estimation. default setting model already fitted stored AMMI_model>GY>model. output generated waas() function shows following results: type, genotype (GEN) environment (ENV); Code, code attributed level factors; Y, response variable (case grain yield); WAAS weighted average absolute scores, estimated PCA axes P-value \(\le\) 0.05; PctWAAS PctResp percentage values WAAS Y, respectively; OrResp OrWAAS ranks attributed genotype environment regarding Y WAAS, respectively; WAASY weighted average absolute scores response variable. case, considering equal weights PctResp PctWAAS, WAASY G1 estimated : \(WAAS_{G1} = [(24.87\times50)+(91.83\times50)]/50+50 = 58.35\). OrWAASY rank WAASY value. genotype (environment) largest WAASY value first ranked.
code: print_table(waas_index$GY$model)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: quadrants proposed Olivoto, Lúcio, Da silva, Marchioro, et al. (2019) following biplot represent four classifications regarding joint interpretation mean performance stability. genotypes environments included quadrant can considered unstable genotypes environments high discrimination ability, productivity grand mean. quadrant II included unstable genotypes, although productivity grand mean. environments included quadrant deserve special attention since, addition providing high magnitudes response variable, present good discrimination ability. Genotypes within quadrant III low productivity, can considered stable due lower values WAASB. lower value, stable genotype can considered. environments included quadrant can considered poorly productive low discrimination ability. genotypes within quadrant IV highly productive broadly adapted due high magnitude response variable high stability performance (lower values WAASB). . obtain biplot must use object class waas (example, waas_index).
code: e <- plot_scores(waas_index, type = 3) f <- plot_scores(waas_index,                  type = 3,                  x.lab = "My custom x label",                  size.shape.gen = 4, # Size of the shape for genotypes                  col.gen = "gray50", # Color for genotypes                  size.tex.gen = 4, # Size of the text for genotypes                  col.alpha.env = 0, # Transparency of environment's point                  x.lim = c(2.4, 3.1), # Limits of x axis                  x.breaks = seq(2.4, 3.1, by = 0.1), # Markers of x axis                  y.lim = c(0, 0.7))+   ggplot2::ggtitle("WAASB vs GY plot", subtitle = "Zoom in genotypes' scores") arrange_ggplot(e, f, tag_levels = list(c("e", "f")))

what: Simultaneous selection for mean performance and stability
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: WAASY index (Olivoto, Lúcio, Da silva, Sari, et al. 2019) used genotype ranking considering stability (WAAS) mean performance based following model: \[ WAASY{_i} = \frac{{\left( {r{G_i} \times {\theta _Y}} \right) + \left( {r{W_i} \times {\theta _S}} \right)}}{{{\theta _Y} + {\theta _S}}} \] \(WAASY_i\) superiority index -th genotype weights performance stability; \(rG_i\) \(rW_i\) rescaled values (0-100) GY WAASB, respectively; \(\theta _Y\) \(\theta_S\) weights GY WAASB, respectively. index also already computed stored AMMI_model>GY>model. intuitively plot may obtained running  values WAASY plot computed considering equal weights mean performance stability. Different weights may assigned using wresp argument waas() function.
code: i <- plot_waasby(waas_index) j <- plot_waasby(waas_index,                  col.shape = c("gray20", "gray80"),                  plot_theme = theme_metan(grid = "x")) arrange_ggplot(i, j, tag_levels = list(c("i", "j")))

what: Weighting the stability and mean performance
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: fitting model functions waas() waasb() possible compute superiority indexes WAASY WAASBY different scenarios weights stability mean performance. number scenarios defined arguments increment. default, twenty-one different scenarios computed. case, superiority index computed considering following weights: stability (waasb waas) = 100; mean performance = 0. words, stability considered genotype ranking. next iteration, weights becomes 95/5 (since increment = 5). third scenario, weights become 90/10, weights become 0/100. last iteration, genotype ranking WAASY WAASBY matches perfectly ranks response variable.
code: WAASratio <- wsmp(waas_index)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text:
following AMMI-based stability indexes may computed using function AMMI_indexes(): AMMI stability value, ASV, (Purchase, Hatting, Deventer 2000). \[ ASV = \sqrt {{{\left[ { rac{{IPCA{1_{ss}}}}{{IPCA{2_{ss}}}} 	imes \left( {IPCA{1_{score}}} ight)} ight]}^2} + {{\left( {IPCA{2_{score}}} ight)}^2}} \] Sums absolute value IPCA scores \[ SIP{C_i} = \sum
olimits_{k = 1}^P {\left| {\mathop {\lambda }
olimits_k^{0.5} {a_{ik}}} ight|} \] Averages squared eigenvector values \[ E{V_i} = \sum
olimits_{k = 1}^P {\mathop 
olimits_{ik}^2 } /P \] described Sneller, Kilgore-Norquest, Dombek (1997), P number IPCA retained via F-tests; absolute value relative contribution IPCAs interaction (Zali et al. 2012). \[ Z{a_i} = \sum
olimits_{k = 1}^P {{	heta _k}{a_{ik}}} \] \({	heta _k}\) percentage sum squares explained k-th IPCA. Simultaneous selection indexes (ssi), computed summation ranks ASV, SIPC, EV Za indexes ranks mean yields (Farshadfar 2008), results ssiASV, ssiSIPC, ssiEV, ssiZa, respectively. AMMI_index() function two arguments. first (x) model, must object class waas performs_ammi. second, (order.y) order ranking response variable. default, set NULL, means response variable ordered descending order. x list one variable, order.y must vector length x. element vector must one “h” “l”. “h” used, response variable ordered maximum minimum. “l” used response variable ordered minimum maximum. use previously fitted model AMMI_model compute AMMI-based stability indexes.
code: stab_indexes <- AMMI_indexes(AMMI_model) # Warning in AMMI_indexes(AMMI_model): `AMMI_indexes()` is deprecated as of metan # 1.16.0. use `ammi_indexes()` instead. print_table(stab_indexes$GY)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using AMMI
text: Singular Value Decomposition requires complete two-way table (.e., genotypes environments). Sometimes (several reasons), complete two-way table obtained multi-environment trial. metan offers option impute missing cells two-way table using Expectation-Maximization algorithms. incomplete two-way table identified performs_ammi() warning issued, impute_missing_val() called internally missing value(s) () imputed using low-rank Singular Value Decomposition approximation estimated Expectation-Maximization algorithm. algorithm () initialize NA values column means; (ii) compute first axis terms SVD completed matrix; (iii) replace previously missing values approximations SVD; (iv) iterate steps 2 3 convergence maximum number iterations achieved. example run AMMI model omiting H2 E1 `data_ge2.

what: Find possible outliers in a data frame
title: Useful functions for biometrical models
text: function find_outlier() may used identify possible outliers dataframe. suggested applying statistical procedures, outliers checked .  check outliers different levels factor, use argument . example, find possible outliers level factor ENV. group one variable, use function group_by() used.
code: library(metan) data_out <- data_ge2 data_out[12, 4] = 5 find_outliers(data_out, var = PH, plots = TRUE) # Trait: PH  # Number of possible outliers: 1  # Line(s): 12  # Proportion: 0.6% # Mean of the outliers: 5  # Maximum of the outliers: 5  | Line 12  # Minimum of the outliers: 5  | Line 12  # With outliers:    mean = 2.499 | CV = 15.58% # Without outliers: mean = 2.483 | CV = 13.46% find_outliers(data_ge2, PH, by = ENV) # No possible outlier identified.  #  # No possible outlier identified.  #  # Trait: PH  # Number of possible outliers: 4  # Line(s): 7 11 14 15  # Proportion: 11.4% # Mean of the outliers: 2.438  # Maximum of the outliers: 2.766  | Line 11  # Minimum of the outliers: 1.71  | Line 7  # With outliers:    mean = 2.167 | CV = 10.309% # Without outliers: mean = 2.136 | CV = 7.377% #  # No possible outlier identified. #   ENV outliers # 1  A1        0 # 2  A2        0 # 3  A3        4 # 4  A4        0 data_ge2 %>%   group_by(ENV) %>%   find_outliers(PH) # No possible outlier identified.  #  # No possible outlier identified.  #  # Trait: PH  # Number of possible outliers: 4  # Line(s): 7 11 14 15  # Proportion: 11.4% # Mean of the outliers: 2.438  # Maximum of the outliers: 2.766  | Line 11  # Minimum of the outliers: 1.71  | Line 7  # With outliers:    mean = 2.167 | CV = 10.309% # Without outliers: mean = 2.136 | CV = 7.377% #  # No possible outlier identified. #   ENV outliers # 1  A1        0 # 2  A2        0 # 3  A3        4 # 4  A4        0

title: Useful functions for biometrical models
text: Pearson’s linear correlation consider influence set traits relationship two traits. example, hypothetical correlation r = 0.9 x y may due influence third trait group traits acting together. identify linear effect x y controlling statistically effect others traits, partial correlation used. Pearson’s simple correlation matrix, partial correlation calculated following equation: \[     {r_{xy.m}} = \frac{{ - {a_{xy}}}}{{\sqrt {{a_{xx}}{a_{yy}}} }} \] \({r_{xy.m}}\) partial correlation coefficient traits * x * * y , excluding effects  m * remaining traits set; \(- {a_{ij}}\) inverse element correlation matrix corresponding xy, \({a_{ii}}{a_{jj}}\) diagonal elements inverse matrix correlation associated trait x y , respectively. significance correlation also tested test * t * according following expression: \[ t_{calc} = r_{xy.m} \sqrt \frac{n-v}{1-r_{xy.m}^2} \] \(t_{calc}\) calculated Student * t * statistic; $ r_{xy.m} $ partial correlation coefficient traits x y excluding effect * m * traits; * n * number observations; * v * number traits. linear partial correlation coefficients may obtained using function lpcor(). Using pairs_mantel() function, possible compute Mantel’s test (Mantel 1967) pairwise correlation matrices example.  plot may obtained passing correlation matrices dimension object class lpcor applying function pairs_mantel().
code: lpc1 <-    data_ge2 %>%    select(starts_with("N")) %>%    lpcor() print_table(lpc1$results) lpc2 %>% pairs_mantel(names = paste("H", 1:4, sep = "")) as.lpcor(cor(data_ge2[1:30, 5:ncol(data_ge2)]),          cor(data_ge2[31:60, 5:ncol(data_ge2)]),          cor(data_ge2[61:90, 5:ncol(data_ge2)]),          cor(data_ge2[91:120, 5:ncol(data_ge2)]),          cor(data_ge2[121:150, 5:ncol(data_ge2)])) %>%   pairs_mantel(diag = TRUE,                pan.spacing = 0,                shape.point = 21,                col.point = "black",                fill.point = "red",                size.point = 1.5,                alpha.point = 0.6,                main = "My own plot",                alpha = 0.2)

what: Graphical and numerical visualization of a correlation matrix
title: Useful functions for biometrical models
text: function corr_coef() can used compute Pearson producto-moment correlation coefficients p-values. correlation heat map can created function plot().  can use select helper function select variables. , select variables starts “C” ends “D” using union_var(). function corr_plot() may used visualize (graphically numerically) correlation matrix. Pairwise scatterplots produced may shown upper lower diagonal, may seen nicer customizable ggplot2-based version pairs()base R function. also possible use categorical variable data map scatterplot colors.  function corr_coef() can used compute Pearson product-moment correlation coefficients p-values. correlation heat map can created function plot()
code: # All numeric variables ccoef <- corr_coef(data_ge2) plot(ccoef) ccoef2 <- corr_coef(data_ge2, union_var("C", "D")) print(ccoef2, digits = 2) # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # Pearson's correlation coefficient # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #        CL    CD   CW   CDED    ED # CL   1.00 0.300 0.74  0.708  0.70 # CD   0.30 1.000 0.48  0.045  0.39 # CW   0.74 0.484 1.00  0.300  0.74 # CDED 0.71 0.045 0.30  1.000 -0.01 # ED   0.70 0.390 0.74 -0.010  1.00 # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # p-values for the correlation coefficients # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #           CL      CD      CW    CDED      ED # CL   0.0e+00 1.4e-04 3.9e-28 4.9e-25 4.7e-24 # CD   1.4e-04 0.0e+00 1.5e-10 5.7e-01 4.9e-07 # CW   3.9e-28 1.5e-10 0.0e+00 1.4e-04 5.3e-28 # CDED 4.9e-25 5.7e-01 1.4e-04 0.0e+00 9.0e-01 # ED   4.7e-24 4.9e-07 5.3e-28 9.0e-01 0.0e+00 a <- corr_plot(data_ge2, CD, EL, PERK, NKR)  b <-  corr_plot(data_ge2, CD, EL, PERK, NKR,           lower = NULL,           upper = "corr") c <-  corr_plot(data_ge2, CD, EL, PERK, NKR,           shape.point = 19,           size.point = 2,           alpha.point = 0.5,           alpha.diag = 0,           pan.spacing = 0,           diag.type = "boxplot",           col.sign = "gray",           alpha.sign = 0.3,           axis.labels = TRUE)  d <-  corr_plot(data_ge2, CD, EL, PERK, NKR, CW, NKE,           prob = 0.01,           shape.point = 21,           col.point = "black",           fill.point = "orange",           size.point = 2,           alpha.point = 0.6,           maxsize = 4,           minsize = 2,           smooth = TRUE,           size.smooth = 1,           col.smooth = "black",           col.sign = "cyan",           col.up.panel = "black",           col.lw.panel = "black",           col.dia.panel = "black",           pan.spacing = 0,           lab.position = "tl") arrange_ggplot(a, b, c, d, tag_levels = "a") corr_plot(iris, col.by = Species)

title: Useful functions for biometrical models
text: function covcor_design() may used compute genetic, phenotypic residual correlation/(co)variance matrices Analysis Variance (ANOVA) method using randomized complete block design (RCBD) completely randomized design (CRD). phenotypic (\(r_p\)), genotypic (\(r_g\)) residual (\(r_r\)) correlations computed follows: \[ r^p_{xy} = \frac{cov^p_{xy}}{\sqrt{var^p_{x}var^p_{y}}} \\ r^g_{xy} = \frac{cov^g_{xy}}{\sqrt{var^g_{x}var^g_{y}}} \\ r^r_{xy} = \frac{cov^r_{xy}}{\sqrt{var^r_{x}var^r_{y}}} \] Using Mean Squares (MS) ANOVA method, variances (var) covariances (cov) computed follows: \[ cov^p_{xy} = [(MST_{x+y} - MST_x - MST_y)/2]/r \\ var^p_x = MST_x / r \\ var^p_y = MST_y / r \\ cov^r_{xy} = (MSR_{x+y} - MSR_x - MSR_y)/2 \\ var^r_x = MSR_x \\ var^r_y = MSR_y \\ cov^g_{xy} = [(cov^p_{xy} \times r) - cov^r_{xy}]/r \\ var^g_x = (MST_x - MSE_x)/r \\ var^g_y = (MST_x - MSE_y)/r \\ \] MST mean square treatment, MSR mean square residuals, r number replications. function covcor_design() returns list matrices (co)variances correlations. Specific matrices may returned using argument type, shown bellow.

title: Useful functions for biometrical models
code: # environment A1 data <- subset(data_ge2, ENV == "A1") gcor <- covcor_design(data, gen = GEN, rep = REP,                       resp = c(PH, EH, NKE, TKW, CL, CD, CW, KW),                       type = "gcor") %>%    as.data.frame() print_table(gcor, rownames = TRUE)

title: Useful functions for biometrical models
text: example obtain residual (co)variance environment. residual (co)variance matrix means (obtained using type = "means") may used function mahala() compute Mahalanobis distance
code: cov <- covcor_design(data_ge2,                      gen = GEN,                      rep = REP,                      resp = c(PH, EH, NKE, TKW, CL, CD, CW, KW),                      type = "rcov") res <- covcor_design(data, GEN, REP,                      resp = c(PH, EH, NKE, TKW, CL, CD, CW, KW),                      type = "rcov") means <- covcor_design(data, GEN, REP,                        resp = c(PH, EH, NKE, TKW, CL, CD, CW, KW),                        type = "means")  D2 <- mahala(.means = means, covar = res, inverted = FALSE) %>%    as.data.frame() print_table(D2, rownames = TRUE)

what: If I have the matrices of means and covariances
title: Useful functions for biometrical models
text: Lets suppose want compute Mahalanobis’ distance pairwise genotype comparison based cob-related traits. Note function select(contains("C")) used select cob-relate traits, computing mean genotype. next step compute variance-covariance matrix means. first approach combines R base functions functions metan package compute covariance matrix. course, simplest way using cov(). computing means covariance matrices able compute Mahalanobis distance using function mahala().
code: means <-    data_ge2 %>%   means_by(GEN) %>%    column_to_rownames("GEN") %>%   select(contains("C")) # Compute the covariance matrix (by hand) cov_mat <- matrix(0, 4, 4) dev_scores <- sweep(means, 2, colMeans(means), FUN = "-") comb_v <- comb_vars(dev_scores, FUN = "*") cov_mat[lower.tri(cov_mat, diag = F)] <- colSums(comb_v/(nrow(means) - 1)) rownames(cov_mat) <- colnames(cov_mat) <- colnames(means) cov_mat <- make_sym(cov_mat, diag = diag(var(means)))  # Compute the covariance using cov() covmat2 <- cov(means)  # Check if the two matrices are equal all.equal(cov_mat, covmat2) # [1] TRUE D2 <- mahala(means, covar = cov_mat)  # Dendrogram D2 %>% as.dist() %>% hclust() %>% as.dendrogram() %>% plot()

what: Analysis of single experiments using mixed-models
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: function gamem() may used analyze single experiments (one-way experiments) using mixed-effect model according following model: \[ y_{ij}= \mu  + \alpha_i + \tau_j + \varepsilon_{ij} \] \(y_{ij}\) value observed ith genotype jth replicate (= 1, 2, … g; j = 1, 2, .., r); g r number genotypes replicates, respectively; \(\alpha_i\) random effect ith genotype; \(\tau_j\) fixed effect jth replicate; \(\varepsilon_{ij}\) random error associated \(y_{ij}\). example, use example data data_g metan package. easiest way obtaining results model using function get_model_data(). Let’s . Details analysis Likelihood ratio test genotype effect Variance components genetic parameters Predicted means example, experimental design complete randomized block. also possible analyze experiment conducted alpha-lattice design function gamem(). case, following model fitted: \[ y_{ijk}= \mu  + \alpha_i + \gamma_j + (\gamma \tau)_{jk} + \varepsilon_{ijk} \] \(y_{ijk}\) observed value ith genotype kth block jth replicate (= 1, 2, … g; j = 1, 2, .., r; k = 1, 2, .., b); respectively; \(\alpha_i\) random effect ith genotype; \(\gamma_j\) fixed effect jth complete replicate; \((\gamma \tau)_{jk}\) random effect kth incomplete block nested within j replicate; \(\varepsilon_{ijk}\) random error associated \(y_{ijk}\). example, use example data data_alpha metan package.
code: gen_mod <- gamem(data_g, GEN, REP,                  resp = c(ED, CL, CD, KW, TKW, NKR)) # Evaluating trait ED |=======                                     | 17% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait CL |===============                             | 33% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait CD |======================                      | 50% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait KW |=============================               | 67% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait TKW |====================================       | 83% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait NKR |===========================================| 100% 00:00:00  # Method: REML/BLUP # Random effects: GEN # Fixed effects: REP # Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #     model       ED       CL    CD     KW     TKW   NKR #  Complete       NA       NA    NA     NA      NA    NA #  Genotype 2.73e-05 2.25e-06 0.118 0.0253 0.00955 0.216 # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # Variables with nonsignificant Genotype effect # CD NKR  # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- get_model_data(gen_mod, "details") %>% print_table() # Class of the model: gamem # Variable extracted: details get_model_data(gen_mod, "lrt") %>% print_table() # Class of the model: gamem # Variable extracted: lrt get_model_data(gen_mod, "genpar") %>% print_table() # Class of the model: gamem # Variable extracted: genpar get_model_data(gen_mod, "blupg") %>% print_table() # Class of the model: gamem # Variable extracted: blupg gen_alpha <- gamem(data_alpha, GEN, REP, YIELD, block = BLOCK) # Evaluating trait YIELD |=========================================| 100% 00:00:00  # Method: REML/BLUP # Random effects: GEN, BLOCK(REP) # Fixed effects: REP # Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #      model    YIELD #   Complete       NA #   Genotype 1.18e-06 #  rep:block 3.35e-03 # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype effect get_model_data(gen_alpha, "lrt") %>% print_table() # Class of the model: gamem # Variable extracted: lrt

previous_headings: The BLUP model for MET trials > Printing the model outputs
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: output shows predicted means genotypes. BLUPg genotypic effect \((\hat{g}_{})\), considering balanced data genotype random effect estimated \[ \hat{g}_{} = h_g^2(\bar{y}_{.}-\bar{y}_{..}) \] \(h_g^2\) shrinkage effect genotype. Predicted predicted mean estimated \[ \hat{g}_{}+\mu \] \(\mu\) grand mean. LL UL lower upper limits, respectively, estimated \[ (\hat{g}_{}+\mu)\pm{CI} \] \[ CI = t\times\sqrt{((1-Ac)\times{\mathop \sigma \nolimits_g^2)}} \] \(t\) Student’s t value two-tailed t test given probability error; \(Ac\) accuracy selection \(\mathop \sigma \nolimits_g^2\) genotypic variance.
code: library(ggplot2) a <- plot_blup(mixed_mod) b <- plot_blup(mixed_mod,                 col.shape  =  c("gray20", "gray80"),                plot_theme = theme_metan(grid = "y")) +   coord_flip() arrange_ggplot(a, b, tag_levels = "a")

what: BLUP for genotypes X environment combination
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: output shows predicted means genotype environment combination. BLUPg genotypic effect described . BLUPge genotypic effect ith genotype jth environment \((\hat{g}_{ij})\), considering balanced data genotype random effect estimated \[\hat{g}_{ij} = h_g^2(\bar{y}_{.}-\bar{y}_{..})+h_{ge}^2(y_{ij}-\bar{y}_{.}-\bar{y}_{.j}+\bar{y}_{..})\] \(h_{ge}^2\) shrinkage effect genotype--environment interaction; BLUPg+ge \(BLUP_g+BLUP_{ge}\); Predicted predicted mean (\(\hat{y}_{ij}\)) estimated \[ \hat{y}_{ij} = \bar{y}_{.j}+BLUP_{g+ge} \]

text: following pieces information provided Details output. Nenv, number environments analysis; Ngen number genotypes analysis; mresp value attributed highest value response variable rescaling ; wresp weight response variable estimating WAASBY index. Mean grand mean; SE standard error mean; SD standard deviation. CV coefficient variation phenotypic means, estimating WAASB, Min minimum value observed (returning genotype environment), Max maximum value observed (returning genotype environment); MinENV environment lower mean, MaxENV environment larger mean observed, MinGEN genotype lower mean, MaxGEN genotype larger.

previous_headings: The BLUP model for MET trials
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: function waasb() function computes Weighted Average Absolute Scores considering possible IPCA Singular Value Decomposition BLUPs genotype-vs-environment interaction effects obtained Linear Mixed-effect Model (Olivoto et al. 2019), follows: \[         WAASB_i  =         \sum_{k = 1}^{p} |IPCA_{ik} \times EP_k|/ \sum_{k = 1}^{p}EP_k \] \(WAASB_i\) weighted average absolute scores ith genotype; \(IPCA_{ik}\) scores ith genotype kth IPCA; \(EP_k\) explained variance kth PCA \(k = 1,2,..,p\), \(p = min(g-1; e-1)\). output generated waasb() function similar generated waas() function. main difference , singular value decomposition based BLUP GEI effects matrix.
code: waasb_model <-    waasb(data_ge,         env = ENV,         gen = GEN,         rep = REP,         resp = everything(),         random = "gen", #Default         verbose = TRUE) #Default # Evaluating trait GY |======================                      | 50% 00:00:01  Evaluating trait HM |============================================| 100% 00:00:02  # Method: REML/BLUP # Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV # Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) # Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #     model       GY       HM #  COMPLETE       NA       NA #       GEN 1.11e-05 5.07e-03 #   GEN:ENV 2.15e-11 2.27e-15 # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction  data <- waasb_model$GY$model print_table(data)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: quadrants proposed Olivoto et al. (2019) following biplot represent four classifications regarding joint interpretation mean performance stability. genotypes environments included quadrant can considered unstable genotypes environments high discrimination ability, productivity grand mean. quadrant II included unstable genotypes, although productivity grand mean. environments included quadrant deserve special attention since, addition providing high magnitudes response variable, present good discrimination ability. Genotypes within quadrant III low productivity, can considered stable due lower values WAASB. lower value, stable genotype can considered. environments included quadrant can considered poorly productive low discrimination ability. genotypes within quadrant IV highly productive broadly adapted due high magnitude response variable high stability performance (lower values WAASB).  obtain WAASB index set variables, function get_model_data() used, shown bellow.
code: g <- plot_scores(waasb_model, type = 3) h <- plot_scores(waasb_model, type = 3,                  x.lab = "My customized x label",                  size.shape.gen = 3,                  size.tex.gen = 2,                  x.lim = c(1.2, 4.7),                  x.breaks = seq(1.5, 4.5, by = 0.5),                  plot_theme = theme_metan(color.background = "white")) arrange_ggplot(g, h, tag_levels = list(c("g", "h"))) waasb(data_ge2, ENV, GEN, REP,      resp = c(PH, ED, TKW, NKR)) %>%  get_model_data(what = "WAASB") %>%  print_table() # Evaluating trait PH |===========                                 | 25% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait ED |======================                      | 50% 00:00:01  Evaluating trait TKW |================================           | 75% 00:00:01  Evaluating trait NKR |===========================================| 100% 00:00:02  # Method: REML/BLUP # Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV # Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) # Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #     model       PH       ED      TKW     NKR #  COMPLETE       NA       NA       NA      NA #       GEN 9.39e-01 2.99e-01 1.00e+00 0.78738 #   GEN:ENV 1.09e-13 1.69e-08 4.21e-10 0.00404 # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction # Class of the model: waasb # Variable extracted: WAASB

what: Simultaneous selection for mean performance and stability
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: waasby index used genotype ranking considering stability (waasb) mean performance (y) based following model (Olivoto et al. 2019). \[ waasby_i = \frac{{\left( {r {Y_i} \times {\theta _Y}} \right) + \left( {r {W_i} \times {\theta _W}} \right)}}{{{\theta _Y} + {\theta _W}}} \] \(waasby_i\) superiority index -th genotype; \(rY_i\) \(rW_i\) rescaled values (0-100) response variable (y) stability (WAAS WAASB), respectively; \(\theta _Y\) \(\theta_W\) weights mean performance stability, respectively. index also already computed stored AMMI_model>GY>model. intuitively plot may obtained running  following example, apply function wsmp() previously fitted model waasb_model aiming planning different scenarios waasby estimation changing weights assigned stability mean performance.vThe number scenarios defined arguments increment. default, twenty-one different scenarios computed. case, superiority index waasby computed considering following weights: stability (waasb waas) = 100; mean performance = 0. words, stability considered genotype ranking. next iteration, weights becomes 95/5 (since increment = 5). third scenario, weights become 90/10, weights become 0/100. last iteration, genotype ranking WAASY WAASBY matches perfectly ranks response variable.
code: i <- plot_waasby(waasb_model) j <- plot_waasby(waasb_model, col.shape = c("gray20", "gray80")) arrange_ggplot(i, j, tag_levels = list(c("e", "f"))) scenarios <- wsmp(waasb_model) # Ranks title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: first type heatmap shows genotype ranking depending number principal component axes used estimating WAASB index. euclidean distance-based dendrogram used grouping genotypes based ranks. second type heatmap shows genotype ranking depending WAASB/GY ratio. ranks obtained ratio 100/0 considers exclusively stability genotype ranking. hand, ratio 0/100 considers exclusively productivity genotype ranking. Four clusters estimated (1) unproductive unstable genotypes; (2) productive, unstable genotypes; (3) stable, unproductive genotypes; (4), productive stable genotypes (Olivoto et al. 2019).

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: Colombari Filho et al. (2013) shown use three BLUP-based indexes selecting genotypes performance stability. first harmonic mean genotypic values -BLUPS- (HMGV) stability index considers genotype highest harmonic mean across environments stable, follows: \[ HMG{V_i} = \frac{E}{{\sum\limits_{j = 1}^E {\frac{1}{{BLUP{_{ij}}}}}}} \] second relative performance genotypic values (RPGV), adaptability index estimated follows: \[ RPGV_i = \frac{1}{e}{\sum\limits_{j = 1}^e {BLUP_{ij}} /\mathop \mu \nolimits_j } \] third last harmonic mean relative performance genotypic values (HMRPGV), simultaneous selection index stability, adaptability mean performance, estimated follows: \[ HMRPG{V_i} = \frac{E}{{\sum\limits_{j = 1}^E {\frac{1}{{BLUP{_{ij}}/{\mu _j}}}} }} \]
code: Res_ind <-  data_ge %>% gamem_met(ENV, GEN, REP, GY, verbose = FALSE) %>%  blup_indexes() # Warning: The WAASB index was not computed. # Use an object computed with `waasb()` to get this index.  print_table(Res_ind$GY)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: FAI-BLUP multi-trait index based factor analysis ideotype-design recentely proposed Rocha, Machado, Carneiro (2018). based factor analysis, factorial scores ideotype designed according desirable undesirable factors. , spatial probability estimated based genotype-ideotype distance, enabling genotype ranking. use mixed-model mod inpute data. default, selection made increase value traits. Change default arguments DI UI.  IMPORTANT fai_blup() recognizes models fitted gamem_met() waasb(). balanced data (genotypes environments) waasb() gamem_met() return model. case unbalanced trials, function waasb() return error since complete two-way table required singular value decomposition procedure.

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using BLUP
text: vignette built pkgdown. tables produced package DT using following function.
code: library(DT) # Used to make the tables # Function to make HTML tables print_table <- function(table, rownames = FALSE, digits = 3, ...){   df <- datatable(table, rownames = rownames, extensions = 'Buttons',                   options = list(scrollX = TRUE,                                   dom = '<<t>Bp>',                                  buttons = c('copy', 'excel', 'pdf', 'print')), ...)   num_cols <- c(as.numeric(which(sapply(table, class) == "numeric")))   if(length(num_cols) > 0){     formatSignif(df, columns = num_cols, digits = digits)   } else{     df   } }

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: section, use data data_ge. information, please, see ?data_ge. data sets can used provided following columns dataset: environment, genotype, block/replicate response variable(s). See section Rendering engine know HTML tables generated.

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: predictive accucary AMMI BLUP models may obtained using cross-validation procedure implemented functions cv_ammif() cv_blup() cv_ammif() function provides complete cross-validation procedure member AMMI model family (AMMI0-AMMIF) using replicate-based data, according diagram . Automatically first validation carried considering AMMIF (possible axis used). Considering model, original data set split two sets: training set validation set. Diagram cross-validation AMMI models. training set combinations (genotype x environment) number replications informed nrepval argument. validation set one replication included training set. splitting data set training validation sets depends design considered. Randomized Complete Block Design (default option) procedure used article, completely blocks randomly selected within environments, suggested Piepho (1994). remaining block serves validation data. design = "CRD" informed, thus declaring completely randomized design used, single observations randomized treatment (genotype--environment combination). procedure suggested Gauch Zobel (1988). estimated values member AMMI model family re-sampling cycle compared observed values validation data. , Root Mean Square Prediction Difference computed follows: \[    RMSPD =    {\left[ {\left( {\sum\nolimits_{= 1}^n {{{\left( {{{\hat y}_{ij}} - {y_{ij}}} \right)}^2}} } \right)/n} \right]^{0.5}} \] \(\widehat{y}_{ij}\) model predicted value; \(y_{ij}\) observed value validation set. number random selection blocks/replicates (n) defined argument nboot. end n cycles models, list estimated RMSPD average RMSPD returned.

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: following code computes cross-validation oat data using AMMI model. two options . first perform cross-validation specific member AMMI-family model. second (realistic) perform cross-validation AMMI-family models procedure.

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: function cv_ammi() used compute cross-validation procedure AMMI0, AMMI2 AMMIF (9 axes) models.
code: library(metan) AMMI0 <- cv_ammi(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, naxis = 0) # AMMI0 AMMI2 <- cv_ammi(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, naxis = 2) # AMMI2 AMMI9 <- cv_ammi(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, naxis = 9) # AMMIF

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: function cv_ammif() used compute cross-validation procedure members AMMI-family model. case, AMMI0-AMMI9.
code: AMMIF <- cv_ammif(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY)

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: function cv_blup() provides cross-validation replicate-based data using mixed models. default, complete blocks randomly selected environment. Using argument random possible chose random effects model, shown bellow.

what: Genotype and genotype-vs-environment as random effects
title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
code: BLUP_g <- cv_blup(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, random = "gen")

what: Environment, replication-within-environment and interaction as random effects
title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
code: BLUP_e <- cv_blup(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, random = "env")

what: A random model (all terms as random effects)
title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
code: BLUP_ge <- cv_blup(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, random = "all")

what: Printing the means of RMSPD estimates
title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: table showns descriptive statistics (mean, standard deviation, standar error mean, quantiles 2.5% 97.5%) 100 RMSPD estimates model, presented accurate model (smallest RMSPD mean) least accurate model (highest RMSPD mean).
code: bind_mod <- bind_cv(AMMIF, BLUP_g, bind = "means") print_table(bind_mod$RMSPD)

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: values RMSPD estimates obtained cross-validation process may plotted using functionplot().  Six statistics shown boxplot. mean (black rhombus), median (black line), lower upper hinges correspond sto first third quartiles (25th 75th percentiles, respectively). upper whisker extends hinge largest value \(1.5\times{IQR}\) hinge (IQR inter-quartile range). lower whisker extends hinge smallest value \(1.5\times{IQR}\) hinge. Data beyond end whiskers considered outlying points. condition violin = TRUE, violin plot added along boxplot. violin plot compact display continuous distribution displayed way boxplot.
code: bind1 <- bind_cv(AMMI0, AMMI2, AMMI9) bind2 <- bind_cv(AMMIF, BLUP_g, BLUP_e, BLUP_ge) a <- plot(bind1, violin = TRUE) b <- plot(bind2,           width.boxplot = 0.6,           order_box = TRUE,           plot_theme = theme_metan_minimal()) arrange_ggplot(a, b, tag_levels = "a")

title: Cross-validation procedures for AMMI and BLUP
text: vignette built pkgdown. tables produced package DT using following function.
code: library(DT) # Used to make the tables # Function to make HTML tables print_table <- function(table, rownames = FALSE, digits = 3, ...){   df <- datatable(table, rownames = rownames, extensions = 'Buttons',                   options = list(scrollX = TRUE,                                   dom = '<<t>Bp>',                                  buttons = c('copy', 'excel', 'pdf', 'print')), ...)   num_cols <- c(as.numeric(which(sapply(table, class) == "numeric")))   if(length(num_cols) > 0){     formatSignif(df, columns = num_cols, digits = digits)   } else{     df   } }

title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
text: metan provides simple intuitive pipe-friendly framework performing descriptive statistics. set functions can used compute used descriptive statistics quickly. tutorial, use data example data_ge2 motivation examples. See section Rendering engine know HTML tables generated. Let’s start simple (widely used) example: compute mean numeric variable (say, PH) data set (data_ge2). Using R base functions stats::mean(), solution look like : Consider now want compute mean value PH level factor GEN. words, compute mean value PH genotype. solution using stats::aggregate() :
code: library(metan) inspect(data_ge2, verbose = FALSE) %>%   print_table() mean(data_ge2$PH) # [1] 2.484813 aggr <- aggregate(PH ~ GEN, data = data_ge2, FUN = mean) print_table(aggr)

what: Statistics by levels of a factor
title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
text: Using metan’s function means_by() amount code needed dramatically reduced. compute grand mean numeric variables data_ge, simple use: compute mean values level factor GEN, need add grouping variable GEN argument .... following _by() functions available computing main descriptive statistics levels factor. cv_by() computing coefficient variation. max_by() computing maximum values. means_by() computing arithmetic means. min_by() computing minimum values. n_by() getting length. sd_by() computing sample standard deviation. sem_by() computing standard error mean .
code: ov_mean <-  means_by(data_ge2) print_table(ov_mean) ov_mean2 <-  means_by(data_ge2, GEN) print_table(ov_mean2)

title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
text: useful functions also implemented. works naturally %>%, handle grouped data dplyr::group_by() multiple variables (numeric variables .data default). av_dev() computes average absolute deviation. ci_mean_t() computes t-inverval (95%) mean. ci_mean_z() computes z-inverval (95%) mean. cv() computes coefficient variation. freq_table() Computes frequency fable. hm_mean(), gm_mean() computes harmonic geometric means, respectively. harmonic mean reciprocal arithmetic mean reciprocals. geometric mean nth root n products. kurt() computes kurtosis like used SAS SPSS. range_data() Computes range values. sd_amo(), sd_pop() Computes sample populational standard deviation, respectively. sem() computes standard error mean. skew() computes skewness like used SAS SPSS. sum_dev() computes sum absolute deviations. sum_sq_dev() computes sum squared deviations. var_amo(), var_pop() computes sample populational variance. valid_n() Return valid (NA) length data. Let’s show examples. Note select helpers can used select variables based names.
code: # Standard error of the mean for numeric variables that contains (ED) data_ge2 %>%    sem(contains("ED")) %>%    print_table()

title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
text: compute statistics can use desc_stat(). wrapper function around ones may used compute measures central tendency, position, dispersion. default (stats = "main"), seven statistics (coefficient variation, maximum, mean, median, minimum, sample standard deviation, standard error confidence interval mean) computed. allowed values "" show statistics, "robust" show robust statistics, "quantile" show quantile statistics, chose one () statistics using comma-separated vector statistic names, e.g., stats = c("mean, cv"). can also use hist = TRUE create histogram variable. , select helpers can also used argument ....

what: All statistics for all numeric variables
title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
code: all <- desc_stat(data_ge2, stats = "all") print_table(all)

title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
code: robust <-  data_ge2 %>%   desc_stat(contains("N"),             stats = "robust") print_table(robust)

title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
code: quantile <-  data_ge2 %>%   desc_stat(PH, EH, CD, ED,             stats = "quantile") print_table(quantile)

what: Create a histogram for each variable
title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
code: stat_vars <-  data_ge2 %>%   desc_stat(EP, EL, CL, CD, CW, NR,             hist = TRUE) print_table(stat_vars)

title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
text: compute statistics level factor, use argument . addition, possible select statistics compute using argument stats, single statistic name, e.g., "mean", comma-separated vector names " beginning end vector . Note statistic names NOTE case sensitive, .e., "mean", "Mean", "MEAN" recognized. Comma spaces can used separate statistics’ names. stats = c("mean, se, cv, max, min") stats = c("mean se cv max min") stats = c("MEAN, Se, CV max Min") may convert results wider format using function desc_wider() compute descriptive statistics one grouping variable, need pass grouped data argument .data function group_by(). Let’s compute mean, standard error mean sample size variables EP EL combinations factors ENV GEN.
code: stats_c <-    desc_stat(data_ge2,             contains("C"),             stats = ("mean, se, cv, max, min"),             by = ENV) print_table(stats_c) desc_wider(stats_c, mean) %>%    print_table() stats_grp <-  data_ge2 %>%    group_by(ENV, GEN) %>%    desc_stat(EP, EL,             stats = c("mean, se, n")) print_table(stats_grp)

title: Descriptive analysis in R with the package metan
text: vignette built pkgdown. tables produced package DT using following function.
code: library(DT) # Used to make the tables # Function to make HTML tables print_table <- function(table, rownames = FALSE, digits = 3, ...){   df <- datatable(table, rownames = rownames, extensions = 'Buttons',                   options = list(scrollX = TRUE,                                   dom = '<<t>Bp>',                                  buttons = c('copy', 'excel', 'pdf', 'print')), ...)   num_cols <- c(as.numeric(which(sapply(table, class) == "numeric")))   if(length(num_cols) > 0){     formatSignif(df, columns = num_cols, digits = digits)   } else{     df   } }

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: Genotype plus Genotype-vs-Environment interaction (GGE) model widely used genotype evaluation mega-environment identification multi-environment trials (MET). model considers GGE (.e., G + GE) biplot, constructed first two symmetrically scaled principal components (PC1 PC2) derived singular value decomposition environment-centered MET data. GGE biplot graphically displays G plus GE MET way facilitates visual genotype evaluation mega-environment identification (W. Yan et al. 2007) section, use data data_ge. information, please, see ?data_ge. data sets can used provided following columns dataset: environment, genotype, block/replicate response variable(s).
code: library(metan)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: mean yield genotype environment j commonly described general linear model \[ \hat y_{ij} + \mu + \alpha_i + \beta_j + \phi_{ij} \] \(\hat y_{ij}\) mean yield genotype environment j, \(= 1, ... g; j = 1, ...e\) g e numbers genotypes environments, respectively; \(\mu\) grand mean; \(\alpha_i\) main effect genotype ; \(\beta_j\) main effect environment j, \(\phi_{ij}\) interaction effect genotype environment j. Subjecting \(\phi_{ij}\) Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) results AMMI model. deletion \(\alpha_i\) allows variation explained term absorbed \(\phi_{ij}\) term. Genotype plus Genotype-vs-Environment interaction (GGE) model \(\alpha_i\) term deleted model environment-centered data matrix, \(\phi_{ij}\), subjected SVD (W. Yan et al. 2007; Weikai. Yan Kang 2003). Explicitly, \[ {\phi_{ij} =  \hat y_{ij}} - \mu - \beta_j  = \sum\limits_{k = 1}^p \xi_{ik}^*\eta_{jk}^* \] \(\xi_{ik}^* = \lambda_k^\alpha\xi_{ik}\); \(\eta_{jk}^* = \lambda_k^{1-\alpha}\eta_{jk}\) \(\lambda_k\) kth eigenvalue SVD (\(k = 1, ...p\)), \(p \le min(e, g)\); \(\alpha\) singular value partition factor Principal Component (PC) k; \(\xi_{ik}^*\) \(\eta_{jk}^*\) PC scores genotype environment j, respectively. function gge() used produce GGE model. According Weikai. Yan Kang (2003), function supports four methods data centering, two methods data scaling three options singular value partitioning:

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: 0 "none" centering; 1 "global" global centered (E+G+GE); 2 "environment" (default), environment-centered (G+GE); 3 "double" double centred (GE). biplot produced models produced without centering.

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: 0 "none" (default) scaling; 1 "sd" value divided standard deviation corresponding environment (column). put testers roughly range values.

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: 1 "genotype" singular value entirely partitioned genotype eigenvectors, also called row metric preserving; 2 "environment" (default) singular value entirely partitioned environment eigenvectors, also called column metric preserving; 3 "symmetrical" singular value symmetrically partitioned genotype environment eigenvectors SVP often used AMMI analysis biplot analysis, ideal visualizing either relationship among entries among testers.

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: fit GGE model use data data_ge, contains data grain yield evaluated 10 genotypes conducted 14 environments. First , let’s inspect data possible problems. GGE model fitted function gge(). function produces GGE model using data frame containing least columns genotypes, environments response variable(s). model fitted considering () column metric preserving (singular value entirely partitioned environment eigenvectors); (ii) environment centered (biplot contain mixed information G + GEI); scaling method. change default settings, use arguments svp, centering, scaling, respectively. Please, note second example argument table set TRUE indicate input data two-way table.
code: inspect(data_ge) # # A tibble: 5 × 10 #   Variable Class   Missing Levels Valid_n   Min Median   Max Outlier Text  #   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <int> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <lgl> # 1 ENV      factor  No      14         420 NA     NA    NA         NA NA    # 2 GEN      factor  No      10         420 NA     NA    NA         NA NA    # 3 REP      factor  No      3          420 NA     NA    NA         NA NA    # 4 GY       numeric No      -          420  0.67   2.61  5.09       0 NA    # 5 HM       numeric No      -          420 38     48    58          0 NA # No issues detected while inspecting data. gge_model <- gge(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY)

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: generic function plot() used generate biplot using input fitted model class gge. type biplot chosen argument type function. Ten biplots type available according Weikai. Yan Kang (2003). type = 1 basic biplot. type =  2 Mean performance vs. stability. type =  3 -won-. type =  4 Discriminativeness vs. representativeness. type =  5 Examine environment. type =  6 Ranking environments. type =  7 Examine genotype. type =  8 Ranking genotypes type =  9 Compare two genotypes. type =  10 Relationship among environments. material, biplot type, two graphics produced. One default settings show graphical options function.

title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: default setting function plot, thus, biplot produced just calling plot(model), shown .
code: a <- plot(gge_model) b <- plot(gge_model,           col.gen = "orange",           size.text.env = 2,           plot_theme = theme_metan(grid =  "both")) arrange_ggplot(a, b, tag_levels = "a")

what: Biplot type 2: Mean performance vs. stability
title: Analyzing multienvironment trials using GGE
text: biplot, visualization mean stability genotypes achieved drawing average environment coordinate (AEC) genotype-focused biplot. First, average environment, represented small circle, defined mean PC1 PC2 scores environments. line passes biplot origin AEC may called average. projections genotype markers onto axis , therefore, approximate mean yield genotypes. Thus, G8 clearly highest-yielding genotype, average. AEC ordinate line passes biplot origin perpendicular AEC abscissa. Therefore, AEC abscissa represents G, AEC ordinate must approximate GEI associated genotype, measure variability instability genotypes (W. Yan et al. 2007). greater projection onto AEC ordinate, regardless direction, means greater instability. example, G3 found stable second productive genotype, G9 great instability.
code: gge_model <- gge(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY, svp = "genotype") c <- plot(gge_model, type = 2) d <- plot(gge_model,           type = 2,           col.gen = "black",           col.env = "red",           axis_expand = 1.5,           plot_theme = theme_metan_minimal()) arrange_ggplot(c, d, tag_levels = list(c("c", "d")))

text: biplot polygon drawn joining genotypes (G7, G8, G9, G10, G4) located farthest biplot origin genotypes contained polygon. vertex genotypes longest vectors, respective directions, measure responsiveness environments. vertex genotypes , therefore, among responsive genotypes; genotypes less responsive respective directions. genotype located origin rank environments responsive environments. perpendicular lines sides polygon divide biplot sectors. sector vertex genotype. example, sector vertex genotype G4 may referred G4 sector; one environment (E9), fell sector. rule, vertex genotype highest-yielding genotype environments share sector (W. Yan et al. 2007). case, G4 highest-yielding E9, shown two-way table .

text: Identifying genotypes adapted environment can easily achieved via GGE biplot. example, visualize performance different genotypes given environment, e.g., E10, simply draw line passes biplot origin marker E10. genotypes can ranked according projections onto E10 axis based performance E10, direction pointed arrow. example, E10, highest-yielding genotype G8, lowest-yielding genotype G10, order genotypes G8 > G7 > G3 > G2 > G4 > G1 > G6 > G5 > G9 > G10.

title: Helper functions for metan
text: package metan reexports tidy select helpers implements select helpers based operations prefixes suffixes (difference_var(), intersect_var(), union_var()), length variable names (width_of(), width_greater_than(), width_less_than()), case type (lower_case_only(), upper_case_only(), title_case_only()).

what: Variables that start with a prefix and ends with a suffix.
title: Helper functions for metan
text: , select variables data_ge2 start “C” ends “D”. Just reduce length outputs, three rows selected
code: library(metan) data_sel <- head(data_ge2, 3) data_sel %>%    select_cols(intersect_var("C", "D")) %>%    print_table()

what: Variables that start with a prefix OR ends with a suffix.
title: Helper functions for metan
text: following code select variables start “C” ends “D”.
code: data_sel %>%    select_cols(union_var("C", "D")) %>%    print_table()

what: Variables that start with a prefix AND NOT ends with a suffix.
title: Helper functions for metan
text: following code select variables start “C” ends “D”.
code: data_sel %>%    select_cols(difference_var("C", "D")) %>%    print_table()

what: Selection based on length of column names.
title: Helper functions for metan
text: Select variables specific name length (four letters) Select variables width less n. Select variables width greater n.
code: data_sel %>%    select_cols(width_of(4)) %>%    print_table() data_sel %>%    select_cols(width_less_than(3)) %>%    print_table() data_sel %>%    select_cols(width_greater_than(2)) %>%    print_table()

title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: section use data examples data_ge data_ge2 provided metan package. information, please, see ?data_ge ?data_ge2. data sets can used provided following columns dataset: environment, genotype, block/replicate response variable(s). See section Rendering engine know HTML tables generated.

title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: function mtsi() used compute multi-trait stability index (MTSI) proposed Olivoto et al. (2019). first argument model class waasb waas. possible compute MTSI WAASB -stability - WAASBY -simultaneous selection mean performance stability.

title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: following example, selection stable genotypes consider five traits, namely, KW, NKE, PH, EH, TKW. Note output function waasb() passed function mtsi() forward-pipe operator %>%. Finally, MTSI index plotted using function plot().
code: library(metan) MTSI_index <- data_ge2 %>%               waasb(ENV, GEN, REP,                     resp = c(KW, NKE, PH, EH, TKW)) %>%               mtsi(verbose = FALSE, index = "waasb")

what: Based on mean performance and stability
title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: following code considers higher values KW, NKE, TKW better, lower values PH EH better. using wresp = 65, simultaneous selection mean performance stability prioritize mean performance (mean variables) rather stability across environments.
code: MTSI_index2 <-    data_ge2 %>%   waasb(ENV, GEN, REP,         resp = c(KW, NKE, PH, EH, TKW),         mresp = c("h, h, l, l, h"),         wresp = 65) %>% # Default is 50   mtsi(SI = 20) # Factor analysis gmd(MTSI_index2, "FA") %>% print_table()

title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: MGIDI index can seen MTSI index weigth 100 mean performance. index computed function mgidi(). , use example data data_g(). default, traits assumed increased. change default, use argument ideotype. example, three traits, first one assumed decreased last two assumed increased, use ideotype = c("l, h, h").
code: mod <- gamem(data_g,              gen = GEN,              rep = REP,              resp = everything()) mgidi_index <- mgidi(mod,                      SI = 20) # Selection intensity p1 <- plot(mgidi_index, SI = 20) p2 <- plot(mgidi_index, type = "contribution") arrange_ggplot(p1, p2)

title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: Smith-Hazel index ((Smith 1936; Hazel 1943)) computed function Smith_Hazel(). Users can compute index either declaring known genetic phenotypic variance-covariance matrices using inpute data, model fitted function gamem(). case, variance-covariance extracted internally. economic weights argument weights set default 1 traits.
code: smith <- Smith_Hazel(mod, SI = 20)

title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: FAI-BLUP multi-trait index based factor analysis ideotype-design recently proposed Rocha, Machado, Carneiro (2018). based factor analysis, factorial scores ideotype designed according desirable undesirable factors. , spatial probability estimated based genotype-ideotype distance, enabling genotype ranking (Rocha, Machado, Carneiro 2018). use mixed-model mod inpute data. default, selection made increase value traits. Change default arguments DI UI.
code: fai <- fai_blup(mod, SI = 20) plot(fai)

title: Indexes for simultaneous selection
text: function coincidence_indexes() can used compute coincidence index described Hamblin Zimmermann (1986), among multi-trait indexes implemented metan. , just use comma-separated list indexes inpute data inform total number genotypes. can also produce Venn plot show relationships indexes
code: coincidence <- coincidence_index(mgidi_index, fai, smith, total = 13) coincidence # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # Coincidence index and common genotypes # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # # A tibble: 3 × 5 #   V1          V2     index common genotypes #   <chr>       <chr>  <dbl>  <int> <chr>     # 1 mgidi_index fai   100         3 H13,H5,H2 # 2 mgidi_index smith  56.71      2 H13,H5    # 3 fai         smith  56.71      2 H5,H13 MGIDI <- gmd(mgidi_index, "sel_gen") # Class of the model: mgidi # Variable extracted: sel_gen FAI <- gmd(fai, "sel_gen") # Class of the model: fai_blup # Variable extracted: sel_gen SH <- gmd(smith, "sel_gen") # Class of the model: sh # Variable extracted: sel_gen  # Create the plot venn_plot(MGIDI, FAI, SH, show_elements = TRUE)
