title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: section, use data data_ge data_ge2. information see ?data_ge ?data_ge2, respectively. data sets can used provided following columns data_ge: environment, genotype, block/replicate response variable(s). See section Rendering engine know HTML tables generated.

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: function ge_plot() may used visualize genotype’s performance across environments.  identify winner genotype within environment, can use function ge_winners(). get genotype ranking within environment. details trials, can use ge_details()
code: library(metan) a <- ge_plot(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY) b <- ge_plot(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY) + ggplot2::coord_flip() arrange_ggplot(a, b, tag_levels = "a") ge_winners(data_ge2, ENV, GEN, resp = everything()) %>% print_table() ge_winners(data_ge2, ENV, GEN, resp = everything(), type = "ranks") %>%    print_table() ge_details(data_ge2, ENV, GEN, resp = everything()) %>%    print_table()

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: function anova_ind() can used compute within-environment analysis variance. Environment values blue significant (p < 0.05) genotype effect.
code: ind <- anova_ind(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY) # Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:00  print_table(ind$GY$individual)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: function make_mat() can used produce two-way table genotype-environment means.
code: make_mat(data_ge, GEN, ENV, GY) %>% print_table(rownames = TRUE)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: function ge_effects() used compute genotype-environment effects.
code: ge_ef <- ge_effects(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY) print_table(ge_ef$GY)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: obtain genotype plus genotype-environment effects, can use argument type =  "gge" function ge_effects().
code: gge_ef <- ge_effects(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY, type = "gge") print_table(gge_ef$GY)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: function ge_cluster() computes cluster analysis grouping environments based similarities using Euclidean distance based standardized data. Line means divided phenotypic standard error relevant environment mean subtracted. standardizing data environment mean zero unit variance, effect variability phenotypic variance (well mean) reduced (Fox Rosielle 1982).  function env_dissimilarity() computes dissimilarity test environment using: partition partition mean square genotype-environment interaction (MS_GE) single (S) complex (C) parts, according Robertson (1959), \(S = \frac{1}{2}(\sqrt{Q_1}-\sqrt{Q_2})^2)\) \(C = (1-r)\sqrt{Q1-Q2}\), \(r\) correlation genotype’s average two environments; \(Q_1\) \(Q_2\) genotype mean square environments 1 2, respectively decomposition MS_GE, complex part given \(C = \sqrt{(1-r)^3\times Q1\times Q2}\) (Cruz Castoldi 1991). interaction mean square genotypes pairs environments. correlation coefficients genotypes’s average pair environment. obtain dendrograms based matrix can use plot(). dendrograms based hierarchical clustering algorithm UPGMA (Unweighted Pair Group Method using Arithmetic averages).
code: d1 <- ge_cluster(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY, nclust = 4) plot(d1, nclust = 4) mod <- env_dissimilarity(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY) # Evaluating trait Y |=============================================| 100% 00:00:00  # Pearson's correlation coefficient print_table(mod$GY$correlation, rownames = TRUE) plot(mod)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: Eberhart Russell (1966) popularized regression-based stability analysis. procedures, adaptability stability analysis performed means adjustments regression equations dependent variable predicted function environmental index, according following model: \[ \mathop Y\nolimits_{ij}  = {\beta _{0i}} + {\beta _{1i}}{I_j} + {\delta _{ij}} + {\bar \varepsilon _{ij}} \] \({\beta _{0i}}\) grand mean genotype (= 1, 2, …, ); \({\beta _{1i}}\) linear response (slope) genotype environmental index; Ij environmental index (j = 1, 2, …, e), \({I_j} = [(y_{.j}/g)- (y_{..}/ge)]\), \({\delta _{ij}}\) deviation regression, \({\bar \varepsilon _{ij}}\) experimental error. model fitted function ge_reg(). S3 methods plot() summary() may used explore fitted model.
code: reg_model <- ge_reg(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY) # Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:00  print_table(reg_model$GY$anova)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: Annicchiarico (1992) proposed stability method stability parameter measured superiority genotype relation average environment, according following model: \[ {Z_{ij}} = \frac{{{Y_{ij}}}}{{{{\bar Y}_{.j}}}} \times 100 \] genotypic confidence index genotype (\(W_i\)) estimated follows: \[ W_i = Z_{.}/e - \alpha \times sd(Z_{.}) \] \(\alpha\) quantile standard normal distribution given probability error (\(\alpha \approx 1.64\) 0.05). method implemented using function Annicchiarico(). confidence index estimated considering environment, favorable environments (positive index) unfavorable environments (negative index), follows:

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
code: ann5 <- Annicchiarico(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY) # Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:00  ann1 <- Annicchiarico(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY, prob = 0.01) # Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:00

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
code: print_table(ann5$GY$environments)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
code: print_table(ann5$GY$general)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: function superiority() implements nonparametric method proposed Lin Binns (1988), considers measure cultivar general superiority cultivar x location data defined distance mean square cultivar’s response maximum response averaged locations, according following model. \[ P_i = \sum\limits_{j = 1}^n{(y_{ij} - y_{.j})^2/(2n)} \] n number environments Similar genotypic confidence index, superiority index calculated environments, favorable, unfavorable environments.
code: super <- superiority(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY) # Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:00  print_table(super$GY$index)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: method combines stability analysis environmental stratification using factor analysis proposed Murakami Cruz (2004). method implemented function ge_factanal(), follows:
code: fact <- ge_factanal(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, GY) plot(fact) print_table(fact$GY$PCA)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: easiest way compute -mentioned stability indexes using function ge_stats(). wrapper function computes stability indexes . get results “ready--read” file, use get_model_data(). also possible obtain Spearman’s rank correlation stability indexes using corr_stab_ind().
code: stat_ge <- data_ge2 %>% ge_stats(ENV, GEN, REP, resp = c(EH, PH)) # Evaluating trait EH |======================                      | 50% 00:00:03  Evaluating trait PH |============================================| 100% 00:00:06  get_model_data(stat_ge, "stats") %>% print_table() # Class of the model: ge_stats # Variable extracted: stats corr_stab_ind(stat_ge)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics
text: vignette built pkgdown. tables produced package DT using following function.
code: library(DT) # Used to make the tables # Function to make HTML tables print_table <- function(table, rownames = FALSE, digits = 3, ...){   df <- datatable(table, rownames = rownames, extensions = 'Buttons',                   options = list(scrollX = TRUE,                                   dom = '<<t>Bp>',                                  buttons = c('copy', 'excel', 'pdf', 'print')), ...)   num_cols <- c(as.numeric(which(sapply(table, class) == "numeric")))   if(length(num_cols) > 0){     formatSignif(df, columns = num_cols, digits = digits)   } else{     df   } }

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: functions add_cols() add_rows() can used add columns rows, respectively data frame. also possible add column based existing data. Note arguments ..used select position new column(s). particularly useful put variables category together.
code: library(metan) add_cols(data_ge,          ROW_ID = 1:420) %>%    print_table() add_cols(data_ge,          GY2 = GY^2,          .after = GY) %>%    print_table()

what: Select or remove columns and rows
title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: functions select_cols() select_rows() can used select columns rows, respectively data frame. Numeric columns can selected quickly using function select_numeric_cols(). Non-numeric columns selected select_non_numeric_cols() can select first last columns quickly select_first_col() select_last_col(), respectively. remove columns rows, use remove_cols() remove_rows().
code: select_cols(data_ge2, ENV, GEN) %>% print_table() select_numeric_cols(data_ge2) %>% print_table() select_first_col(data_ge2) %>% print_table() remove_cols(data_ge2, ENV, GEN)  %>% print_table()

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: function concatetate() can used concatenate multiple columns data frame. return data frame original columns .data plus concatenated variable, last column (default), position using arguments ... drop existing variables keep concatenated column, use argument drop = TRUE. use concatenate() within given function like add_cols() use argument pull = TRUE pull results vector. check column exists data frame, use column_exists()
code: concatenate(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, .after = REP) %>% print_table() concatenate(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, drop = TRUE) %>% head() # # A tibble: 6 × 1 #   new_var #   <chr>   # 1 E1_G1_1 # 2 E1_G1_2 # 3 E1_G1_3 # 4 E1_G2_1 # 5 E1_G2_2 # 6 E1_G2_3 concatenate(data_ge, ENV, GEN, REP, pull = TRUE) %>% head() # [1] "E1_G1_1" "E1_G1_2" "E1_G1_3" "E1_G2_1" "E1_G2_2" "E1_G2_3" column_exists(data_ge, "ENV") # [1] TRUE

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: get levels size levels factor, functions get_levels() get_level_size() can used.

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: function round_cols()round selected column whole data frame specified number decimal places (default 0). variables informed, numeric variables rounded. Alternatively, select variables round.
code: round_cols(data_ge2) %>% print_table() round_cols(data_ge2, PH, EP, digits = 1)  %>% print_table()

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: functions extract_number(), replace_number() can used extract replace numbers. example, extract number genotype data_g. replace numbers given column specified replacement, use replace_number(). default, numbers replaced ““.
code: extract_number(data_ge, GEN) %>% print_table() replace_number(data_ge, GEN) %>% print_table()

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: functions extract_string(), replace_string() used context extract_number(), replace_number(), handling strings. replace strings, can use function replace_strings(). remove strings data frame, use remove_strings().
code: extract_string(data_ge, GEN) %>% print_table() replace_string(data_ge,                GEN,                replacement = "GENOTYPE_") %>%    print_table() remove_strings(data_ge) %>% print_table()

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: function tidy_strings() tidy characters strings, non-numeric columns, selected columns data frame putting word upper case, replacing space, tabulation, punctuation characters '_', putting '_' lower upper cases. Consider following character strings: messy_env definition represent unique level factor environment (environment 1). messy_gen shows six genotypes, messy_int represents interaction genotypes environment 1. character vectors visually messy. Let’s tidy . tidy_strings() works also tidy whole data frame specific columns. Let’s create ‘messy’ data frame context plant breeding trials.
code: messy_env <- c("ENV 1", "Env   1", "Env1", "env1", "Env.1", "Env_1") messy_gen <- c("GEN1", "gen 2", "Gen.3", "gen-4", "Gen_5", "GEN_6") messy_int <- c("Env1Gen1", "Env1_Gen2", "env1 gen3", "Env1 Gen4", "ENV_1GEN5", "ENV1GEN6") tidy_strings(messy_env) # [1] "ENV_1" "ENV_1" "ENV_1" "ENV_1" "ENV_1" "ENV_1" tidy_strings(messy_gen) # [1] "GEN_1" "GEN_2" "GEN_3" "GEN_4" "GEN_5" "GEN_6" tidy_strings(messy_int) # [1] "ENV_1_GEN_1" "ENV_1_GEN_2" "ENV_1_GEN_3" "ENV_1_GEN_4" "ENV_1_GEN_5" # [6] "ENV_1_GEN_6" library(tibble) #  # Attaching package: 'tibble' # The following objects are masked from 'package:metan': #  #     column_to_rownames, remove_rownames, rownames_to_column df <- tibble(Env = messy_env,              gen = messy_gen,              Env_GEN = interaction(Env, gen),              y = rnorm(6, 300, 10)) df %>% print_table()

title: Utilities for data manipulation
text: vignette built pkgdown. tables produced package DT using following function.
code: library(metan) library(DT) # Used to make the tables # Function to make HTML tables print_table <- function(table, rownames = FALSE, digits = 3, ...){   df <- datatable(table, rownames = rownames, extensions = 'Buttons',                   options = list(scrollX = TRUE,                                   dom = '<<t>Bp>',                                  buttons = c('copy', 'excel', 'pdf', 'print')), ...)   num_cols <- c(as.numeric(which(sapply(table, class) == "numeric")))   if(length(num_cols) > 0){     formatSignif(df, columns = num_cols, digits = digits)   } else{     df   } }

title: Contributing to metan
text: Small typos grammatical errors documentation may edited directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. YES: edit roxygen comment .R file R/. : edit .Rd file man/.

title: Contributing to metan
text: make substantial pull request, always file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s problem. ’ve found bug, create associated issue illustrate bug minimal reprex.

title: Contributing to metan
text: recommend create Git branch pull request (PR). Look Travis AppVeyor build status making changes. README contain badges continuous integration services used package. New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md current development version header describing changes made followed GitHub username, links relevant issue(s)/PR(s).

title: Contributing to metan
text: Please note metan project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: metan
text: metan (multi-environment trials analysis) provides useful functions analyzing multi-environment trial data using parametric non-parametric methods. package help : Inspect data possible common errors; Manipulate rows columns; Manipulate numbers strings; Manipulate NAs 0s; Compute descriptive statistics; Compute within-environment joint-analysis variance; Compute AMMI analysis prediction considering different numbers interaction principal component axes; Compute AMMI-based stability indexes; Compute GGE biplot analysis; Compute GT GYT biplot analysis; Compute BLUP-based stability indexes; Compute variance components genetic parameters single environment multi-environment trials using mixed-effect models; Perform cross-validation procedures AMMI-family BLUP models; Compute parametric nonparametric stability statistics; Implement biometrical models.

title: metan
text: Install released version metan CRAN : install development version GitHub : Note: Windows user, also first download install latest version Rtools. latest release notes development version, see NEWS file.
code: install.packages("metan") devtools::install_github("TiagoOlivoto/metan")  # To build the HTML vignette use devtools::install_github("TiagoOlivoto/metan", build_vignettes = TRUE)

title: metan
text: metan offers set functions can used manipulate, summarize, analyze plot typical multi-environment trial data. Maybe, one first functions users use inspect(). , inspect example dataset data_ge contains data two variables assessed 10 genotypes growing 14 environments.  issues inspecting data. issue given (like outliers, missing values, etc.) consider using find_outliers() find possible outliers data set metan’s data manipulation tool remove_rows_na() remove rows NA values, replace_zero() replace 0’s NA, as_factor() convert desired columns factor, find_text_in_num() find text fragments columns assumed numeric, even tidy_strings() tidy strings.
code: library(metan) inspect(data_ge, plot = TRUE) # # A tibble: 5 × 10 #   Variable Class   Missing Levels Valid_n   Min Median   Max Outlier Text  #   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <int> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <lgl> # 1 ENV      factor  No      14         420 NA     NA    NA         NA NA    # 2 GEN      factor  No      10         420 NA     NA    NA         NA NA    # 3 REP      factor  No      3          420 NA     NA    NA         NA NA    # 4 GY       numeric No      -          420  0.67   2.61  5.09       0 NA    # 5 HM       numeric No      -          420 38     48    58          0 NA

title: metan
text: metan provides set functions compute descriptive statistics. easiest way using desc_stat().

title: metan
text: AMMI model fitted function performs_ammi(). analyze multiple variables can use comma-separated vector unquoted variable names, use select helper argument resp. , using everything() apply function numeric variables data. details, see complete vignette.
code: model <- performs_ammi(data_ge,                        env = ENV,                        gen = GEN,                        rep = REP,                        resp = everything(),                        verbose = FALSE) # Significance of IPCAs get_model_data(model, "ipca_pval") # Class of the model: performs_ammi # Variable extracted: Pr(>F) # # A tibble: 9 × 4 #   PC       DF     GY     HM #   <chr> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> # 1 PC1      21 0      0      # 2 PC2      19 0      0      # 3 PC3      17 0.0014 0.0021 # 4 PC4      15 0.0096 0.0218 # 5 PC5      13 0.318  0.0377 # 6 PC6      11 0.561  0.041  # 7 PC7       9 0.754  0.0633 # 8 PC8       7 0.804  0.232  # 9 PC9       5 0.934  0.944

title: metan
text: well-known AMMI1 AMMI2 biplots can created plot_scores(). Note since performs_ammi allows analyzing multiple variables , e.g., resp = c(v1, v2, ...), output model list, case two elements (GY HM). default, biplots created first variable model. choose another variable use argument var (e.g., var = "HM").
code: a <- plot_scores(model) b <- plot_scores(model,                  type = 2, # AMMI 2 biplot                  polygon = TRUE, # show a polygon                  highlight = c("G4", "G5", "G6"), #highlight genotypes                  col.alpha.env = 0.5, # alpha for environments                  col.alpha.gen = 0, # remove the other genotypes                  col.env = "gray", # color for environment point                  col.segm.env = "gray", # color for environment segment                  plot_theme = theme_metan_minimal()) # theme arrange_ggplot(a, b, tag_levels = "a")

title: metan
text: GGE model fitted function gge(). details, see complete vignette.
code: model <- gge(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY) model2 <- gge(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY, svp = "genotype") model3 <- gge(data_ge, ENV, GEN, GY, svp = "symmetrical") a <- plot(model) b <- plot(model2, type = 8) c <- plot(model2,           type = 2,           col.gen = "black",           col.env = "gray70",           axis.expand = 1.5,           plot_theme = theme_metan_minimal()) arrange_ggplot(a, b, c, tag_levels = "a")

title: metan
text: Linear-mixed effect models predict response variable METs fitted using function gamem_met(). obtain predicted means genotypes variables GY HM. details, see complete vignette.
code: model2 <-    gamem_met(data_ge,             env = ENV,             gen = GEN,             rep = REP,             resp = everything()) # Evaluating trait GY |======================                      | 50% 00:00:01 Evaluating trait HM |============================================| 100% 00:00:02  # Method: REML/BLUP # Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV # Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) # Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #     model       GY       HM #  COMPLETE       NA       NA #       GEN 1.11e-05 5.07e-03 #   GEN:ENV 2.15e-11 2.27e-15 # --------------------------------------------------------------------------- # All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction # Get the variance components get_model_data(model2, what = "vcomp") # Class of the model: waasb # Variable extracted: vcomp # # A tibble: 3 × 3 #   Group        GY    HM #   <chr>     <dbl> <dbl> # 1 GEN      0.0280 0.490 # 2 GEN:ENV  0.0567 2.19  # 3 Residual 0.0967 2.84

title: metan
text: produce plot predicted means, use function plot_blup().
code: a <- plot_blup(model2) b <- plot_blup(model2,                prob = 0.2,                col.shape = c("gray20", "gray80"),                invert = TRUE) arrange_ggplot(a, b, tag_levels = "a")

title:
Adjusted Coefficient of Variation
 — acv
text: Computes scale-adjusted coefficient variation, acv, (Doring Reckling, 2018) account systematic dependence \(\sigma^2\) \(\mu\). acv computed follows: \[acv = \frac{\sqrt{10^{\tilde v_i}}}{\mu_i}\times 100\] \(\tilde v_i\) adjusted logarithm variance computed : \[\tilde v_i = + (b - 2)\frac{1}{n}\sum m_i + 2m_i + e_i\] \(\) \(b\) coefficients linear regression \(log_{10}\) variance \(log_{10}\) mean; \( m_i\) \(log_{10}\) mean, \( e_i\) Power Law Residuals (POLAR), .e., residuals previously described regression.

title:
Adjusted Coefficient of Variation
 — acv
code: acv(mean, var, na.rm = FALSE)

title:
Adjusted Coefficient of Variation
 — acv
text: mean numeric vector mean values. var numeric vector variance values. na.rm FALSE, default, missing values removed warning. TRUE, missing values silently removed.

title:
Adjusted Coefficient of Variation
 — acv
text: tibble following columns mean mean values; var variance values; log10_mean base 10 logarithm mean; log10_var base 10 logarithm variance; POLAR Power Law Residuals; cv standard coefficient variation; acv Adjusted coefficient variation.

Adjusted Coefficient of Variation

AMMI-based stability indexes — ammi_indexes
text: ammi_indexes()  computes several AMMI-based stability statistics. See Details detailed overview. AMMI_indexes()  use ammi_indexes() instead.

title: AMMI-based stability indexes — ammi_indexes
code: ammi_indexes(.data, order.y = NULL, level = 0.95)  AMMI_indexes(.data, order.y = NULL, level = 0.95)

title: AMMI-based stability indexes — ammi_indexes
text: .data object class waas performs_ammi order.y vector length x used order response variable. element vector must one 'h' 'l'. 'h' used, response variable ordered maximum minimum. 'l' used response variable ordered minimum maximum. Use comma-separated vector names. example, order.y = c("h, h, l, h, l"). level confidence level. Defaults 0.95.

title: AMMI-based stability indexes — ammi_indexes
text: list element contains result AMMI-based stability indexes one variable.

title: AMMI-based stability indexes — ammi_indexes
text: First, define symbols: \(N'\) number significant interation principal component axis (IPCs) retained AMMI model via F tests); \(\lambda_{n}\) singular value th IPC correspondingly \(\lambda_{n}^{2}\) eigen value; \(\gamma_{}\) eigenvector value ith genotype; \(\delta_{jn}\) eigenvector value th environment. \(PC_{1}\), \(PC_{2}\), \(PC_{n}\) scores 1st, 2nd, nth IPC; respectively; \(\theta_{1}\), \(\theta_{2}\), \(\theta_{n}\)  percentage sum squares explained 1st, 2nd, nth IPC, respectively.  AMMI Based Stability Parameter (ASTAB) (Rao Prabhakaran 2005). \[ASTAB = \sum_{n=1}^{N'}\lambda_{n}\gamma_{}^{2}\] AMMI Stability Index (ASI) (Jambhulkar et al. 2017) \[ASI = \sqrt{\left [ PC_{1}^{2} \times \theta_{1}^{2} \right ]+\left[ PC_{2}^{2} \times \theta_{2}^{2} \right ]}\] AMMI-stability value (ASV) (Purchase et al., 2000). \[ASV_{}=\sqrt{\frac{SS_{IPCA1}}{SS_{IPCA2}}(\mathrm{IPC} \mathrm{} 1)^{2}+(\mathrm{IPCA} 2)^{2}}\] Sum Across Environments Absolute Value GEI Modelled AMMI (AVAMGE) (Zali et al. 2012) \[AV_{(AMGE)} = \sum_{j=1}^{E} \sum_{n=1}^{N'} \left |\lambda_{n}\gamma_{} \delta_{jn} \right |\] Annicchiarico's D Parameter values (Da) (Annicchiarico 1997) \[D_{} = \sqrt{\sum_{n=1}^{N'}(\lambda_{n}\gamma_{})^2}\] Zhang's D Parameter (Dz) (Zhang et al. 1998) \[D_{z} = \sqrt{\sum_{n=1}^{N'}\gamma_{}^{2}}\] Sums Averages Squared Eigenvector Values (EV) (Zobel 1994) \[EV = \sum_{n=1}^{N'}\frac{\gamma_{}^2}{N'}\] Stability Measure Based Fitted AMMI Model (FA) (Raju 2002) \[FA = \sum_{n=1}^{N'}\lambda_{n}^{2}\gamma_{}^{2}\] Modified AMMI Stability Index (MASI) (Ajay et al. 2018) \[MASI = \sqrt{ \sum_{n=1}^{N'} PC_{n}^{2} \times \theta_{n}^{2}}\] Modified AMMI Stability Value (MASV) (Ajay et al. 2019) \[MASV = \sqrt{\sum_{n=1}^{N'-1}\left (\frac{SSIPC_{n}}{SSIPC_{n+1}} \right ) \times (PC_{n})^2   + \left (PC_{N'}\right )^2}\] Sums Absolute Value IPC Scores (SIPC) (Sneller et al. 1997) \[SIPC = \sum_{n=1}^{N'} | \lambda_{n}^{0.5}\gamma_{}|\] Absolute Value Relative Contribution IPCs Interaction (Za) (Zali et al. 2012) \[Za = \sum_{=1}^{N'} | \theta_{n}\gamma_{} |\] Weighted average absolute scores (WAAS) (Olivoto et al. 2019) \[WAAS_i = \sum_{k = 1}^{p} |IPCA_{ik} \times \theta_{k}/ \sum_{k = 1}^{p}\theta_{k}\] statistics, simultaneous selection indexes (SSI) also computed summation ranks stability mean performance, Y_R, (Farshadfar, 2008).

title: AMMI-based stability indexes — ammi_indexes
text: Ajay BC, Aravind J, Abdul Fiyaz R, Bera SK, Kumar N, Gangadhar K, Kona P (2018). “Modified AMMI Stability Index (MASI) stability analysis.” ICAR-DGR Newsletter, 18, 4–5. Ajay BC, Aravind J, Fiyaz RA, Kumar N, Lal C, Gangadhar K, Kona P, Dagla MC, Bera SK (2019). “Rectification modified AMMI stability value (MASV).” Indian Journal Genetics Plant Breeding (), 79, 726–731. https://www.isgpb.org/article/rectification--modified-ammi-stability-value-masv. Annicchiarico P (1997). “Joint regression vs AMMI analysis genotype-environment interactions cereals Italy.” Euphytica, 94(1), 53–62. doi:10.1023/:1002954824178 Farshadfar E (2008) Incorporation AMMI stability value grain yield single non-parametric index (GSI) bread wheat. Pakistan J Biol Sci 11:1791–1796. doi:10.3923/pjbs.2008.1791.1796 Jambhulkar NN, Rath NC, Bose LK, Subudhi HN, Biswajit M, Lipi D, Meher J (2017). “Stability analysis grain yield rice demonstrations conducted rabi season India.” Oryza, 54(2), 236–240. doi:10.5958/2249-5266.2017.00030.3 Olivoto T, LUcio ADC, Silva JAG, et al (2019) Mean Performance Stability Multi-Environment Trials : Combining Features AMMI BLUP Techniques. Agron J 111:2949–2960. doi:10.2134/agronj2019.03.0220 Raju BMK (2002). “study AMMI model biplots.” Journal Indian Society Agricultural Statistics, 55(3), 297–322. Rao AR, Prabhakaran VT (2005). “Use AMMI simultaneous selection genotypes yield stability.” Journal Indian Society Agricultural Statistics, 59, 76–82. Sneller CH, Kilgore-Norquest L, Dombek D (1997). “Repeatability yield stability statistics soybean.” Crop Science, 37(2), 383–390. doi:10.2135/cropsci1997.0011183X003700020013x Zali H, Farshadfar E, Sabaghpour SH, Karimizadeh R (2012). “Evaluation genotype × environment interaction chickpea using measures stability AMMI model.” Annals Biological Research, 3(7), 3126–3136. Zhang Z, Lu C, Xiang Z (1998). “Analysis variety stability based AMMI model.” Acta Agronomica Sinica, 24(3), 304–309. http://zwxb.chinacrops.org/EN/Y1998/V24/I03/304. Within-environment analysis of variance — anova_ind
text: Performs within-environment analysis variance randomized complete block alpha-lattice designs returns values Mean Squares, p-values, coefficient variation, heritability, accuracy selection.

title: Within-environment analysis of variance — anova_ind
code: anova_ind(.data, env, gen, rep, resp, block = NULL, verbose = TRUE)

title: Within-environment analysis of variance — anova_ind
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. analysis variance computed level factor. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) employed. effects, except error, assumed fixed. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently.

title: Within-environment analysis of variance — anova_ind
text: list element result one variable containing (1) individual: tidy tbl_df results individual analysis variance following column names, (2) MSRatio: ratio higher lower residual mean square. following columns returned, depending experimental design analysis alpha-lattice designs: MEAN: grand mean. DFG, DFCR, DFIB_R, DFE: degree freedom genotype, complete replicates, incomplete blocks within replicates, error, respectively. MSG, MSCR, MSIB_R: mean squares genotype, replicates, incomplete blocks within replicates, error, respectively. FCG, FCR, FCIB_R: F-calculated genotype, replicates incomplete blocks within replicates, respectively. PFG, PFCR, PFIB_R: P-values genotype, replicates incomplete blocks within replicates, respectively. CV: coefficient variation. h2: broad-sense heritability. : accuracy selection (square root h2) analysis randomized complete block design: MEAN: grand mean. DFG, DFB, DFE: degree freedom genotype blocks, error, respectively. MSG, MSB, MSE: mean squares genotype blocks, error, respectively. FCG FCB: F-calculated genotype blocks, respectively. PFG PFB: P-values genotype blocks, respectively. CV: coefficient variation. h2: broad-sense heritability. : accuracy selection (square root h2)

title: Fast way to create bar plots — barplots
text: plot_bars() Creates bar plot based one categorical variable one numeric variable.  can used show results one-way trial qualitative treatments. plot_factbars() Creates bar plot based two categorical variables one numeric variable.  can used show results two-way trial qualitative-qualitative treatment structure.

code: plot_bars(   .data,   x,   y,   order = NULL,   y.lim = NULL,   y.breaks = waiver(),   y.expand = 0.05,   y.contract = 0,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   n.dodge = 1,   check.overlap = FALSE,   color.bar = "black",   fill.bar = "gray",   lab.bar = NULL,   lab.bar.hjust = 0.5,   lab.bar.vjust = -0.5,   lab.bar.angle = 0,   size.text.bar = 5,   values = FALSE,   values.hjust = 0.5,   values.vjust = 1.5,   values.angle = 0,   values.digits = 2,   values.size = 4,   lab.x.hjust = 0.5,   lab.x.vjust = 1,   lab.x.angle = 0,   errorbar = TRUE,   stat.erbar = "se",   width.erbar = NULL,   level = 0.95,   invert = FALSE,   width.bar = 0.9,   size.line = 0.5,   size.text = 12,   fontfam = "sans",   na.rm = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   plot_theme = theme_metan() )  plot_factbars(   .data,   ...,   resp,   y.lim = NULL,   y.breaks = waiver(),   y.expand = 0.05,   y.contract = 0,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   n.dodge = 1,   check.overlap = FALSE,   lab.bar = NULL,   lab.bar.hjust = 0.5,   lab.bar.vjust = -0.5,   lab.bar.angle = 0,   size.text.bar = 5,   values = FALSE,   values.hjust = 0.5,   values.vjust = 1.5,   values.angle = 0,   values.digits = 2,   values.size = 4,   lab.x.hjust = 0.5,   lab.x.vjust = 1,   lab.x.angle = 0,   errorbar = TRUE,   stat.erbar = "se",   width.erbar = NULL,   level = 0.95,   invert = FALSE,   col = TRUE,   palette = "Spectral",   width.bar = 0.9,   legend.position = "bottom",   size.line = 0.5,   size.text = 12,   fontfam = "sans",   na.rm = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE,   plot_theme = theme_metan() )

title: Fast way to create bar plots — barplots
text: .data data set. x, y Argument valid plot_bars() variables mapped x y axes, respectively. order Argument valid plot_bars(). Controls order factor x axis. Defaults order factors .data. Use order = "asce" order = "desc" reorder labels ascending descending order, respectively, based values variable y. y.lim range y axis. Defaults NULL (maximum minimum values data set). New values can inserted y.lim = c(y.min, y.max). y.breaks breaks plotted y-axis. Defaults waiver(). authomatic breaks. arguments x.breaks can used. y.expand, y.contract multiplication range expansion/contraction factor. y.expand expands upper limit y escale, y.contract contracts lower limit y scale. default y.expand = 0.05 y.contract = 0 produces plot without spacing lower y limit expansion upper y limit. xlab, ylab labels axes x y, respectively. Defaults NULL. n.dodge number rows used render x labels. useful displaying labels otherwise overlap. check.overlap Silently remove overlapping labels, (recursively) prioritizing first, last, middle labels. color.bar, fill.bar Argument valid plot_bars(). color fill values bars. lab.bar vector characters show bar. Defaults NULL. lab.bar.hjust, lab.bar.vjust horizontal vertical adjust labels bar. Defaults 0.5 -0.5, respectively. lab.bar.angle angle labels plot. Defaults 0. Use combination lab.bar.hjust lab.bar.vjust best fit labels plot. size.text.bar size text bar labels. values Logical argument. Shows values plot bar? Defaults FALSE values.hjust, values.vjust horizontal vertical adjust values bar. Defaults 0.5 1.5, respectively. values = TRUE values shown bellow error bar. values.angle angle labels plot. Defaults 0. Use combination values.hjust values.vjust best fit values plot bar. values.digits significant digits show values = TRUE. Defaults 2. values.size size text values shown bars. Defaults 3. lab.x.hjust, lab.x.vjust horizontal vertical adjust labels bar. Defaults 0.5 1, respectively. lab.x.angle angle labels x axis. Defaults 0. Use combination lab.x.hjust lab.x.vjust best fit labels axis. errorbar Logical argument, set TRUE. case, error bar shown. stat.erbar statistic shown errorbar. Must one stat.erbar = "se" (standard error, default), stat.erbar = "sd" (standard deviation), stat.erbar = "ci" (confidence interval), based confidence level argument level. width.erbar width error bar. Defaults 25% width.bar. level confidence level invert Logical argument. TRUE, rotate plot plot_bars() invert order factors plot_factbars(). width.bar width bars graph. Defaults 0.9. Possible values range 0-1. size.line size line bars. Default 0.5. size.text size text. Default 12. fontfam family font text. Defaults "sans". na.rm 'NA' values removed compute statistics? Defaults true verbose Logical argument. TRUE tibble containing mean, N, standard deviation, standard error mean confidence interval returned. plot_theme graphical theme plot. Default plot_theme = theme_metan(). details, see ggplot2::theme(). ... Argument valid plot_factbars(). comma-separated list unquoted variable names. Sets two variables mapped x axis. resp Argument valid plot_factbars(). response variable mapped y axis. col Logical argument valid plot_factbars(). FALSE, gray scale used. palette Argument valid plot_factbars() color palette used. details, see ?scale_colour_brewer legend.position position legend plot.

code: # \donttest{ library(metan) # Two examples with only 5 resampling procedures AMMI <- cv_ammi(data_ge,                 resp = GY,                 gen = GEN,                 env = ENV,                 rep = REP,                 nboot = 5) #> Validating 1 of 5 sets |========                                 | 20% 00:00:00  Validating 2 of 5 sets |================                         | 40% 00:00:01  Validating 3 of 5 sets |=========================                | 60% 00:00:01  Validating 4 of 5 sets |=================================        | 80% 00:00:02  Validating 5 of 5 sets |=========================================| 100% 00:00:03   BLUP <- cv_blup(data_ge,                 resp = GY,                 gen = GEN,                 env = ENV,                 rep = REP,                 nboot = 5) #> Validating 1 of 5 sets |========                                 | 20% 00:00:00  Validating 2 of 5 sets |================                         | 40% 00:00:01  Validating 3 of 5 sets |=========================                | 60% 00:00:01  Validating 4 of 5 sets |=================================        | 80% 00:00:02  Validating 5 of 5 sets |=========================================| 100% 00:00:03   bind_data <- bind_cv(AMMI, BLUP) plot(bind_data)   print(bind_cv(AMMI, BLUP, bind = 'means')) #> $RMSPD #>         MODEL      mean         sd          se      Q2.5     Q97.5 #> 1 BLUP_g_RCBD 0.3971465 0.01650126 0.007379588 0.3726176 0.4125433 #> 2       AMMI2 0.4072114 0.02643781 0.011823349 0.3749006 0.4350654 #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "cvalidation" # }

what: Stability indexes based on a mixed-effect model — blup_indexes
title: Stability indexes based on a mixed-effect model — blup_indexes
text: hmgv() Computes harmonic mean genotypic values (HMGV). rpgv() Computes relative performance genotypic values (RPGV). hmrpgv() Computes harmonic mean relative performance genotypic values (HMRPGV). blup_indexes() wrapper around functions also computes WAASB index (Olivoto et al. 2019) object computed waasb() used input data.

title: Stability indexes based on a mixed-effect model — blup_indexes
code: hmgv(model)  rpgv(model)  hmrpgv(model)  blup_indexes(model)

title: Stability indexes based on a mixed-effect model — blup_indexes
text: model object class waasb computed waasb() gamem_met().

title: Stability indexes based on a mixed-effect model — blup_indexes
text: tibble containing indexes.

title: Stability indexes based on a mixed-effect model — blup_indexes
text: indexes computed function used select genotypes stability performance mixed-effect model framework. examples Alves et al (2018), Azevedo Peixoto et al. (2018), Dias et al. (2018) Colombari Filho et al. (2013). HMGV index computed \[HMG{V_i} = \frac{E}{{\sum\limits_{j = 1}^E {\frac{1}{{G{v_{ij}}}}}}}\] \(E\) number environments included analysis, \(Gv_{ij}\) genotypic value (BLUP) ith genotype jth environment. RPGV index computed \[RPGV_i = \frac{1}{E}{\sum\limits_{j = 1}^E {Gv_{ij}} /\mathop \mu \nolimits_j }\] HMRPGV index computed \[HMRPG{V_i} = \frac{E}{{\sum\limits_{j = 1}^E {\frac{1}{{G{v_{ij}}/{\mu _j}}}} }}\]

title: Stability indexes based on a mixed-effect model — blup_indexes

title: Canonical correlation analysis — can_corr
text: .data data analyzed. can data frame (possible grouped data passed dplyr::group_by(). FG, SG comma-separated list unquoted variable names compose first (smallest) second (highest) group correlation analysis, respectively. Select helpers also allowed. One variable (factor) compute function . shortcut dplyr::group_by(). compute statistics one grouping variable use function. use matrix used. Must one 'cor' analysis using correlation matrix (default) 'cov' analysis using covariance matrix. test test significance relationship FG SG. Must one 'Bartlett' (default) 'Rao'. prob probability error assumed. Set 0.05. center data centered compute scores? stdscores Rescale scores produce scores unit variance? verbose Logical argument. TRUE (default) results shown console. collinearity Logical argument. TRUE (default) collinearity diagnostic performed group variables according Olivoto et al.(2017).

Matrix correlation (covariance) matrix variables MFG, MSG correlation (covariance) matrix variables first group second group, respectively. MFG_SG correlation (covariance) matrix variables first group second group. Coef_FG, Coef_SG Matrix canonical coefficients first group second group, respectively. Loads_FG, Loads_SG Matrix canonical loadings first group second group, respectively. Score_FG, Score_SG Canonical scores variables FG SG, respectively. Crossload_FG, Crossload_FG Canonical cross-loadings FG variables SG scores, cross-loadings SG variables FG scores, respectively. SigTest dataframe correlation canonical pairs hypothesis testing results. collinearity list collinearity diagnostic group variables.

title: Clustering analysis — clustering
text: selvar = TRUE variable selection algorithm executed. objective select group variables contribute explain variability original data. selection variables based eigenvalue/eigenvectors solution based following steps. compute distance matrix cophenetic correlation original variables (numeric variables dataset); compute eigenvalues eigenvectors correlation matrix variables; Delete variable largest weight (highest eigenvector lowest eigenvalue); Compute distance matrix cophenetic correlation remaining variables; Compute Mantel's correlation obtained distances matrix original distance matrix; Iterate steps 2 5 p - 2 times, p number original variables. end p - 2 iterations, summary models returned. distance calculated variables generated model largest cophenetic correlation. suggest careful evaluation aiming choosing parsimonious model, .e., one fewer number variables, presents acceptable cophenetic correlation high similarity original distances.

what: Computes the coincidence index of genotype selection — coincidence_index
title: Computes the coincidence index of genotype selection — coincidence_index
text: Computes coincidence index (Hamblin Zimmermann, 1986) follows: \[CI = \frac{-C}{M-C}\times 100\] number selected genotypes common different methods; C number expected genotypes selected chance; M number genotypes selected according selection intensity.

what: Confidence interval for correlation coefficient — corr_ci
title: Confidence interval for correlation coefficient — corr_ci
text: Computes half-width confidence interval correlation coefficient using nonparametric method proposed Olivoto et al. (2018). half-width confidence interval computed according following equation: \[CI_w = 0.45304^r \times 2.25152 \times n^{-0.50089}\] \(n\) sample size \(r\) correlation coefficient.

text: Computes Spearman's rank correlation parametric nonparametric stability indexes computed function ge_stats().

title: Correlation between stability indexes — corr_stab_ind
code: corr_stab_ind(x, stats = "all", plot = TRUE, ...)

title: Correlation between stability indexes — corr_stab_ind
text: x object class ge_stats. stats statistics compute correlation. See section Details information. plot Plot heat map correlations? Defaults TRUE. ... arguments passed function plot.corr_coef().

title: Correlation between stability indexes — corr_stab_ind
text: list data (ranks) correlation, p-values heat map showing correlation coefficients.

title: Correlation between stability indexes — corr_stab_ind
text: argument stats used chose statistics show ranks. Allowed values "" (statistics, default), "par" (Parametric statistics), "nonpar" (Non-parametric statistics), "ammi" (AMMI-based stability statistics), following values can combined comma-separated character vector. "Y" (Response variable), "Var" (Genotype's variance), "Shukla" (Shukla's variance), "Wi_g", "Wi_f", "Wi_u" (Annichiarrico's genotypic confidence index , favorable unfavorable environments, respectively), "Ecoval" (Wricke's ecovalence), "Sij" (Deviations joint-regression analysis), "R2" (R-squared joint-regression analysis), "ASTAB" (AMMI Based Stability Parameter), "ASI" (AMMI Stability Index), "ASV" (AMMI-stability value), "AVAMGE" (Sum Across Environments Absolute Value GEI Modelled AMMI ), "Da" (Annicchiarico's D Parameter values), "Dz" (Zhang's D Parameter), "EV" (Sums Averages Squared Eigenvector Values), "FA" (Stability Measure Based Fitted AMMI Model), "MASV" (Modified AMMI Stability Value), "SIPC" (Sums Absolute Value IPC Scores), "Za" (Absolute Value Relative Contribution IPCs Interaction), "WAAS" (Weighted average absolute scores), "HMGV" (Harmonic mean genotypic value), "RPGV" (Relative performance genotypic values), "HMRPGV" (Harmonic mean relative performance genotypic values), "Pi_a", "Pi_f", "Pi_u" (Superiority indexes , favorable unfavorable environments, respectively), "Gai" (Geometric adaptability index), "S1" (mean absolute rank differences genotype n environments), "S2" (variance among ranks k environments), "S3" (sum absolute deviations), "S6" (relative sum squares rank genotype), "N1", "N2", "N3", "N4" (Thennarasu"s statistics)).

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_ammi
text: Cross-validation estimation AMMI models original dataset split two datasets: training set validation set. 'training' set combinations (genotype x environment) N-1 replications. 'validation' set remaining replication. splitting dataset modeling validation sets depends design informed. Completely Randomized Block Design (default), alpha-lattice design (declaring block arguments), complete replicates selected within environments. remained replicate serves validation data. design = 'RCD' informed, completely randomly samples made genotype--environment combination (Olivoto et al. 2019). estimated values considering naxis-Interaction Principal Component Axis compared 'validation' data. Root Mean Square Prediction Difference (RMSPD) computed. end boots, list returned. IMPORTANT: data set unbalanced (.e., genotype missing environment) function return error. error also observed combination genotype-environment different number replications observed trial.

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_ammi
code: cv_ammi(   .data,   env,   gen,   rep,   resp,   block = NULL,   naxis = 2,   nboot = 200,   design = "RCBD",   verbose = TRUE )

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_ammi
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. LEAST THREE REPLICATES REQUIRED PERFORM CROSS-VALIDATION. resp response variable. block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) employed. effects, except error, assumed fixed. naxis number axis considered estimation GE effects. nboot number resamples used cross-validation. Defaults 200. design experimental design. Defaults RCBD (Randomized complete Block Design). Completely Randomized Designs inform design = 'CRD'. verbose logical argument define progress bar shown. Default TRUE.

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_ammi
text: object class cv_ammi following items: * RMSPD: vector nboot-estimates Root Mean Squared Prediction Difference predicted validating data. RMSPDmean: mean RMSPDmean estimates. Estimated: data frame contain values (predicted, observed, validation) last loop. Modeling: dataset used modeling data last loop Testing: dataset used testing data last loop.

'validation' set remaining replication. splitting dataset modeling validation sets depends design informed. Root Mean Square Prediction Difference (RMSPD) computed. end boots, list returned. text: Cross-validation blup prediction. function provides cross-validation procedure mixed models using replicate-based data. default, complete blocks randomly selected within environment. iteration, original dataset split two datasets: training validation data. 'training' set combinations (genotype x environment) R - 1 replications. title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_blup
code: cv_blup(   .data,   env,   gen,   rep,   resp,   block = NULL,   nboot = 200,   random = "gen",   verbose = TRUE )

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_blup
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. LEAST THREE REPLICATES REQUIRED PERFORM CROSS-VALIDATION. resp response variable. block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) employed. See fixed random effects considered, see section Details. nboot number resamples used cross-validation. Defaults 200 random effects model assumed random. See Details information. verbose logical argument define progress bar shown. Default TRUE.

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_blup
text: object class cv_blup following items: * RMSPD: vector nboot-estimates root mean squared prediction difference predicted validating data. * RMSPDmean mean RMSPDmean estimates.

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_blup
text: Six models may fitted depending upon values block random arguments. Model 1: block = NULL random = "gen" (default option). model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment assuming genotype genotype-environment interaction random effects. Environments blocks nested within environments assumed fixed factors. Model 2: block = NULL random = "env". model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment treating environment, genotype-environment interaction, blocks nested within environments random factors. Genotypes assumed fixed factors. Model 3: block = NULL random = "". model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment assuming random-effect model, .e., effects (genotypes, environments, genotype-vs-environment interaction blocks nested within environments) assumed random factors. Model 4: block NULL random =   "gen". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming genotype, genotype-environment interaction, incomplete blocks nested within complete replicates random make use inter-block information (Mohring et al., 2015). Complete replicates nested within environments environments assumed fixed factors. Model 5: block NULL random =   "env". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming genotype fixed. sources variation (environment, genotype-environment interaction, complete replicates nested within environments, incomplete blocks nested within replicates) assumed random factors. Model 6: block NULL random =   "". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming effects, except intercept, random factors. IMPORTANT:  error returned combination genotype-environment different number replications observed trial.

title: Cross-validation procedure — cv_blup
text: Olivoto, T., .D.C. L\'ucio, J..G. da silva, V.S. Marchioro, V.Q. de Souza, E. Jost. 2019. Mean performance stability multi-environment trials : Combining features AMMI BLUP techniques. Agron. J. 111:2949-2960. doi:10.2134/agronj2019.03.0220 Patterson, H.D., E.R. Williams. 1976. new class resolvable incomplete block designs. Biometrika 63:83-92. Mohring, J., E. Williams, H.-P. Piepho. 2015. Inter-block information: recover recover ? TAG. Theor. Appl. Genet. 128:1541-54. doi:10.1007/s00122-015-2530-0

title: Simulate genotype and genotype-environment data — data_simula
text: functions simulate genotype genotype-environment data given desired number genotypes, environments effects. effects sampled uniform distribution. example, given 10 genotypes, gen_eff = 30, genotype effects sampled runif(10, min = -30, max = 30). Use argument seed ensure reproducibility. one trait used (nvars > 1), effects seed can passed numeric vector. Single numeric values recycled warning one trait used.

title: Simulate genotype and genotype-environment data — data_simula
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Simulate genotype and genotype-environment data — data_simula
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) # Genotype data (5 genotypes and 3 replicates) gen_data <-    g_simula(ngen = 5,             nrep = 3,             seed = 1) gen_data #> # A tibble: 15 × 3 #>    GEN   REP      V1 #>    <fct> <fct> <dbl> #>  1 H1    B1     96.3 #>  2 H1    B2     91.0 #>  3 H1    B3     94.7 #>  4 H2    B1    103.  #>  5 H2    B2    102.  #>  6 H2    B3     95.0 #>  7 H3    B1    114.  #>  8 H3    B2    109.  #>  9 H3    B3    101.  #> 10 H4    B1    109.  #> 11 H4    B2    126.  #> 12 H4    B3    118.  #> 13 H5    B1     92.0 #> 14 H5    B2     97.2 #> 15 H5    B3     93.8 inspect(gen_data, plot = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 3 × 10 #>   Variable Class   Missing Levels Valid_n   Min Median   Max Outlier Text  #>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>    <int> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <lgl> #> 1 GEN      factor  No      5           15  NA      NA    NA       NA NA    #> 2 REP      factor  No      3           15  NA      NA    NA       NA NA    #> 3 V1       numeric No      -           15  91.0   101.  126.       0 NA    #> Warning: Expected three or more factor variables. The data has only 2.   aov(V1 ~ GEN + REP, data = gen_data) %>% anova() #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Response: V1 #>           Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F)    #> GEN        4 1242.03 310.508 10.1917 0.003146 ** #> REP        2   55.60  27.798  0.9124 0.439611    #> Residuals  8  243.74  30.467                     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1  # Genotype-environment data # 5 genotypes, 3 environments, 4 replicates and 2 traits df <- ge_simula(ngen = 5,           nenv = 3,           nrep = 4,           nvars = 2,           seed = 1) #> Warning: 'gen_eff = 20' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'env_eff = 15' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'rep_eff = 5' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'ge_eff = 10' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'res_eff = 5' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'intercept = 100' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'seed = 1' recycled for all the 2 traits. ge_plot(df, ENV, GEN, V1)  aov(V1 ~ ENV*GEN + ENV/REP, data = df) %>% anova() #> Analysis of Variance Table #>  #> Response: V1 #>           Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq  F value    Pr(>F)     #> ENV        2   363.7  181.83  13.0240 5.551e-05 *** #> GEN        4 12319.5 3079.87 220.6002 < 2.2e-16 *** #> ENV:GEN    8   643.9   80.48   5.7647 9.551e-05 *** #> ENV:REP    9   426.2   47.36   3.3920   0.00415 **  #> Residuals 36   502.6   13.96                        #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1  # Change genotype effect (trait 1 with fewer differences among genotypes) # Define different intercepts for the two traits df2 <- ge_simula(ngen = 10,           nenv = 3,           nrep = 4,           nvars = 2,           gen_eff = c(1, 50),           intercept = c(80, 1500),           seed = 1) #> Warning: 'env_eff = 15' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'rep_eff = 5' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'ge_eff = 10' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'res_eff = 5' recycled for all the 2 traits. #> Warning: 'seed = 1' recycled for all the 2 traits. ge_plot(df2, ENV, GEN, V2)  # }

title: Descriptive statistics — desc_stat
text: .data data analyzed. can data frame (possible grouped data passed dplyr::group_by() numeric vector. desc_wider() .data object class desc_stat. ... single variable name comma-separated list unquoted variables names. variable informed, numeric variables .data used. Select helpers allowed. One variable (factor) compute function . shortcut dplyr::group_by(). compute statistics one grouping variable use function. stats descriptive statistics show. used filter output computation. Defaults "main" (cv, max, mean median, min, sd.amo, se, ci ). allowed values "" show statistics, "robust" show robust statistics, "quantile" show quantile statistics, chose one () following: "av.dev": average deviation. "ci.t": t-interval (95% confidence interval) mean. "ci.z": z-interval (95% confidence interval) mean. "cv": coefficient variation. "iqr": interquartile range. "gmean": geometric mean. "hmean": harmonic mean. "Kurt": kurtosis. "mad": median absolute deviation. "max": maximum value. "mean": arithmetic mean. "median": median. "min": minimum value. "n": length data. "n.valid": valid (NA) number elements "n.missing": number missing values "n.unique": length unique elements. "ps": pseudo-sigma (iqr / 1.35). "q2.5", "q25", "q75", "q97.5": percentile 2.5\ quartile, third quartile, percentile 97.5\ range: range data). "sd.amo", "sd.pop": sample population standard deviation. "se": standard error mean. "skew": skewness. "sum". sum values. "sum.dev": sum absolute deviations. "ave.sq.dev": average squared deviations. "sum.sq.dev": sum squared deviations. "n.valid": size sample valid number (NA). "var.amo", "var.pop": sample population variance. Use names select statistics. example, stats = c("median, mean, cv, n"). Note statistic names case-sensitive. comma space can used separator. hist Logical argument defaults FALSE. hist = TRUE histogram created selected variable. level confidence level compute confidence interval mean. Defaults 0.95. digits number significant digits. na.rm Logical. missing values removed? Defaults FALSE. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently. plot_theme graphical theme plot. Default plot_theme = theme_metan(). details, see ggplot2::theme(). statistic fill table.

title: Dissimilarity between environments — env_dissimilarity
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). Select helpers also allowed.

title: Dissimilarity between environments — env_dissimilarity
text: list following matrices: SPART_CC: percentage single (non cross-) part interaction genotypes pairs environments according method proposed Cruz Castoldi (1991). CPART_CC: percentage complex (cross-) part interaction genotypes pairs environments according method proposed Cruz Castoldi (1991). SPART_RO: percentage single (non cross-) part interaction genotypes pairs environments according method proposed Robertson (1959). CPART_RO: percentage complex (cross-) part interaction genotypes pairs environments according method proposed Robertson (1959). MSGE: Interaction mean square genotypes pairs environments. SSGE: Interaction sum square genotypes pairs environments. correlation: Correlation coefficients genotypes's average pair environment.

title: Dissimilarity between environments — env_dissimilarity
text: Roberteson (1959) proposed partition mean square genotype-environment interaction  (MS_GE) single (S) complex (C) parts, \(S = \frac{1}{2}(\sqrt{Q1}-\sqrt{Q2})^2)\) \(C =   (1-r)\sqrt{Q1-Q2}\), r correlation genotype's average two environments; Q1 Q2 genotype mean square environments 1 2, respectively. Cruz Castoldi (1991) proposed new decomposition MS_GE, complex part given \(C = \sqrt{(1-r)^3\times Q1\times Q2}\).

title: Dissimilarity between environments — env_dissimilarity
text: Cruz, C.D., Castoldi, F. (1991). Decomposicao da interacao genotipos x ambientes em partes simples e complexa. Ceres, 38:422-430. Robertson, . (1959). Experimental design measurement heritabilities genetic correlations. biometrical genetics. New York: Pergamon Press.

title: Multi-trait selection index — fai_blup
code: fai_blup(   .data,   use_data = "blup",   DI = NULL,   UI = NULL,   SI = 15,   mineval = 1,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Multi-trait selection index — fai_blup
text: .data object class waasb two-way table genotypes rows traits columns. last case row names must contain genotypes names. use_data Define data use .data object class gamem. Defaults "blup" (BLUPs genotypes). Use "pheno" use phenotypic means instead BLUPs computing index. DI, UI vector length .data construct desirable (DI) undesirable (UI) ideotypes. element vector, allowed values 'max', 'min', 'mean', numeric value. Use comma-separated vector text. example, DI = c("max, max, min, min"). default, DI set "max" traits UI set "min" traits. SI integer (0-100). selection intensity percentage total number genotypes. Defaults 15. mineval minimum value eigenvector retained factor analysis. verbose Logical value. TRUE results shown console.

title: Multi-trait selection index — fai_blup
text: object class fai_blup following items: data data (BLUPS) used compute index. eigen eigenvalues explained variance axis. FA results factor analysis. canonical_loadings canonical loadings factor retained. FAI list FAI-BLUP index ideotype design. sel_dif_trait list selection differential ideotype design. sel_gen selected genotypes. ideotype_construction list construction ideotypes. total_gain list total gain variables increased decreased.

title: Multi-trait selection index — fai_blup
text: Rocha, J.R..S.C.R, J.C. Machado, P.C.S. Carneiro. 2018. Multitrait index based factor analysis ideotype-design: proposal application elephant grass breeding bioenergy. GCB Bioenergy 10:52-60. doi:10.1111/gcbb.12443

what: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
text: One-way analysis variance genotypes conducted randomized complete block alpha-lattice designs.

title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
code: gafem(   .data,   gen,   rep,   resp,   block = NULL,   by = NULL,   prob = 0.05,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
text: .data dataset containing columns related , Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). gen name column contains levels genotypes, treated random effect. rep name column contains levels replications (assumed fixed). resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). Select helpers also allowed. block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) employed. effects, except error, assumed fixed. Use function gamem() analyze one-way trial mixed-effect models. One variable (factor) compute function . shortcut dplyr::group_by().especially useful, example, researcher want fit fixed-effect model environment. case, object class gafem_grouped returned. mgidi() can used compute mgidi index within environment. prob error probability. Defaults 0.05. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently.

title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
text: list element result one variable containing following objects: anova: one-way ANOVA table. model: model lm. augment: Information observation dataset. includes predicted values fitted column, residuals resid column, standardized residuals stdres column, diagonal 'hat' matrix hat, standard errors fitted values se.fit column. hsd: Tukey's 'Honest Significant Difference' genotype effect. details: tibble following data: Ngen, number genotypes; OVmean, grand mean; Min, minimum observed (returning genotype replication/block); Max maximum observed, MinGEN loser winner genotype, MaxGEN, winner genotype.

title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
text: gafem analyses data one-way genotype testing experiment. default, randomized complete block design used according following model:   \[Y_{ij} = m + g_i + r_j + e_{ij}\] \(Y_{ij}\) response variable ith genotype jth block; m grand mean (fixed); \(g_i\) effect ith genotype; \(r_j\) effect jth replicate; \(e_{ij}\) random error. block informed, resolvable alpha design implemented, according following model: \[Y_{ijk} = m + g_i + r_j + b_{jk} + e_{ijk}\] \(y_{ijk}\) response variable ith genotype kth block jth replicate; m intercept, \(t_i\) effect ith genotype \(r_j\) effect jth replicate, \(b_{jk}\) effect kth incomplete block jth replicate, \(e_{ijk}\) plot error effect corresponding \(y_{ijk}\). effects, except random error assumed fixed.

title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
text: Patterson, H.D., E.R. Williams. 1976. new class resolvable incomplete block designs. Biometrika 63:83-92.

title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Genotype analysis by fixed-effect models — gafem

Select helpers also allowed. block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, alpha-lattice design employed considering block random make use inter-block information, whereas complete replicate effect always taken fixed, inter-replicate information recovered (Mohring et al., 2015). title: Genotype analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem
text: object class gamem gamem_grouped, list following items element (variable): fixed: Test fixed effects. random: Variance components random effects. LRT: Likelihood Ratio Test random effects. BLUPgen: estimated BLUPS genotypes ranef: random effects model modellme mixed-effect model class lmerMod. residuals residuals mixed-effect model. model_lm fixed-effect model class lm. residuals_lm residuals fixed-effect model. Details: tibble following data: Ngen, number genotypes; OVmean, grand mean; Min, minimum observed (returning genotype replication/block); Max maximum observed, MinGEN winner genotype, MaxGEN, loser genotype. ESTIMATES: tibble values: Gen_var, genotypic variance ; rep:block_var block-within-replicate variance (alpha-lattice design used informing block block); Res_var, residual variance; Gen (%), rep:block (%), Res (%) respective contribution variance components phenotypic variance; H2, broad-sense heritability; h2mg, heritability entry-mean basis; Accuracy, accuracy selection (square root h2mg); CVg, genotypic coefficient variation; CVr, residual coefficient variation; CV ratio, ratio genotypic residual coefficient variation. formula formula used fit mixed-model.

title: Genotype analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem
text: gamem analyses data one-way genotype testing experiment. default, randomized complete block design used according following model:   \[Y_{ij} = m + g_i + r_j + e_{ij}\] \(Y_{ij}\) response variable ith genotype jth block; m grand mean (fixed); \(g_i\) effect ith genotype (assumed random); \(r_j\) effect jth replicate (assumed fixed); \(e_{ij}\) random error. block informed, resolvable alpha design implemented, according following model: \[Y_{ijk} = m + g_i + r_j + b_{jk} + e_{ijk}\] \(y_{ijk}\) response variable ith genotype kth block jth replicate; m intercept, \(t_i\) effect ith genotype \(r_j\) effect jth replicate, \(b_{jk}\) effect kth incomplete block jth replicate, \(e_{ijk}\) plot error effect corresponding \(y_{ijk}\).

what: Genotype-environment analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem_met
title: Genotype-environment analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem_met
text: Genotype analysis multi-environment trials using mixed-effect random-effect models. nature effects model chosen argument random. default, experimental design considered environment randomized complete block design. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) implemented. following six models can fitted depending values random block arguments. Model 1: block = NULL random = "gen" (default option). model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment assuming genotype genotype-environment interaction random effects. Environments blocks nested within environments assumed fixed factors. Model 2: block = NULL random = "env". model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment treating environment, genotype-environment interaction, blocks nested within environments random factors. Genotypes assumed fixed factors. Model 3: block = NULL random = "". model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment assuming random-effect model, .e., effects (genotypes, environments, genotype-vs-environment interaction blocks nested within environments) assumed random factors. Model 4: block NULL random =   "gen". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming genotype, genotype-environment interaction, incomplete blocks nested within complete replicates random make use inter-block information (Mohring et al., 2015). Complete replicates nested within environments environments assumed fixed factors. Model 5: block NULL random =   "env". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming genotype fixed. sources variation (environment, genotype-environment interaction, complete replicates nested within environments, incomplete blocks nested within replicates) assumed random factors. Model 6: block NULL random =   "". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming effects, except intercept, random factors.

title: Genotype-environment analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem_met
code: gamem_met(   .data,   env,   gen,   rep,   resp,   block = NULL,   by = NULL,   random = "gen",   prob = 0.05,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Genotype-environment analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem_met
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, alpha-lattice design employed considering block random make use inter-block information, whereas complete replicate effect always taken fixed, inter-replicate information recovered (Mohring et al., 2015). One variable (factor) compute function . shortcut dplyr::group_by().especially useful, example, researcher want analyze environments within mega-environments. case, object class waasb_grouped returned. random effects model assumed random. Defaults random = "gen". See Details see random effects assumed depending experimental design trials. prob probability estimating confidence interval BLUP's prediction. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently.

title: Genotype-environment analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem_met
text: object class waasb following items variable: fixed Test fixed effects. random Variance components random effects. LRT Likelihood Ratio Test random effects. BLUPgen random effects estimated BLUPS genotypes (random = "gen" random = "") BLUPenv random effects estimated BLUPS environments, (random = "env" random = ""). BLUPint random effects estimated BLUPS genotypes environments. MeansGxE phenotypic means genotypes environments. modellme mixed-effect model class lmerMod. residuals residuals mixed-effect model. model_lm fixed-effect model class lm. residuals_lm residuals fixed-effect model. Details list summarizing results. following information shown: Nenv, number environments analysis; Ngen number genotypes analysis; Mean grand mean; SE standard error mean; SD standard deviation. CV coefficient variation phenotypic means, estimating WAASB, Min minimum value observed (returning genotype environment), Max maximum value observed (returning genotype environment); MinENV environment lower mean, MaxENV environment larger mean observed, MinGEN genotype lower mean, MaxGEN genotype larger. ESTIMATES tibble genetic parameters (random = "gen" random = "") following columns: Phenotypic variance phenotypic variance; Heritability broad-sense heritability; GEr2 coefficient determination interaction effects; h2mg heritability mean basis; Accuracy selective accuracy; rge genotype-environment correlation; CVg genotypic coefficient variation; CVr residual coefficient variation; CV ratio ratio genotypic residual coefficient variation. formula formula used fit mixed-model.

text: Olivoto, T., .D.C. L\'ucio, J..G. da silva, V.S. Marchioro, V.Q. de Souza, E. Jost. 2019. Mean performance stability multi-environment trials : Combining features AMMI BLUP techniques. Agron. J. 111:2949-2960. doi:10.2134/agronj2019.03.0220 Mohring, J., E. Williams, H.-P. Piepho. 2015. Inter-block information: recover recover ? TAG. Theor. Appl. Genet. 128:1541-54. doi:10.1007/s00122-015-2530-0 Patterson, H.D., E.R. Williams. 1976. new class resolvable incomplete block designs. Biometrika 63:83-92.

text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Genotype-environment analysis by mixed-effect models — gamem_met
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) #===============================================================# # Example 1: Analyzing all numeric variables assuming genotypes # # as random effects                                             # #===============================================================# model <- gamem_met(data_ge,                   env = ENV,                   gen = GEN,                   rep = REP,                   resp = everything()) #> Evaluating trait GY |======================                      | 50% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait HM |============================================| 100% 00:00:01   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       GY       HM #>  COMPLETE       NA       NA #>       GEN 1.11e-05 5.07e-03 #>   GEN:ENV 2.15e-11 2.27e-15 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction # Distribution of random effects (first variable) plot(model, type = "re")   # Genetic parameters get_model_data(model, "genpar") #> Class of the model: waasb #> Variable extracted: genpar #> # A tibble: 9 × 3 #>   Parameters              GY     HM #>   <chr>                <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 Phenotypic variance  0.181 5.52   #> 2 Heritability         0.154 0.0887 #> 3 GEIr2                0.313 0.397  #> 4 h2mg                 0.815 0.686  #> 5 Accuracy             0.903 0.828  #> 6 rge                  0.370 0.435  #> 7 CVg                  6.26  1.46   #> 8 CVr                 11.6   3.50   #> 9 CV ratio             0.538 0.415     #===============================================================# # Example 2: Unbalanced trials                                  # # assuming all factors as random effects                        # #===============================================================# un_data <- data_ge %>%              remove_rows(1:3) %>%              droplevels()  model2 <- gamem_met(un_data,                    env = ENV,                    gen = GEN,                    rep = REP,                    random = "all",                    resp = GY) #> Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:00   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, REP(ENV), ENV, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: - #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       GY #>  COMPLETE       NA #>       GEN 1.31e-05 #>  REP(ENV) 9.23e-08 #>       ENV 9.33e-17 #>   GEN:ENV 2.11e-11 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction get_model_data(model2) #> Class of the model: waasb #> Variable extracted: genpar #> # A tibble: 9 × 2 #>   Parameters               GY #>   <chr>                 <dbl> #> 1 Phenotypic variance  0.907  #> 2 Heritability         0.0308 #> 3 GEIr2                0.314  #> 4 h2mg                 0.813  #> 5 Accuracy             0.902  #> 6 rge                  0.371  #> 7 CVg                  6.24   #> 8 CVr                 11.6    #> 9 CV ratio             0.536  # }
