title: Get data from a model easily — get_model_data
text: get_model_data() Easily get data objects generated metan package WAASB WAASBY indexes  (Olivoto et al., 2019a, 2019b) BLUPs, variance components, details AMMI models AMMI-based stability statistics. gmd() shortcut get_model_data. sel_gen() Extracts selected genotypes given index. Bellow listed options allowed argument depending class object Objects class ammi_indexes: "ASV" AMMI stability value. "EV" Averages squared eigenvector values. "SIPC" Sums absolute value IPCA scores. "WAAS" Weighted average absolute scores (default). "ZA" Absolute value relative contribution IPCAs interaction. Objects class anova_ind: "MEAN"mean value variable "DFG", "DFB", "DFCR", "DFIB_R", "DFE". degree freedom genotypes, blocks (randomized complete block design), complete replicates, incomplete blocks within replicates (alpha-lattice design), error, respectively. "MSG", "FCG", "PFG" mean square, F-calculated P-values genotype effect, respectively. "MSB", "FCB", "PFB" mean square, F-calculated P-values block effect randomized complete block design. "MSCR", "FCR", "PFCR" mean square, F-calculated P-values complete replicates alpha lattice design. "MSIB_R", "FCIB_R", "PFIB_R" mean square, F-calculated P-values incomplete blocks within complete replicates, respectively (alpha lattice design ). "MSE" mean square error. "CV" coefficient variation. "h2" broad-sence heritability "" accucary selection (square root h2). "FMAX" Hartley's test (ratio largest MSE smallest MSE). Objects class anova_joint gafem: "Y" observed values. "h2" broad-sense heritability. "Sum Sq" Sum squares. "Mean Sq" Mean Squares. "F value" F-values. "Pr(>F)" P-values. ".fitted" Fitted values (default). ".resid" Residuals. ".stdresid" Standardized residuals. ".se.fit" Standard errors fitted values. "details" Details. Objects class Annicchiarico Schmildt: "Sem_rp" standard error relative mean performance (Schmildt). "Mean_rp" relative performance mean. "rank" rank genotypic confidence index. "Wi" genotypic confidence index. Objects class can_corr: "coefs" canonical coefficients (default). "loads" canonical loadings. "crossloads" canonical cross-loadings. "canonical" canonical correlations hypothesis testing. Objects class ecovalence: "Ecoval" Ecovalence value (default). "Ecov_perc" Ecovalence percentage value. "rank" Rank ecovalence. Objects class fai_blup: See Value section fai_blup() see valid options argument. Objects class ge_acv: "ACV" adjusted coefficient variation (default). "ACV_R" rank adjusted coefficient variation. Objects class ge_polar: "POLAR" Power Law Residuals (default). "POLAR_R" rank Power Law Residuals. Objects class ge_reg: GEN: genotypes. b0 b1 (default): intercept slope regression, respectively. t(b1=1): calculated t-value pval_t: p-value t test. s2di deviations regression (stability parameter). F(s2di=0): F-test deviations. pval_f: p-value F test; RMSE root-mean-square error. R2 determination coefficient regression. Objects class ge_effects: objects class ge_effects argument required. Objects class ge_means: "ge_means" Genotype-environment interaction means (default). "env_means" Environment means. "gen_means" Genotype means. Objects class gge: "scores" scores genotypes environments analyzed traits (default). "exp_var" eigenvalues explained variance. "projection" projection genotype AEC coordinates stability GGE plot Objects class gytb: "gyt" Genotype yield*trait table (Default). "stand_gyt" standardized (zero mean unit variance) Genotype yield*trait table. "si" superiority index (sum standardized value across yield*trait combinations). Objects class mgidi: See Value section mgidi() see valid options argument. Objects class mtsi: See Value section mtsi() see valid options argument. **Objects class path_coeff "coef" Path coefficients "eigenval" Eigenvalues eigenvectors. "vif " Variance Inflation Factor **Objects class path_coeff_seq "resp_fc" Coefficients primary predictors response "resp_sc" Coefficients secondary predictors response "resp_sc2" contribution total effects primary traits "fc_sc_coef" Coefficients secondary predictors primary predictors. Objects class Shukla: "rMean" Rank mean. "ShuklaVar" Shukla's stablity variance (default). "rShukaVar" Rank Shukla's stablity variance. "ssiShukaVar" Simultaneous selection index. Objects class sh: See Value section Smith_Hazel() see valid options argument. Objects class Fox: "TOP" proportion locations genotype occurred top third (default). Objects class gai: "GAI" geometric adaptability index (default). "GAI_R" rank GAI values. Objects class superiority: "Pi_a" superiority measure environments (default). "R_a" rank Pi_a. "Pi_f" superiority measure favorable environments. "R_f" rank Pi_f. "Pi_u" superiority measure unfavorable environments. "R_u" rank Pi_u. Objects class Huehn: "S1" Mean absolute rank differences genotype n environments (default). "S2" variance among ranks k environments. "S3" Sum absolute deviations. "S6" Relative sum squares rank genotype. "S1_R", "S2_R", "S3_R",  "S6_R", ranks S1, S2, S3, S6, respectively. Objects class Thennarasu: "N1" First statistic (default). "N2" Second statistic. "N3" Third statistic. "N4" Fourth statistic. "N1_R", "N2_R", "N3_R", "N4_R", ranks statistics. Objects class performs_ammi: "PC1", "PC2", ..., "PCn" values nth interaction principal component axis. "ipca_ss" Sum square IPCA. "ipca_ms" Mean square IPCA. "ipca_fval" F value IPCA. "ipca_pval" P-value IPCA. "ipca_expl"  Explained sum square IPCA (default). "ipca_accum" Accumulated explained sum square. Objects class waas, waas_means, waasb: "PC1", "PC2", ..., "PCn" values nth interaction principal component axis. "WAASB"  weighted average absolute scores (default objects class waas). "PctResp" rescaled values response variable. "PctWAASB" rescaled values WAASB. "wResp" weight response variable. "wWAASB" weight stability. "OrResp" ranking regarding response variable. "OrWAASB" ranking regarding WAASB. "OrPC1" ranking regarding first principal component axix. "WAASBY" superiority index WAASBY. "OrWAASBY" ranking regarding superiority index. Objects class gamem waasb: "blupge" Best Linear Unbiased Prediction genotype-environment interaction (mixed-effect model, class waasb). "blupg" Best Linear Unbiased Prediction genotype effect. "bluege" Best Linear Unbiased Estimation genotype-environment interaction (fixed-effect model, class waasb). "blueg" Best Linear Unbiased Estimation genotype effect (fixed model). "data" data used. "details" details trial. "genpar" Genetic parameters (default). "gcov" genotypic variance-covariance matrix. "pcov" phenotypic variance-covariance matrix. "gcor" genotypic correlation matrix. "pcor" phenotypic correlation matrix. "h2" broad-sense heritability. "lrt" likelihood-ratio test random effects. "vcomp" variance components random effects. "ranef" Random effects. Objects class blup_ind "HMGV","HMGV_R" harmonic mean genotypic values ranks. "RPGV", RPGV_Y" relative performance genotypic values ranks. "HMRPGV", "HMRPGV_R" harmonic mean relative performance genotypic values ranks. "WAASB", "WAASB_R" weighted average absolute scores singular ranks. value decomposition BLUPs GxE interaction ranks.

code: # \donttest{ library(metan)   #################### WAASB index ##################### # Fitting the WAAS index AMMI <- waasb(data_ge2,               env = ENV,               gen = GEN,               rep = REP,               resp = c(PH, ED, TKW, NKR)) #> Evaluating trait PH |===========                                 | 25% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait ED |======================                      | 50% 00:00:01  Evaluating trait TKW |================================           | 75% 00:00:01  Evaluating trait NKR |===========================================| 100% 00:00:02   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       PH       ED      TKW     NKR #>  COMPLETE       NA       NA       NA      NA #>       GEN 9.39e-01 2.99e-01 1.00e+00 0.78738 #>   GEN:ENV 1.09e-13 1.69e-08 4.21e-10 0.00404 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction  # Getting the weighted average of absolute scores gmd(AMMI, what = "WAASB") #> Class of the model: waasb #> Variable extracted: WAASB #> # A tibble: 13 × 5 #>    GEN      PH    ED   TKW   NKR #>    <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 H1    0.319 0.695 3.49  0.545 #>  2 H10   0.287 0.879 2.47  0.291 #>  3 H11   0.210 0.579 0.801 0.533 #>  4 H12   0.298 0.344 1.59  0.433 #>  5 H13   0.258 0.758 0.423 0.547 #>  6 H2    0.312 0.990 3.86  0.271 #>  7 H3    0.340 0.364 3.08  0.172 #>  8 H4    0.268 0.321 2.77  0.615 #>  9 H5    0.171 0.465 0.476 0.561 #> 10 H6    0.232 0.528 0.591 1.07  #> 11 H7    0.209 0.301 2.55  0.369 #> 12 H8    0.334 0.640 4.50  0.612 #> 13 H9    0.208 0.913 5.13  0.632   #################### BLUP model ##################### # Fitting a mixed-effect model # Genotype and interaction as random blup <- gamem_met(data_ge2,                   env = ENV,                   gen = GEN,                   rep = REP,                   resp = c(PH, ED)) #> Evaluating trait PH |======================                      | 50% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait ED |============================================| 100% 00:00:00   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       PH       ED #>  COMPLETE       NA       NA #>       GEN 9.39e-01 2.99e-01 #>   GEN:ENV 1.09e-13 1.69e-08 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction  # Getting p-values for likelihood-ratio test gmd(blup, what = "lrt") #> Class of the model: waasb #> Variable extracted: lrt #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   VAR   model    npar  logLik   AIC      LRT    Df `Pr(>Chisq)` #>   <chr> <chr>   <int>   <dbl> <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1 PH    GEN        14    7.89  12.2  0.00581     1     9.39e- 1 #> 2 PH    GEN:ENV    14  -19.7   67.4 55.2         1     1.09e-13 #> 3 ED    GEN        14 -327.   681.   1.08        1     2.99e- 1 #> 4 ED    GEN:ENV    14 -342.   712.  31.8         1     1.69e- 8  # Getting the variance components gmd(blup, what = "vcomp") #> Class of the model: waasb #> Variable extracted: vcomp #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   Group          PH    ED #>   <chr>       <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 GEN      0.000455 0.557 #> 2 GEN:ENV  0.0425   2.82  #> 3 Residual 0.0224   2.59   # }

title: Cluster genotypes or environments — ge_cluster
code: ge_cluster(   .data,   env = NULL,   gen = NULL,   resp = NULL,   table = FALSE,   distmethod = "euclidean",   clustmethod = "ward.D",   scale = TRUE,   cluster = "env",   nclust = NULL )

title: Cluster genotypes or environments — ge_cluster
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes response variable. also possible use two-way table genotypes lines environments columns input. case must use table = TRUE. env name column contains levels environments. Defaults NULL, case input data two-way table. gen name column contains levels genotypes. Defaults NULL, case input data two-way table. resp response variable(s). Defaults NULL, case input data two-way table. table Logical values indicating input data two-way table genotypes rows environments columns. Defaults FALSE. distmethod distance measure used. must one 'euclidean', 'maximum', 'manhattan', 'canberra', 'binary', 'minkowski'. clustmethod agglomeration method used. one 'ward.D' (Default), 'ward.D2', 'single', 'complete', 'average' (= UPGMA), 'mcquitty' (= WPGMA), 'median' (= WPGMC) 'centroid' (= UPGMC). scale data scaled befor computing distances? Set TRUE. Let \(Y_{ij}\) yield Hybrid Location j, \(\bar Y_{.j}\) mean yield, \(S_j\) standard deviation Location j. standardized yield (Zij) computed (Ouyang et al. 1995): \(Z_{ij} = (Y_{ij} - Y_{.j}) / S_j\). cluster clustered? Defaults cluster = "env" (cluster environments). cluster genotypes use cluster = "gen". nclust number clust formed. Set NULL.

title: Cluster genotypes or environments — ge_cluster
text: data data used compute distances. cutpoint cutpoint dendrogram according Mojena (1977). distance matrix distances. de distances object class dist. hc hierarchical clustering. cophenetic cophenetic correlation coefficient distance matrix cophenetic matrix Sqt total sum squares. tab table clusters similarity. clusters sum square mean clusters genotype (cluster = "env" environment (cluster = "gen"). labclust labels genotypes/environments within cluster.

title: Cluster genotypes or environments — ge_cluster

Cluster analysis genotype x environment interaction unbalanced data. Crop Sci. 35:1300-1305. doi:10.2135/cropsci1995.0011183X003500050008x

what:
Power Law Residuals as yield stability index
 — ge_polar
title:
Power Law Residuals as yield stability index
 — ge_polar
text: Performs stability analysis based Power Law Residuals (POLAR) statistics (Doring et al., 2015). POLAR residuals linear regression \(log(\sigma^2\)) \(log(\mu\)) can used measure crop stability lower stability (relative samples mean yield) indicated positive POLAR values, higher stability (relative samples mean yield) indicated negative POLAR values.

title:
Power Law Residuals as yield stability index
 — ge_polar
code: ge_polar(.data, env, gen, resp, base = 10, verbose = TRUE)

title:
Power Law Residuals as yield stability index
 — ge_polar
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure use, example, resp = c(var1, var2, var3). base base respect logarithms computed. Defaults 10. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently.

Power Law Residuals as yield stability index
 — ge_polar

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics — ge_stats
code: ge_stats(.data, env, gen, rep, resp, verbose = TRUE, prob = 0.05)

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics — ge_stats
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure use, example, resp = c(var1, var2, var3). verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently. prob probability error assumed.

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics — ge_stats
text: object class ge_stats list one data frame variable containing computed indexes.

title: Parametric and non-parametric stability statistics — ge_stats
text: function computes statistics ranks following stability indexes. "Y" (Response variable), "CV" (coefficient variation) "ACV" (adjusted coefficient variation calling ge_acv() internally) POLAR (Power Law Residuals, calling ge_polar() internally) "Var" (Genotype's variance) "Shukla" (Shukla's variance, calling Shukla() internally) "Wi_g", "Wi_f", "Wi_u" (Annichiarrico's genotypic confidence index , favorable unfavorable environments, respectively, calling Annicchiarico() internally ) "Ecoval" (Wricke's ecovalence, ecovalence() internally) "Sij" (Deviations joint-regression analysis) "R2" (R-squared joint-regression analysis, calling ge_reg() internally) "ASTAB" (AMMI Based Stability Parameter), "ASI" (AMMI Stability Index), "ASV" (AMMI-stability value), "AVAMGE" (Sum Across Environments Absolute Value GEI Modelled AMMI ), "Da" (Annicchiarico's D Parameter values), "Dz" (Zhang's D Parameter), "EV" (Sums Averages Squared Eigenvector Values), "FA" (Stability Measure Based Fitted AMMI Model), "MASV" (Modified AMMI Stability Value), "SIPC" (Sums Absolute Value IPC Scores), "Za" (Absolute Value Relative Contribution IPCs Interaction), "WAAS" (Weighted average absolute scores), calling ammi_indexes() internally "HMGV" (Harmonic mean genotypic value), "RPGV" (Relative performance genotypic values), "HMRPGV" (Harmonic mean relative performance genotypic values), calling blup_indexes() internally "Pi_a", "Pi_f", "Pi_u" (Superiority indexes , favorable unfavorable environments, respectively, calling superiority() internally) "Gai" (Geometric adaptability index, calling gai() internally) "S1" (mean absolute rank differences genotype n environments), "S2" (variance among ranks k environments), "S3" (sum absolute deviations), "S6" (relative sum squares rank genotype), calling Huehn() internally "N1", "N2", "N3", "N4" (Thennarasu"s statistics, calling Thennarasu() internally ).

Genotype-environment winners — ge_winners
text: Computes ranking genotypes within environments return winners.

title: Genotype-environment winners — ge_winners
code: ge_winners(.data, env, gen, resp, type = "winners", better = NULL)

title: Genotype-environment winners — ge_winners
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). Select helpers also allowed. type type results. Defaults "winners" (default), .e., two-way table winner genotype environment. type = "ranks" return genotype ranking within environment. better vector length number variables rank genotypes according response variable. element vector must one 'h' 'l'. 'h' used (default), genotypes ranked maximum minimum. 'l' used ranked minimum maximum. Use comma-separated vector names. example, better = c("h, h, h, h, l"), ranking fifth variable minimum maximum.

title: Genotype-environment winners — ge_winners
text: tibble two-way table winner genotype environment (default) genotype ranking environment (type = "ranks").

title: Genotype plus genotype-by-environment model — gge

code: gge(   .data,   env,   gen,   resp,   centering = "environment",   scaling = "none",   svp = "environment",   by = NULL,   ... )

title: Genotype plus genotype-by-environment model — gge
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). Select helpers also supported. centering centering method. Must one 'none | 0', centering; 'global | 1', global centered (E+G+GE); 'environment | 2' (default), environment-centered (G+GE); 'double | 3', double centered (GE). biplot produced models produced without centering. scaling scaling method. Must one 'none | 0' (default), scaling; 'sd | 1', value divided standard deviation corresponding environment (column). put environments roughly rang values. svp method singular value partitioning. Must one 'genotype | 1', (singular value entirely partitioned genotype eigenvectors, also called row metric preserving); 'environment | 2', default, (singular value entirely partitioned environment eigenvectors, also called column metric preserving); 'symmetrical | 3' (singular value symmetrically partitioned genotype environment eigenvectors SVP often used AMMI analysis biplot analysis, ideal visualizing either relationship among genotypes among environments). One variable (factor) compute function . shortcut dplyr::group_by().especially useful, example, researcher want produce GGE biplots level categorical variable. case, object class gge_grouped returned. ... Arguments passed function impute_missing_val() imputation missing values case unbalanced data.

title: Genotype by yield*trait biplot — gytb
text: Produces Genotype Yield*Trait biplot (GTY) proposed Yan Fregeau-Reid (2018).

title: Genotype by yield*trait biplot — gytb
code: gytb(   .data,   gen,   yield,   traits = everything(),   ideotype = NULL,   weight = NULL,   prefix = "Y",   centering = "trait",   scaling = "sd",   svp = "trait" )

title: Genotype by yield*trait biplot — gytb
text: .data dataset containing columns related Genotypes, Yield, Traits. gen name column contains levels genotypes. yield column containing yield values. traits column(s) traits values. Defaults NULL. case, numeric traits .data, except yield selected. select specific traits .data, use list unquoted comma-separated variable names (e.g. traits = c(var1, var2, var3)), specific range variables, (e.g. traits = c(var1:var3)), even select helper like starts_with("N"). ideotype vector "h" "l" length traits define trait desired increase decrease. default (ideotype = NULL) numeric traits traits assumed high values desirable. Following order traits selected traits, use "h" indicate traits higher values desired "l" indicate variables lower values desired. , yield  multiplied traits "h" divided traits "l" generate Genotype yield*trait table. example, ideotype = c("h, h, l") assume ideotype higher values first two traits lower values last trait. weight weight assumed trait. Similar ideotype argument, provide numeric vector length traits. Suggested values 0 2. prefix prefix used biplot yield*trait combinations. Defaults "Y". centering centering method. Must one 'none | 0', centering; 'global | 1', global centered (T+G+GYT); 'trait | 2' (default), trait-centered (G+GYT); 'double | 3', double centered (GYT). biplot produced models produced without centering. scaling scaling method. Must one 'none | 0', scaling; 'sd | 1' (default), mean trait yield-trait combination becomes 0 variance becomes unit. svp method singular value partitioning. Must one 'genotype | 1', (singular value entirely partitioned genotype eigenvectors, also called row metric preserving); 'trait | 2', default, (singular value entirely partitioned trait eigenvectors, also called column metric preserving); 'symmetrical | 3' (singular value symmetrically partitioned genotype trait eigenvectors SVP often used AMMI analysis biplot analysis, ideal visualizing either relationship among genotypes among traits).

title: Huehn's stability statistics — Huehn
text: Performs stability analysis based Huehn (1979) statistics. four nonparametric measures phenotypic stability : S1 (mean absolute rank differences genotype n environments), S2 (variance among ranks k environments), S3 (sum absolute deviations), S6 (relative sum squares rank genotype).

title: Huehn's stability statistics — Huehn

title: Missing value imputation — impute_missing_val

title: Missing value imputation — impute_missing_val
text: .data matrix impute missing entries. Frequently two-way table genotype means environment. naxis rank Singular Value Approximation. Defaults 1. algorithm algorithm impute missing values. Defaults "EM-SVD". possible values "EM-AMMI" "colmeans". See Details section. tol convergence tolerance algorithm. max_iter maximum number steps take. max_iter achieved without convergence, algorithm stop warning. simplified Valid argument algorithm = "EM-AMMI". FALSE (default), current effects rows columns change iteration iteration. TRUE, general mean effects rows columns computed first iteration , next iterations uses values. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently.

title: Missing value imputation — impute_missing_val
text: object class imv following values: .data imputed matrix pc_ss sum squares representing variation explained principal components iter final number iterations. Final_RMSE maximum change estimated values missing cells last step iteration. final_axis final number principal component axis. convergence Logical value indicating whether modern converged.

title: Missing value imputation — impute_missing_val
text: EM-AMMI algorithm EM-AMMI algorithm completes data set missing values according main interaction effects. algorithm works follows (Gauch Zobel, 1990): initial values calculated grand mean increased main effects rows main effects columns. way, matrix observations pre-filled . parameters AMMI model estimated. adjusted means calculated based AMMI model naxis principal components. missing cells filled adjusted means. root mean square error predicted values (RMSE_p) calculated two lasts iteration steps. RMSE_p > tol, steps 2 5 repeated. Declare convergence RMSE_p < tol. max_iter achieved without convergence, algorithm stop warning. EM-SVD algorithm EM-SVD algorithm impute missing entries using low-rank Singular Value Decomposition approximation estimated Expectation-Maximization algorithm. algorithm works follows (Troyanskaya et al., 2001). Initialize NA values column means. Compute first naxis terms SVD completed matrix Replace previously missing values approximations SVD root mean square error predicted values (RMSE_p) calculated two lasts iteration steps. RMSE_p > tol, steps 2 3 repeated. Declare convergence RMSE_p < tol. max_iter achieved without convergence, algorithm stop warning. colmeans algorithm colmeans algorithm simply impute missing entires using column mean respective entire. Thus, iteractive process.

title: Missing value imputation — impute_missing_val
text: Gauch, H. G., & Zobel, R. W. (1990). Imputing missing yield trial data. Theoretical Applied Genetics, 79(6), 753-761. doi:10.1007/BF00224240 Troyanskaya, O., Cantor, M., Sherlock, G., Brown, P., Hastie, T., Tibshirani, R., . Altman, R. B. (2001). Missing value estimation methods DNA microarrays. Bioinformatics, 17(6), 520-525.

title: Multi-Environment Trial Analysis — metan-package
text: metan provides functions performing used analyses evaluation multi-environment trials, including, limited : ANOVA-based stability statistics; AMMI-based stability indexes; BLUP-based stability indexes; Cross-validation procedures AMMI-family BLUP models; GGE biplot analysis; Estimation using AMMI considering different numbers interaction principal component axes; Graphics tools generating biplots; Nonparametric stability statistics; Variance components genetic parameters mixed-effect models; Within-environment analysis variance; metan also provides functions biometrical analysis path analysis, canonical correlation, partial correlation, clustering analysis, well tools summarizing plotting data. complete guide may found https://tiagoolivoto.github.io/metan/

title: Multitrait Genotype-Ideotype Distance Index — mgidi
text: Computes multi-trait genotype-ideotype distance index, MGIDI, (Olivoto Nardino, 2020), used select genotypes plant breeding programs based multiple traits.MGIDI index computed follows:   \[MGIDI_i = \sqrt{\sum\limits_{j = 1}^f(F_{ij} - {F_j})^2}\] \(MGIDI_i\) multi-trait genotype-ideotype distance index ith genotype; \(F_{ij}\) score ith genotype jth factor (= 1, 2, ..., g; j = 1, 2, ..., f), g f number genotypes factors, respectively, \(F_j\) jth score ideotype. genotype lowest MGIDI closer ideotype therefore presents desired values analyzed traits.

title: Multitrait Genotype-Ideotype Distance Index — mgidi
code: mgidi(   .data,   use_data = "blup",   SI = 15,   mineval = 1,   ideotype = NULL,   weights = NULL,   use = "complete.obs",   verbose = TRUE )

title: Multitrait Genotype-Ideotype Distance Index — mgidi
text: .data object fitted function gafem(), gamem() two-way table BLUPs genotypes trait (genotypes rows traits columns). last case, row names must contain genotypes names. use_data Define data use .data object class gamem. Defaults "blup" (BLUPs genotypes). Use "pheno" use phenotypic means instead BLUPs computing index. SI integer (0-100). selection intensity percentage total number genotypes. mineval minimum value eigenvector retained factor analysis. ideotype vector length nvar nvar number variables used plan ideotype. Use 'h' indicate traits higher values desired 'l' indicate variables lower values desired. example, ideotype = c("h, h, h, h, l") consider ideotype higher values first four traits lower values last trait. .data model fitted functions gafem() gamem(), order traits declared argument resp functions. weights Optional weights assign trait selection process. must numeric vector length equal number traits .data. default (NULL) numeric vector weights equal 1 used, .e., traits weight selection process. suggested weights ranging 0 1. weights shrink ideotype vector toward 0. useful, example, prioritize grain yield rather plant-related trait selection process. use method computing covariances presence missing values. Defaults complete.obs, .e., missing values handled casewise deletion. verbose verbose = TRUE (Default) results shown console.

title: Multitrait Genotype-Ideotype Distance Index — mgidi
text: object class mgidi following items: data data used compute factor analysis. cormat correlation matrix among environments. PCA eigenvalues explained variance. FA factor analysis. KMO result Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin test. MSA measure sampling adequacy individual variable. communalities communalities. communalities_mean communalities' mean. initial_loadings initial loadings. finish_loadings final loadings varimax rotation. canonical_loadings canonical loadings. scores_gen scores genotypes retained factors. scores_ide scores ideotype retained factors. gen_ide distance scores genotype ideotype. MGIDI multi-trait genotype-ideotype distance index. contri_fac relative contribution factor MGIDI value. lower contribution factor, close ideotype variables factor . contri_fac_rank, contri_fac_rank_sel rank contribution factor genotypes selected genotypes, respectively. sel_dif selection differential variables. stat_gain descriptive statistic selection gains. minimum, mean, confidence interval, standard deviation, maximum, sum selection gain values computed. traits negative positive desired gains, statistics computed strata. sel_gen selected genotypes.

title: Multitrait Genotype-Ideotype Distance Index — mgidi
text: Olivoto, T., Nardino, M. (2020). MGIDI: toward effective multivariate selection biological experiments. Bioinformatics. doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btaa981

what: Mean performance and stability in multi-environment trials — mps
title: Mean performance and stability in multi-environment trials — mps
text: function implements weighting method mean performance stability (Olivoto et al., 2019) considering different parametric non-parametric stability indexes.

title: Mean performance and stability in multi-environment trials — mps
code: mps(   .data,   env,   gen,   rep,   resp,   block = NULL,   by = NULL,   random = "gen",   performance = "blupg",   stability = "waasb",   ideotype_mper = NULL,   ideotype_stab = NULL,   wmper = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Mean performance and stability in multi-environment trials — mps
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, alpha-lattice design employed considering block random make use inter-block information, whereas complete replicate effect always taken fixed, inter-replicate information recovered (Mohring et al., 2015). One variable (factor) compute function . shortcut dplyr::group_by().especially useful, example, researcher want analyze environments within mega-environments. case, object class mps_grouped returned. random effects model assumed random. Defaults random = "gen". See gamem_met() see random effects assumed depending experimental design trials. performance Wich considers mean performance. Either blupg (Best Linear Unbiased Prediction) blueg (Best Linear Unbiased Estimation) stability stability method. One following: "waasb" weighted average absolute scores (Olivoto et al. 2019). "ecovalence" Wricke's ecovalence (Wricke, 1965). "Shukla" Shukla's stability variance parameter (Shukla, 1972). "hmgv" harmonic mean genotypic values (Resende, 2007). "s2di" deviations Eberhart Russell regression (Eberhart Russell, 1966). "r2" determination coefficient Eberhart Russell regression (Eberhart Russell, 1966).. "rmse" root mean squared error Eberhart Russell regression (Eberhart Russell, 1966). "wi" Annicchiarico's genotypic confidence index (Annicchiarico, 1992). "polar" Power Law Residuals yield stability index (Doring et al., 2015). "acv" Adjusted Coefficient Variation (Doring Reckling, 2018) "pi" Lin e Binns' superiority index (Lin Binns, 1988). "gai" Geometric adaptability index (Mohammadi Amri, 2008). "s1", "s2", "s3", "s6" Huehn's stability statistics (Huehn, 1979). "n1", "n2", "n3", "n4" Thennarasu's stability statistics (Thennarasu, 1995). "asv", "ev", "za", "waas" AMMI-based stability indexes (see ammi_indexes()). ideotype_mper, ideotype_stab new maximum value rescaling response variable/stability index. default, variables resp rescaled de maximum value 100 minimum value 0 (.e., ideotype_mper = NULL ideotype_stab = NULL). must character vector length resp rescaling assumed different across variables, e.g., first variable smaller values better second one, higher values better, ideotype_mper = c("l, h") must used. stability index lower values better, use ideotype_stab = "l". Character value length 1 recycled warning message. wmper weight mean performance. default, variables resp equal weights mean performance stability (.e., wmper = 50). must numeric vector length resp assign different weights across variables, e.g., first variable equal weights mean performance stability assumed second one, higher weight mean performance (e.g. 65) assumed, wmper = c(50, 65) must used. Numeric value length 1 recycled warning message. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently.

title: Mean performance and stability in multi-environment trials — mps
text: object class mps following items. observed: observed value genotype-mean basis. performance: performance genotypes (BLUPs BLUEs) performance_res: rescaled values genotype's performance, considering ideotype_mper. stability: stability genotypes, chosen argument stability. stability_res: rescaled values genotype's stability, considering ideotype_stab. mps_ind: mean performance stability traits. h2: broad-sense heritability traits. perf_method: method measuring genotype's performance. wmper: weight mean performance. sense_mper: goal genotype's performance (l = lower, h = higher). stab_method: method measuring genotype's stability. wstab: weight mean stability. sense_stab: goal genotype's stability (l = lower, h = higher).

title: Multi-trait mean performance and stability index — mtmps
text: object class mtmps following items: data data used compute factor analysis. cormat correlation matrix among environments. PCA eigenvalues explained variance. FA factor analysis. KMO result Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin test. MSA measure sampling adequacy individual variable. communalities communalities. communalities_mean communalities' mean. initial_loadings initial loadings. finish_loadings final loadings varimax rotation. canonical_loadings canonical loadings. scores_gen scores genotypes retained factors. scores_ide scores ideotype retained factors. MTSI multi-trait mean performance stability index. contri_fac relative contribution factor MTSI value. lower contribution factor, close ideotype variables factor . contri_fac_rank, contri_fac_rank_sel rank contribution factor genotypes selected genotypes, respectively. sel_dif_trait, sel_dif_stab, sel_dif_mps data frame containing selection differential (gains) mean performance, stability index, mean performance stability index, respectively. following variables shown. VAR: trait's name. Factor: factor traits grouped . Xo: original population mean. Xs: mean selected genotypes. SD SDperc: selection differential selection differential percentage, respectively. h2: broad-sense heritability. SG SGperc: selection gains selection gains percentage, respectively. sense: desired selection sense. goal: selection gains match desired sense? 100 yes 0 . stat_dif_trait, stat_dif_stab, stat_dif_mps data frame descriptive statistic selection gains mean performance, stability index, mean performance stability index, respectively. following columns shown sense. sense: desired selection sense. variable: trait's name. min: minimum value selection gain. mean: mean value selection gain. ci: confidence interval selection gain. sd.amo: standard deviation selection gain. max: maximum value selection gain. sum: sum selection gain. sel_gen selected genotypes.

title: Multi-trait stability index — mtsi
text: .data object class waasb waas. index index = 'waasby' (default) stability mean performance considered. index = 'waasb' multi-trait index computed considering stability genotypes .  details can seen waasb() waas() functions. ideotype vector length nvar nvar number variables used plan ideotype. Use 'h' indicate traits higher values desired 'l' indicate variables lower values desired. example, ideotype = c("h, h, h, h, l") consider ideotype higher values first four traits lower values last trait. SI integer (0-100). selection intensity percentage total number genotypes. mineval minimum value eigenvector retained factor analysis. verbose verbose = TRUE (Default) results shown console.

what: Path coefficients with minimal multicollinearity — path_coeff
title: Path coefficients with minimal multicollinearity — path_coeff
text: path_coeff() computes path analysis using data frame input data. path_coeff_seq() computes sequential path analysis using primary secondary traits. path_coeff_mat() computes path analysis using correlation matrices input data.

title: Path coefficients with minimal multicollinearity — path_coeff
code: path_coeff(   .data,   resp,   pred = everything(),   by = NULL,   exclude = FALSE,   correction = NULL,   knumber = 50,   brutstep = FALSE,   maxvif = 10,   missingval = "pairwise.complete.obs",   plot_res = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )  path_coeff_mat(cor_mat, resp, correction = NULL, knumber = 50, verbose = TRUE)  path_coeff_seq(.data, resp, chain_1, chain_2, by = NULL, verbose = TRUE, ...)

title: Path coefficients with minimal multicollinearity — path_coeff
text: .data data. Must data frame grouped data passed dplyr::group_by() resp <tidy-select> dependent trait. pred <tidy-select> predictor traits. set everything(), .e., predictor traits numeric traits data except resp. select multiple traits, use comma-separated vector names, (e.g., pred = c(V1, V2, V2)), interval trait names, (e.g., pred = c(V1:V3)), even select helper (e.g., pred = starts_with("V")). One variable (factor) compute function . shortcut dplyr::group_by(). compute statistics one grouping variable use function. exclude Logical argument, set false. exclude = TRUE, traits pred deleted data, analysis use predictor remained, except resp. correction Set NULL. correction value (k) added diagonal elements X'X matrix aiming reducing harmful problems multicollinearity path analysis (Olivoto et al., 2017) knumber correction = NULL, plot showing values direct effects set different k values (0-1) produced. knumber number k values used range 0 1. brutstep Logical argument, set FALSE. true, algorithm select subset variables minimal multicollinearity fit set possible models. See Details section information. maxvif maximum value Variance Inflation Factor (cut point) accepted. See Details section information. missingval deal missing values. information, please see stats::cor(). plot_res TRUE, create scatter plot residual predicted value normal Q-Q plot. verbose verbose = TRUE results shown console. ... Depends function used: path_coeff() additional arguments passed stats::plot.lm(). path_coeff_seq() additional arguments passed path_coeff. cor_mat Matrix correlations containing dependent independent traits. chain_1, chain_2 <tidy-select> traits used first (primary) second (secondary) chain.

title: Path coefficients with minimal multicollinearity — path_coeff
text: Depends function used: path_coeff(), returns list following items: Corr.x correlation matrix predictor variables. Corr.y vector correlations predictor variable dependent variable. Coefficients path coefficients. Direct effects diagonal elements, indirect effects -diagonal elements (lines). Eigen Eigenvectors eigenvalues Corr.x. VIF Variance Inflation Factors. plot ggplot2-based graphic showing direct effects 21 different k values. Predictors predictor variables used model. CN Condition Number, .e., ratio highest lowest eigenvalue. Det matrix determinant Corr.x.. R2 coefficient determination model. Residual residual effect model. Response response variable. weightvar order predictor variables highest weight (highest eigenvector) lowest eigenvalue. path_coeff_seq() returns list following objects resp_fc object class path_coeff results analysis dependent trait first chain predictors. resp_sc object class path_coeff results analysis dependent trait second chain predictors. resp_sc2 path coefficients second chain predictors dependent trait first chain predictors fc_sc_list list objects path analysis using trait first chain dependent second chain predictors. fc_sc_coef coefficients first- second-chain traits. cor_mat correlation matrix analyzed traits. .data grouped data passed dplyr::group_by() results returned list-column data frames.

code: library(metan)  # Using KW as the response variable and all other ones as predictors pcoeff <- path_coeff(data_ge2, resp = KW) #> Severe multicollinearity.  #> Condition Number: 7865.84 #> Consider using a correction factor with 'correction' argument. #> Consider identifying collinear traits with `non_collinear_vars()`  # The same as above, but using the correlation matrix cor_mat <- cor(data_ge2 %>% select_numeric_cols()) pcoeff2 <- path_coeff_mat(cor_mat, resp = KW) #> Severe multicollinearity.  #> Condition Number = 7865.84 #> Please, consider using a correction factor, or use 'brutstep = TRUE'.   # Declaring the predictors # Create a residual plot with 'plot_res = TRUE' pcoeff3<- path_coeff(data_ge2,                       resp = KW,                       pred = c(PH, EH, NKE, TKW),                       plot_res = TRUE)  #> Weak multicollinearity.  #> Condition Number: 40.232 #> You will probably have path coefficients close to being unbiased.   # Selecting a set of predictors with minimal multicollinearity # Maximum variance Inflation factor of 5 pcoeff4 <- path_coeff(data_ge2,                      resp = KW,                      brutstep = TRUE,                      maxvif = 5) #> -------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> The algorithm has selected a set of 8 predictors with largest VIF = 3.346.  #> Selected predictors: NR what: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi
title: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi
text: Compute Additive Main effects Multiplicative interaction (AMMI) model. estimate response variable ith genotype jth environment (\(y_{ij}\)) using AMMI model, given follows:   \[{y_{ij}} = \mu  + {\alpha_i} + {\tau_j} + \sum\limits_{k = 1}^p {{\lambda_k}{a_{ik}}} {t_{jk}} + {\rho_{ij}} + {\varepsilon _{ij}}\] \(\lambda_k\) singular value k-th interaction principal component axis (IPCA); \(a_{ik}\) -th element k-th eigenvector; \(t_{jk}\) jth element kth eigenvector. residual \(\rho _{ij}\) remains, p IPCA used, \(p \le min(g - 1; e - 1)\). function also serves helper function procedures performed metan package waas() wsmp()

title: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi
code: performs_ammi(.data, env, gen, rep, resp, block = NULL, verbose = TRUE, ...)

title: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments gen name column contains levels genotypes rep name column contains levels replications/blocks resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure, use comma-separated list unquoted variable names, .e., resp = c(var1, var2, var3), select helper like resp = contains("_PLA"). block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) employed. effects, except error, assumed fixed. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently. ... Arguments passed function impute_missing_val() imputation missing values case unbalanced data.

title: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi
text: ANOVA: analysis variance AMMI model. PCA: principal component analysis MeansGxE: means genotypes environments model: scores genotypes environments possible axes. augment: Information observation dataset. includes predicted values fitted column, residuals resid column, standardized residuals stdres column, diagonal 'hat' matrix hat, standard errors fitted values se.fit column.

title: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi
text: Patterson, H.D., E.R. Williams. 1976. new class resolvable incomplete block designs. Biometrika 63:83-92.

title: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Additive Main effects and Multiplicative Interaction — performs_ammi

Default authomatic breaks. arguments x.breaks can used. axis.expand Multiplication factor expand axis limits enable fitting labels. Default 1.1. shape shape points plot. Default 21 (circle). Values must 21-25: 21 (circle), 22 (square), 23 (diamond), 24 (triangle), 25 (low triangle). col.shape vector length 2 contains color shapes genotypes mean, respectively. Defaults "orange". c("blue", "red"). col.alpha alpha value color. Default 0.9. Values must 0 (full transparency) 1 (full color). size.shape size shape plot. Default 3.5. size.bor.tick size tick shape. Default 0.3. size shape size.shape + size.bor.tick labels Logical arguments. TRUE points plot labels. main title plot. Defaults NULL, plot default title. text: x data set. type type heat map produce. Either lower (default) produce lower triangle heat map upper produce upper triangular heat map. diag Plot diagonal elements? Defaults FALSE. reorder Reorder correlation matrix identify hidden pattern? Defaults TRUE. signif show significant correlations. TRUE (Default) includes caption significance meaning stars. digits.cor, digits.pval significant digits show correlations p-values, respectively. col.low, col.mid, col.high color low (-1), mid(0) high (1) points color key. Defaults blue, white, red, respectively. lab.x.position, lab.y.position position x y axis label. Defaults "bottom" "right" type = "lower" "top" "left" type = "upper". legend.position legend position plot. legend.title title color key. Defaults "Pearson's Correlation". size.text.cor size text correlation values. Defaults 3. size.text.signif size text significance values (stars p-values). Defaults 3. size.text.lab size text labels. Defaults 10. ... Currently used.

what: Several types of residual plots — plot.gamem
title: Several types of residual plots — plot.gamem
text: Residual plots output model class gamem. Six types plots produced: (1) Residuals vs fitted, (2) normal Q-Q plot residuals, (3) scale-location plot (standardized residuals vs Fitted Values), (4) standardized residuals vs Factor-levels, (5) Histogram raw residuals (6) standardized residuals vs observation order. waasb object, normal Q-Q plot random effects may also obtained declaring type = 're'

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.gamem
code: # S3 method for gamem plot(   x,   var = 1,   type = "res",   position = "fill",   rotate = FALSE,   conf = 0.95,   out = "print",   n.dodge = 1,   check.overlap = FALSE,   labels = FALSE,   plot_theme = theme_metan(),   alpha = 0.2,   fill.hist = "gray",   col.hist = "black",   col.point = "black",   col.line = "red",   col.lab.out = "red",   size.line = 0.7,   size.text = 10,   width.bar = 0.75,   size.lab.out = 2.5,   size.tex.lab = 10,   size.shape = 1.5,   bins = 30,   which = c(1:4),   ncol = NULL,   nrow = NULL,   ... )

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.gamem
text: x object class gamem. var variable plot. Defaults var = 1 first variable x. type One "res" plot model residuals (default), type = 're' plot normal Q-Q plots random effects, "vcomp" create bar plot variance components. position position adjustment type = "vcomp". Defaults "fill", shows relative proportions trait stacking bars standardizing bar height. Use position = "stack" plot phenotypic variance trait. rotate Logical argument. rotate = TRUE plot rotated, .e., traits y axis value x axis. conf Level confidence interval use Q-Q plot (0.95 default). output returned. Must one 'print' (default) 'return'. n.dodge number rows used render x labels. useful displaying labels otherwise overlap. check.overlap Silently remove overlapping labels, (recursively) prioritizing first, last, middle labels. labels Logical argument. TRUE labels points outside confidence interval limits. plot_theme graphical theme plot. Default plot_theme = theme_metan(). details, see ggplot2::theme(). alpha transparency confidence band Q-Q plot. Must number 0 (opaque) 1 (full transparency). fill.hist color fill histogram. Default 'gray'. col.hist color border histogram. Default 'black'. col.point color points graphic. Default 'black'. col.line color lines graphic. Default 'red'. col.lab.color labels 'outlying' points. size.line size line graphic. Defaults 0.7. size.text size text plot. Defaults 10. width.bar width bars type = "contribution". size.lab.size labels 'outlying' points. size.tex.lab size text axis text labels. size.shape size shape plots. bins number bins use histogram. Default 30. graphics plotted. Default = c(1:4) means first four graphics plotted. ncol, nrow number columns rows plot pannel. Defaults NULL ... Additional arguments passed function patchwork::wrap_plots().

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.gamem
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.gamem
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) model <- gamem(data_g,                gen = GEN,                rep = REP,                resp = PH) #> Evaluating trait PH |============================================| 100% 00:00:00   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN #> Fixed effects: REP #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model    PH #>  Complete    NA #>  Genotype 0.051 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> Variables with nonsignificant Genotype effect #> PH  #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- plot(model) #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x' #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'  # }

what: Create GGE, GT or GYT biplots — plot.gge
title: Create GGE, GT or GYT biplots — plot.gge
text: Produces ggplot2-based GGE-GT-GYT biplot based model fitted functions gge(), gtb(), gytb().

title: Create GGE, GT or GYT biplots — plot.gge
code: # S3 method for gge plot(   x,   var = 1,   type = 1,   sel_env = NA,   sel_gen = NA,   sel_gen1 = NA,   sel_gen2 = NA,   shape.gen = 21,   shape.env = 23,   line.type.gen = "dotted",   size.shape = 2.2,   size.shape.win = 3.2,   size.stroke = 0.3,   col.stroke = "black",   col.gen = "blue",   col.env = "forestgreen",   col.line = "forestgreen",   col.alpha = 1,   col.circle = "gray",   col.alpha.circle = 0.5,   leg.lab = NULL,   size.text.gen = 3.5,   size.text.env = 3.5,   size.text.lab = 12,   size.text.win = 4.5,   size.line = 0.5,   axis_expand = 1.2,   title = TRUE,   plot_theme = theme_metan(),   ... )

title: Create GGE, GT or GYT biplots — plot.gge
text: x object classes gge gtb, gytb. var variable plot (useful gge objects. Defaults var = 1 first variable x. type type biplot produce. Basic biplot. Mean performance vs. stability (gge biplots) Average Tester Coordination view genotype-trait genotype-yield*trait biplots. -won-. Discriminativeness vs. representativeness. Examine environment (trait/yield*trait combination). Ranking environments (trait/yield*trait combination). Examine genotype. Ranking genotypes. Compare two genotypes. Relationship among environments (trait/yield*trait combination). sel_env, sel_gen name environment (trait/yield*trait combination) genotype examine type = 5   type = 7, respectively. Must string matches environment genotype label. sel_gen1, sel_gen2 name genotypes compare type = 9. Must string present genotype's name. shape.gen, shape.env shape genotype environment indication biplot. Defaults shape.gen = 21 (circle) genotypes shape.env = 23 (rhombus) environments. Values must 21-25: 21 (circle), 22 (square), 23 (rhombus), 24 (triangle), 25 (low triangle). line.type.gen line type highlith genotype's vectors. Defaults line.type.gen == "dotted. size.shape size shape (genotypes environments). Defaults 2.2. size.shape.win size shape winners genotypes type = 3. Defaults 3.2. size.stroke, col.stroke width color border, respectively. Default size.stroke = 0.3 col.stroke = "black". size shape size.shape + size.stroke col.gen, col.env, col.line Color genotype/environment labels line passes biplot origin. Defaults col.gen = 'blue', col.env = 'forestgreen', col.line = 'forestgreen'. col.alpha alpha value color. Defaults 1. Values must 0 (full transparency) 1 (full color). col.circle, col.alpha.circle color alpha values circle lines. Defaults 'gray' 0.4, respectively. leg.lab labs legend. Defaults NULL c('Env', 'Gen'). size.text.gen, size.text.env, size.text.lab size text genotypes, environments labels, respectively. size.text.win text size use winner genotypes type = 3 two selected genotypes type = 9. Defaults 4.5. size.line size line biplots (segments circles). axis_expand multiplication factor expand axis limits enable fitting labels. Defaults 1.2 title Logical values (Defaults TRUE) include automatically generated information plot singular value partitioning, scaling centering. plot_theme graphical theme plot. Default plot_theme = theme_metan(). details, see ggplot2::theme(). ... Currently used.

text: Makes radar plot showing multi-trait genotype-ideotype distance index

title: Plot the multi-trait genotype-ideotype distance index — plot.mgidi
code: # S3 method for mgidi plot(   x,   SI = 15,   radar = TRUE,   type = "index",   position = "fill",   rotate = FALSE,   genotypes = "selected",   n.dodge = 1,   check.overlap = FALSE,   x.lab = NULL,   y.lab = NULL,   title = NULL,   arrange.label = FALSE,   size.point = 2.5,   size.line = 0.7,   size.text = 10,   width.bar = 0.75,   col.sel = "red",   col.nonsel = "gray",   legend.position = "bottom",   ... )

title: Plot the multi-trait genotype-ideotype distance index — plot.mgidi
text: x object class mgidi SI integer (0-100). selection intensity percentage total number genotypes. radar Logical argument. true (default) radar plot generated using coord_polar(). type type plot. Defaults "index". Use type = "contribution" show contribution factor MGIDI index selected genotypes/treatments. position position adjustment type = "contribution". Defaults "fill", shows relative proportions trait stacking bars standardizing bar height. Use position = "stack" plot MGIDI index genotype/treatment. rotate Logical argument. rotate = TRUE plot rotated, .e., traits y axis value x axis. genotypes type = "contribution" defines genotypes shown plot. default (genotypes = "selected" selected genotypes shown. Use genotypes = "" plot contribution genotypes.) n.dodge number rows used render x labels. useful displaying labels otherwise overlap. check.overlap Silently remove overlapping labels, (recursively) prioritizing first, last, middle labels. x.lab, y.lab labels axes x y, respectively. x label set null radar plot produced. title plot title type = "contribution". arrange.label Logical argument. TRUE, labels arranged avoid text overlapping. becomes useful number genotypes large, say, 30. size.point size point graphic. Defaults 2.5. size.line size line graphic. Defaults 0.7. size.text size text plot. Defaults 10. width.bar width bars type = "contribution". Defaults 0.75. col.sel colour selected genotypes. Defaults "red". col.nonsel colour nonselected genotypes. Defaults "gray". legend.position position legend. ... arguments passed  ggplot2::theme().

code: # S3 method for path_coeff plot(   x,   which = "coef",   size.text.plot = 4,   size.text.labels = 10,   digits = 3,   ... )

title: Plots an object of class path_coeff — plot.path_coeff
text: x object class path_coeff group_path. plot: one 'coef', 'vif', 'betas'. size.text.plot, size.text.labels size text plot area labels, respectively. digits significant digits shown. ... arguments passed ggplot2::theme().

title: Plots an object of class path_coeff — plot.path_coeff
text: plot = "coef" (default) interpreted follows: direct effects shown diagonal (highlighted thicker line). example, direct effect NKE KW 0.718. indirect effects shown line. example, indirect effect EH KW TKW 0.396. linear correlation (direct + indirect) shown last column.

title: Plots an object of class path_coeff — plot.path_coeff
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Plots an object of class path_coeff — plot.path_coeff
code: # \donttest{ library(metan)  # KW as dependent trait and all others as predictors # PH, EH, NKE, and TKW as predictors  pcoeff <-   path_coeff(data_ge2,              resp = KW,              pred = c(PH, EH, NKE, TKW)) #> Weak multicollinearity.  #> Condition Number: 40.232 #> You will probably have path coefficients close to being unbiased.  plot(pcoeff)  plot(pcoeff, which = "vif")  plot(pcoeff, which = "betas")  # }

what: Several types of residual plots — plot.performs_ammi
title: Several types of residual plots — plot.performs_ammi
text: Residual plots output model class performs_ammi. Seven types plots produced: (1) Residuals vs fitted, (2) normal Q-Q plot residuals, (3) scale-location plot (standardized residuals vs Fitted Values), (4) standardized residuals vs Factor-levels, (5) Histogram raw residuals (6) standardized residuals vs observation order, (7) 1:1 line plot.

code: # \donttest{ library(metan) vcov <- covcor_design(data_g, GEN, REP, everything()) means <- as.matrix(vcov$means) pcov <- vcov$phen_cov gcov <- vcov$geno_cov  index <- Smith_Hazel(means, pcov = pcov, gcov = gcov, weights = rep(1, 15)) plot(index)  # }

what: Several types of residual plots — plot.waasb
title: Several types of residual plots — plot.waasb
text: Residual plots output model class waas waasb. Six types plots produced: (1) Residuals vs fitted, (2) normal Q-Q plot residuals, (3) scale-location plot (standardized residuals vs Fitted Values), (4) standardized residuals vs Factor-levels, (5) Histogram raw residuals (6) standardized residuals vs observation order. waasb object, normal Q-Q plot random effects may also obtained declaring type = 're'

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.waasb
code: # S3 method for waasb plot(   x,   var = 1,   type = "res",   position = "fill",   rotate = FALSE,   conf = 0.95,   out = "print",   n.dodge = 1,   check.overlap = FALSE,   labels = FALSE,   plot_theme = theme_metan(),   alpha = 0.2,   fill.hist = "gray",   col.hist = "black",   col.point = "black",   col.line = "red",   col.lab.out = "red",   size.line = 0.7,   size.text = 10,   width.bar = 0.75,   size.lab.out = 2.5,   size.tex.lab = 10,   size.shape = 1.5,   bins = 30,   which = c(1:4),   ncol = NULL,   nrow = NULL,   ... )

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.waasb
text: x object class waasb. var variable plot. Defaults var = 1 first variable x. type One "res" plot model residuals (default), type = 're' plot normal Q-Q plots random effects, "vcomp" create bar plot variance components. position position adjustment type = "vcomp". Defaults "fill", shows relative proportions trait stacking bars standardizing bar height. Use position = "stack" plot phenotypic variance trait. rotate Logical argument. rotate = TRUE plot rotated, .e., traits y axis value x axis. conf Level confidence interval use Q-Q plot (0.95 default). output returned. Must one 'print' (default) 'return'. n.dodge number rows used render x labels. useful displaying labels otherwise overlap. check.overlap Silently remove overlapping labels, (recursively) prioritizing first, last, middle labels. labels Logical argument. TRUE labels points outside confidence interval limits. plot_theme graphical theme plot. Default plot_theme = theme_metan(). details, see ggplot2::theme(). alpha transparency confidence band Q-Q plot. Must number 0 (opaque) 1 (full transparency). fill.hist color fill histogram. Default 'gray'. col.hist color border histogram. Default 'black'. col.point color points graphic. Default 'black'. col.line color lines graphic. Default 'red'. col.lab.color labels 'outlying' points. size.line size line graphic. Defaults 0.7. size.text size text plot. Defaults 10. width.bar width bars type = "contribution". size.lab.size labels 'outlying' points. size.tex.lab size text axis text labels. size.shape size shape plots. bins number bins use histogram. Default 30. graphics plotted. Default = c(1:4) means first four graphics plotted. ncol, nrow number columns rows plot pannel. Defaults NULL ... Additional arguments passed function patchwork::wrap_plots().

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.waasb
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Several types of residual plots — plot.waasb
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) model2 <- waasb(data_ge,                 resp = GY,                 gen = GEN,                 env = ENV,                 rep = REP) #> Evaluating trait GY |============================================| 100% 00:00:01   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       GY #>  COMPLETE       NA #>       GEN 1.11e-05 #>   GEN:ENV 2.15e-11 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction plot(model2) #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x' #> `geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'  # }

title: Plot heat maps with genotype ranking — plot.wsmp
text: Plot heat maps genotype ranking two ways.

title: Plot heat maps with genotype ranking — plot.wsmp
code: # S3 method for wsmp plot(x, var = 1, type = 1, y.lab = NULL, x.lab = NULL, size.lab = 12, ...)

title: Plot heat maps with genotype ranking — plot.wsmp
text: x object returned function wsmp. var variable plot. Defaults var = 1 first variable x. type 1 = Heat map Ranks: graphic shows genotype ranking considering WAASB index estimated different numbers Principal Components; 2 = Heat map WAASY-GY ratio: graphic shows genotype ranking considering different combinations WAASB/GY ratio. y.lab label y axis. Default 'Genotypes'. x.lab label x axis. Default 'Number axes'. size.lab size labels. ... Currently used.

title: Plot heat maps with genotype ranking — plot.wsmp
text: object class gg.

title: Plot heat maps with genotype ranking — plot.wsmp
text: first type heatmap shows genotype ranking depending number principal component axis used estimating WAASB index. second type heatmap shows genotype ranking depending WAASB/GY ratio. ranks obtained ratio 100/0 considers exclusively stability genotype ranking. hand, ratio 0/100 considers exclusively productivity genotype ranking.  Four clusters genotypes shown label colors (red) unproductive unstable genotypes; (blue) productive, unstable genotypes; (black) stable, unproductive genotypes; (green), productive stable genotypes.

title: Plot heat maps with genotype ranking — plot.wsmp
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

what: Plot scores in different graphical interpretations — plot_scores
title: Plot scores in different graphical interpretations — plot_scores
text: Plot scores genotypes environments different graphical interpretations. Biplots type 1 2 well known AMMI analysis. plot type 3, scores genotypes environments plotted considering response variable WAASB, stability index considers significant principal component axis traditional AMMI models principal component axis estimated BLUP-interaction effects (Olivoto et al. 2019). Plot type 4 may used better understand well known '-won-' pattern, facilitating recommendation appropriate genotypes targeted specific environments, thus allowing exploitation narrow adaptations.

title: Plot scores in different graphical interpretations — plot_scores
code: plot_scores(   x,   var = 1,   type = 1,   first = "PC1",   second = "PC2",   repel = TRUE,   repulsion = 1,   max_overlaps = 20,   polygon = FALSE,   title = TRUE,   plot_theme = theme_metan(),   axis.expand = 1.1,   x.lim = NULL,   y.lim = NULL,   x.breaks = waiver(),   y.breaks = waiver(),   x.lab = NULL,   y.lab = NULL,   shape.gen = 21,   shape.env = 23,   size.shape.gen = 2.2,   size.shape.env = 2.2,   size.bor.tick = 0.3,   size.tex.lab = 12,   size.tex.gen = 3.5,   size.tex.env = 3.5,   size.line = 0.5,   size.segm.line = 0.5,   col.bor.gen = "black",   col.bor.env = "black",   col.line = "black",   col.gen = "blue",   col.env = "forestgreen",   col.alpha.gen = 1,   col.alpha.env = 1,   col.segm.gen = transparent_color(),   col.segm.env = "forestgreen",   highlight = NULL,   col.highlight = "red",   col.alpha.highlight = 1,   size.tex.highlight = 5.5,   size.shape.highlight = 3.2,   leg.lab = c("Env", "Gen"),   line.type = "solid",   line.alpha = 0.9,   resolution = deprecated(),   file.type = "png",   export = FALSE,   file.name = NULL,   width = 8,   height = 7,   color = TRUE,   ... )

title: Plot scores in different graphical interpretations — plot_scores
text: x object fitted functions performs_ammi(), waas(), waas_means(), waasb(). var variable plot. Defaults var = 1 first variable x. type type biplot produce type = 1 default. Produces AMMI1 biplot (Y x PC1) make inferences related stability productivity. type = 2 Produces AMMI2 biplot (PC1 x PC2) make inferences related interaction effects. Use arguments first second change default IPCA shown plot. type = 3 Valid objects class waas waasb, produces biplot showing GY x WAASB. type = 4 Produces plot Nominal yield x Environment PC. first, second IPCA shown first (x) second (y) axis. default, IPCA1 shown x axis IPCA2 y axis. example, use second = "PC3" shown IPCA3 y axis. repel TRUE (default), text labels repel away away data points. repulsion Force repulsion overlapping text labels. Defaults 1. max_overlaps Exclude text labels overlap many things. Defaults 20. polygon Logical argument. TRUE, polygon drawn type = 2. title Logical values (Defaults TRUE) include automatically generated titles plot_theme graphical theme plot. Default plot_theme = theme_metan(). details, see ggplot2::theme(). axis.expand Multiplication factor expand axis limits enable fitting labels. Default 1.1. x.lim, y.lim range x y axes, respectively. Default NULL (maximum minimum values data set). New values can inserted x.lim = c(x.min, x.max) y.lim = c(y.min, y.max). x.breaks, y.breaks breaks plotted x y axes, respectively. Defaults waiver() (automatic breaks). New values can inserted, example, x.breaks = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.3) x.breaks = seq(0, 1, = 0.2) x.lab, y.lab label x y axes, respectively. Defaults NULL, .e., plot default axis label. New values can inserted x.lab = 'label'. shape.gen, shape.env shape genotypes environments indication biplot. Default 21 (circle) genotypes 23 (diamond) environments. Values must 21-25: 21 (circle), 22 (square), 23 (diamond), 24 (triangle), 25 (low triangle). size.shape.gen, size.shape.env size shapes genotypes environments respectively. Defaults 2.2. size.bor.tick size tick shape. Default 0.3. size shape max(size.shape.gen, size.shape.env) + size.bor.tick size.tex.lab, size.tex.gen, size.tex.env size text axis labels (Defaults 12), genotypes labels, environments labels (Defaults 3.5). size.line size line indicate means biplot. Default 0.5. size.segm.line size segment start origin biplot end scores values. Default 0.5. col.bor.gen, col.bor.env color shape's border genotypes environments, respectively. col.line color line indicate means biplot. Default 'gray' col.gen, col.env shape color genotypes (Defaults 'blue') environments ('forestgreen'). Must length one vector colors length number genotypes/environments. col.alpha.gen, col.alpha.env alpha value color genotypes environments, respectively. Defaults NA. Values must 0 (full transparency) 1 (full color). col.segm.gen, col.segm.env color segment genotypes (Defaults transparent_color()) environments (Defaults 'forestgreen'), respectively. Valid arguments plots type = 1 type = 2 graphics. highlight Genotypes/environments highlight plot. Defaults NULL. col.highlight color shape/labels value provided highlight. Defaults "red". col.alpha.highlight alpha value color highlighted genotypes. Defaults 1. size.tex.highlight size text highlighted genotypes. Defaults 5.5. size.shape.highlight size shape highlighted genotypes. Defaults 3.2. leg.lab labs legend. Default Gen Env. line.type type line indicate means biplot. Default 'solid'. values can attributed : 'blank', lines biplot, 'dashed', 'dotted', 'dotdash', 'longdash', 'twodash'. line.alpha alpha value combine line background create appearance partial full transparency. Default 0.4. Values must '0' (full transparency) '1' (full color). resolution deprecated file.type type file exported. Currently recognises extensions eps/ps, tex, pdf, jpeg, tiff, png (default), bmp, svg wmf (windows ). export Export () plot. Default FALSE. TRUE, calls ggplot2::ggsave() function. file.name name file exportation, default NULL, .e. files automatically named. width width 'inch' plot. Default 8. height height 'inch' plot. Default 7. color type 4 plot colors? Default TRUE. ... Currently used.

title: Predict the means of a performs_ammi object — predict.performs_ammi
text: function used predict response variable two-way table (examples yielding -th genotype j-th environment) based AMMI model. prediction based number multiplicative terms used. naxis = 0, main effects (AMMI0) used. case, predicted mean predicted value OLS estimation. naxis = 1 AMMI1 (one multiplicative term) used predicting response variable. naxis = min(gen-1;env-1), AMMIF fitted predicted value cell mean, .e. mean R-replicates -th genotype j-th environment. number axis used must carefully chosen. Procedures based Postdictive success (Gollobs's d.f.) Predictive success (cross-validation) used . package provide . performs_ammi() function compute traditional AMMI analysis showing number significant axis. hand, cv_ammif() function provide cross-validation, estimating RMSPD AMMI-family models, based resampling procedures.

text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Print the partial correlation coefficients — print.lpcor
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) pcor <- lpcor(data_ge2, NR, NKR, NKE) print(pcor) #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   Pairs     linear partial     t  prob #>   <chr>      <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 NR x NKR  0.0206  -0.767 -14.8     0 #> 2 NR x NKE  0.626    0.866  21.4     0 #> 3 NKR x NKE 0.708    0.891  24.3     0  # Compute the correlations for each level of the factor ENV lpc2 <- lpcor(data_ge2,               NR, NKR, NKE,               by = ENV) print(lpc2) #> # A tibble: 420 × 6 #>    ENV   Pairs      linear partial       t   prob #>    <fct> <chr>       <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 A1    PH x EH   0.425     0.981  25.1   0      #>  2 A1    PH x EP  -0.124    -0.971 -20.1   0      #>  3 A1    PH x EL  -0.00287  -0.169  -0.841 0.408  #>  4 A1    PH x ED   0.0729    0.301   1.55  0.135  #>  5 A1    PH x CL  -0.158    -0.311  -1.60  0.122  #>  6 A1    PH x CD   0.140     0.183   0.911 0.372  #>  7 A1    PH x CW  -0.0111    0.155   0.771 0.448  #>  8 A1    PH x KW   0.0825    0.155   0.770 0.449  #>  9 A1    PH x NR  -0.0142    0.389   2.07  0.0496 #> 10 A1    PH x NKR  0.140     0.271   1.38  0.181  #> # … with 410 more rows # }

what: Rescale a variable to have specified minimum and maximum values — resca
title: Rescale a variable to have specified minimum and maximum values — resca
text: Helper function rescales continuous variable specified minimum maximum values. function rescale continuous variable follows: $$Rv_i = (Nmax - Nmin)/(Omax - Omin) * (O_i - Omax) + Nmax$$ \(Rv_i\) rescaled value ith position variable/ vector; \(Nmax\) \(Nmin\) new maximum minimum values; \(Omax Omin\) maximum minimum values original data, \(O_i\) ith value original data. basically two options use resca rescale variable. first passing data frame .data argument selecting one variables scaled using .... function return original variables .data plus rescaled variable(s) prefix _res. using function group_by dplyr package possible rescale variable(s) within level grouping factor. second option pass numeric vector argument values. output, course, numeric vector rescaled values.

title: Rescale a variable to have specified minimum and maximum values — resca
code: resca(   .data = NULL,   ...,   values = NULL,   new_min = 0,   new_max = 100,   na.rm = TRUE,   keep = TRUE )

title: Rescale a variable to have specified minimum and maximum values — resca
text: .data dataset. Grouped data allowed. ... Comma-separated list unquoted variable names rescaled. values Optional vector values rescale new_min minimum value new scale. Default 0. new_max maximum value new scale. Default 100 na.rm Remove NA values? Default TRUE. keep variables kept rescaling? false, rescaled variables kept.

title: Rescale a variable to have specified minimum and maximum values — resca
text: numeric vector values used input data tibble data frame used input .data.

title: Rescale a variable to have specified minimum and maximum values — resca
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Rescale a variable to have specified minimum and maximum values — resca
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) library(dplyr) # Rescale a numeric vector resca(values = c(1:5)) #> [1]   0  25  50  75 100   # Using a data frame head(  resca(data_ge, GY, HM, new_min = 0, new_max = 1) ) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #>   ENV   GEN   REP      GY    HM GY_res HM_res #>   <fct> <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 E1    G1    1      2.17  44.9  0.338  0.346 #> 2 E1    G1    2      2.50  46.9  0.414  0.445 #> 3 E1    G1    3      2.43  47.8  0.397  0.487 #> 4 E1    G2    1      3.21  45.2  0.574  0.36  #> 5 E1    G2    2      2.93  45.3  0.512  0.365 #> 6 E1    G2    3      2.56  45.5  0.428  0.375  # Rescale within factors; # Select variables that stats with 'N' and ends with 'L'; # Compute the mean of these variables by ENV and GEN; # Rescale the variables that ends with 'L' whithin ENV; data_ge2 %>%   select(ENV, GEN, starts_with("N"), ends_with("L")) %>%   means_by(ENV, GEN) %>%   group_by(ENV) %>%   resca(ends_with("L")) %>%   head(n = 13) #> Adding missing grouping variables: `ENV` #> # A tibble: 13 × 9 #> # Groups:   ENV [1] #>    ENV   GEN      NR   NKR   NKE    EL    CL EL_res   CL_res #>    <fct> <fct> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl> #>  1 A1    H1     16.3  33.3  527.  15.4  28.1   34.4 2.50e+ 1 #>  2 A1    H10    16.7  31.2  515.  16.1  31.4   69.9 8.17e+ 1 #>  3 A1    H11    15.2  34.6  530.  16.6  29.0   98.2 4.09e+ 1 #>  4 A1    H12    17.3  32.7  553.  15.2  29.8   20.9 5.52e+ 1 #>  5 A1    H13    18.7  32.9  611.  14.8  31.2    0   7.85e+ 1 #>  6 A1    H2     19.2  33.5  622.  15.0  26.6   11.0 1.42e-14 #>  7 A1    H3     18.5  34.1  610.  15.5  28.0   35.5 2.41e+ 1 #>  8 A1    H4     16.4  38.3  603.  16.0  27.4   63.1 1.42e+ 1 #>  9 A1    H5     14.5  37.4  539.  15.8  28.3   51.8 2.94e+ 1 #> 10 A1    H6     16.8  35.5  569.  16.7  31.7  100   8.74e+ 1 #> 11 A1    H7     17.9  31.5  544   15.4  30.6   34.8 6.94e+ 1 #> 12 A1    H8     17.2  32.8  542.  15.1  32.4   18.8 1   e+ 2 #> 13 A1    H9     14.9  32.3  489.  15.5  32.0   38.7 9.17e+ 1 # }

what: Several types of residual plots — residual_plots
title: Several types of residual plots — residual_plots
text: Residual plots output model class performs_ammi, waas,  anova_ind,  anova_joint. Seven types plots produced: (1) Residuals vs fitted, (2) normal Q-Q plot residuals, (3) scale-location plot (standardized residuals vs Fitted Values), (4) standardized residuals vs Factor-levels, (5) Histogram raw residuals (6) standardized residuals vs observation order, (7) 1:1 line plot

title: Several types of residual plots — residual_plots
code: residual_plots(   x,   var = 1,   conf = 0.95,   labels = FALSE,   plot_theme = theme_metan(),   band.alpha = 0.2,   point.alpha = 0.8,   fill.hist = "gray",   col.hist = "black",   col.point = "black",   col.line = "red",   col.lab.out = "red",   size.lab.out = 2.5,   size.tex.lab = 10,   size.shape = 1.5,   bins = 30,   which = c(1:4),   ncol = NULL,   nrow = NULL,   ... )

title: Several types of residual plots — residual_plots
text: x object class performs_ammi, waas, anova_joint,  gafem var variable plot. Defaults var = 1 first variable x. conf Level confidence interval use Q-Q plot (0.95 default). labels Logical argument. TRUE labels points outside confidence interval limits. plot_theme graphical theme plot. Default plot_theme = theme_metan(). details, see ggplot2::theme(). band.alpha, point.alpha transparency confidence band Q-Q plot points, respectively. Must number 0 (opaque) 1 (full transparency). fill.hist color fill histogram. Default 'gray'. col.hist color border histogram. Default 'black'. col.point color points graphic. Default 'black'. col.line color lines graphic. Default 'red'. col.lab.color labels 'outlying' points. size.lab.size labels 'outlying' points. size.tex.lab size text axis text labels. size.shape size shape plots. bins number bins use histogram. Default 30. graphics plotted. Default = c(1:4) means first four graphics plotted. ncol, nrow number columns rows plot pannel. Defaults NULL ... Additional arguments passed function patchwork::wrap_plots().

title: Several types of residual plots — residual_plots
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com
