Select helper — Select_helper
text: functions allow select variables based operations prefixes suffixes length names. difference_var(): Select variables start prefix end wiht suffix. intersect_var(): Select variables start prefix end wiht suffix. union_var(): Select variables start prefix end wiht suffix. width_of(): Select variables width n. width_greater_than(): Select variables width greater n. width_less_than(): Select variables width less n. lower_case_only(): Select variables contains lower case (e.g., "env"). upper_case_only(): Select variables contains upper case (e.g., "ENV"). title_case_only(): Select variables contains upper case first character (e.g., "Env").

title: Select helper — Select_helper
code: difference_var(prefix, suffix)  intersect_var(prefix, suffix)  union_var(prefix, suffix)  width_of(n, vars = peek_vars(fn = "width_of"))  width_greater_than(n, vars = peek_vars(fn = "width_greater_than"))  width_less_than(n, vars = peek_vars(fn = "width_less_than"))  lower_case_only(vars = peek_vars(fn = "lower_case_only"))  upper_case_only(vars = peek_vars(fn = "upper_case_only"))  title_case_only(vars = peek_vars(fn = "title_case_only"))

title: Select helper — Select_helper
text: prefix prefix start variable name. suffix suffix end variable name. n length variable names select. width_of() selected variables contains n characters. width_greater_than() width_less_than() selected variables contains greater less characteres n, respectively. vars character vector variable names. called inside selecting functions like select_cols() automatically set names table.

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
text: Computes Smith (1936) Hazel (1943) index given economic weights phenotypic genotypic variance-covariance matrices. Smith-Hazel index computed follows:   \[\bf{b = P^{-1}Aw}\] \(\bf{P}\) \(\bf{G}\) phenotypic genetic covariance matrices, respectively, \(\bf{b}\) \(\bf{w}\) vectors index coefficients economic weightings, respectively. genetic worth \(\) individual genotype based traits x, y, ..., n, calculated : \[= b_xG_x + b_yG_y + ... + b_nG_n\] b index coefficient traits x, y, ..., n, respectively, G individual genotype BLUPs traits x, y, ..., n, respectively.

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
code: Smith_Hazel(   .data,   use_data = "blup",   pcov = NULL,   gcov = NULL,   SI = 15,   weights = NULL )

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
text: .data input data. can either two-way table genotypes rows traits columns, object fitted function gamem(). Please, see Details details. use_data Define data use .data object class gamem. Defaults "blup" (BLUPs genotypes). Use "pheno" use phenotypic means instead BLUPs computing index. pcov, gcov phenotypic genotypic variance-covariance matrix, respectively. Defaults NULL. two-way table informed .data matrices mandatory. SI selection intensity (percentage). Defaults 20 weights vector economic weights. Defaults vector 1s length number traits.

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
text: object class hz containing: b: vector index coefficient. index: genetic worth. sel_dif_trait: selection differencial. sel_gen: selected genotypes. gcov: genotypic variance-covariance matrix pcov: phenotypic variance-covariance matrix

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
text: using phenotypic means .data, sure genotype's code rownames. .data object class gamem BLUPs genotype used compute index. case, genetic covariance components estimated mean cross products.

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
text: Smith, H.F. 1936. discriminant function plant selection. Ann. Eugen. 7:240-250. doi:10.1111/j.1469-1809.1936.tb02143.x Hazel, L.N. 1943. genetic basis constructing selection indexes. Genetics 28:476-90. https://www.genetics.org/content/28/6/476.short

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Smith-Hazel index — Smith_Hazel
code: # \donttest{ vcov <- covcor_design(data_g, GEN, REP, everything()) means <- as.matrix(vcov$means) pcov <- vcov$phen_cov gcov <- vcov$geno_cov  index <- Smith_Hazel(means, pcov = pcov, gcov = gcov, weights = rep(1, 15)) # }

Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. tidy eval operators {{, !!, !!! syntactic constructs specially interpreted tidy eval functions. mostly need {{, !! !!! advanced operators use simple cases. curly-curly operator {{ allows tunnel data-variables passed function arguments inside tidy eval functions. {{ designed individual arguments. pass multiple arguments contained dots, use ... normal way.   enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. former returns single expression, latter returns list expressions. defused, expressions longer evaluate . must injected back evaluation context !! (single expression) !!! (list expressions).   simple case, code equivalent usage {{ ... . Defusing enquo() enquos() needed complex cases, instance need inspect modify expressions way. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[.   Another tidy eval operator :=. makes possible use glue curly-curly syntax LHS =. technical reasons, R language support complex expressions left =, use := workaround.   Many tidy eval functions like dplyr::mutate() dplyr::summarise() give automatic name unnamed inputs. need create sort automatic names , use as_label(). instance, glue-tunnelling syntax can reproduced manually :   Expressions defused enquo() (tunnelled {{) need simple column names, can arbitrarily complex. as_label() handles cases gracefully. code assumes simple column name, use as_name() instead. safer throws error input name expected.

title: Utilities for handling with NA and zero values — utils_na_zero
text: NAs zeros can increase noise multi-environment trial analysis. collection functions make easier deal . fill_na(): Fills NA selected columns using next previous entry. has_na(), has_zero(): Check NAs 0s data return logical value. prop_na() returns proportion NAs column data frame. random_na(): Generate random NA values two-way table based desired proportion. remove_cols_na(), remove_rows_na(): Remove columns rows contains least one NA value. remove_cols_all_na(), remove_rows_all_na(): Remove columns rows values NAs. remove_cols_zero(), remove_rows_zero(): Remove columns rows contains least one 0 value, respectively. select_cols_na(), select_cols_zero(): Select columns NAs 0s, respectively. select_rows_na(), select_rows_zero(): Select rows NAs 0s, respectively. replace_na(), replace_zero(): Replace NAs 0s, respectively, replacement value.

title: Utilities for handling with NA and zero values — utils_na_zero
code: fill_na(.data, ..., direction = "down")  has_na(.data)  prop_na(.data, ...)  remove_rows_na(.data, verbose = TRUE)  remove_rows_all_na(.data, verbose = TRUE)  remove_cols_na(.data, verbose = TRUE)  remove_cols_all_na(.data, verbose = TRUE)  select_cols_na(.data, verbose = TRUE)  select_rows_na(.data, verbose = TRUE)  replace_na(.data, ..., replacement = 0)  random_na(.data, prop)  has_zero(.data)  remove_rows_zero(.data, verbose = TRUE)  remove_cols_zero(.data, verbose = TRUE)  select_cols_zero(.data, verbose = TRUE)  select_rows_zero(.data, verbose = TRUE)  replace_zero(.data, ..., replacement = NA)

Variables fill  NAs fill_na(), replace NAs replace_na() zeros replace_zero(). ... null variables .data evaluated. must single variable name comma-separated list unquoted variables names. TRUE (default) shows console rows columns deleted. replacement value used replacement. Defaults 0. possible values Use "colmean", "colmin", "colmax" replace missing values column mean, minimum maximum values, respectively. prop proportion (percentage) NA values generate .data.

code: # \donttest{ library(metan) data_naz <- iris %>%               group_by(Species) %>%               doo(~head(., n = 3)) %>%               as_character(Species) data_naz #> # A tibble: 9 × 5 #>   Species    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>             <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 setosa              5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 #> 2 setosa              4.9         3            1.4         0.2 #> 3 setosa              4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2 #> 4 versicolor          7           3.2          4.7         1.4 #> 5 versicolor          6.4         3.2          4.5         1.5 #> 6 versicolor          6.9         3.1          4.9         1.5 #> 7 virginica           6.3         3.3          6           2.5 #> 8 virginica           5.8         2.7          5.1         1.9 #> 9 virginica           7.1         3            5.9         2.1 data_naz[c(2:3, 6, 8), c(1:2, 4, 5)] <- NA data_naz[c(2, 7, 9), c(2, 3, 4)] <- 0 has_na(data_naz) #> [1] TRUE has_zero(data_naz) #> [1] TRUE  # Fill NA values of column GEN fill_na(data_naz, Species) #> # A tibble: 9 × 5 #>   Species    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>             <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 setosa              5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 #> 2 setosa              0           0            0          NA   #> 3 setosa             NA           3.2         NA          NA   #> 4 versicolor          7           3.2          4.7         1.4 #> 5 versicolor          6.4         3.2          4.5         1.5 #> 6 versicolor         NA           3.1         NA          NA   #> 7 virginica           0           0            0           2.5 #> 8 virginica          NA           2.7         NA          NA   #> 9 virginica           0           0            0           2.1  # Remove columns remove_cols_na(data_naz) #> Warning: Column(s) Species, Sepal.Length, Petal.Length, Petal.Width with NA values deleted. #> # A tibble: 9 × 1 #>   Sepal.Width #>         <dbl> #> 1         3.5 #> 2         0   #> 3         3.2 #> 4         3.2 #> 5         3.2 #> 6         3.1 #> 7         0   #> 8         2.7 #> 9         0   remove_cols_zero(data_naz) #> Warning: Column(s) Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length with 0s deleted. #> # A tibble: 9 × 2 #>   Species    Petal.Width #>   <chr>            <dbl> #> 1 setosa             0.2 #> 2 NA                NA   #> 3 NA                NA   #> 4 versicolor         1.4 #> 5 versicolor         1.5 #> 6 NA                NA   #> 7 virginica          2.5 #> 8 NA                NA   #> 9 virginica          2.1 remove_rows_na(data_naz) #> Warning: Row(s) 2, 3, 6, 8 with NA values deleted. #> # A tibble: 5 × 5 #>   Species    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>             <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 setosa              5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 #> 2 versicolor          7           3.2          4.7         1.4 #> 3 versicolor          6.4         3.2          4.5         1.5 #> 4 virginica           0           0            0           2.5 #> 5 virginica           0           0            0           2.1 remove_rows_zero(data_naz) #> Warning: Row(s) 2, 7, 9 with 0s deleted. #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   Species    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>             <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 setosa              5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 #> 2 NA                 NA           3.2         NA          NA   #> 3 versicolor          7           3.2          4.7         1.4 #> 4 versicolor          6.4         3.2          4.5         1.5 #> 5 NA                 NA           3.1         NA          NA   #> 6 NA                 NA           2.7         NA          NA    # Select columns select_cols_na(data_naz) #> Warning: Column(s) with NAs: Species, Sepal.Length, Petal.Length, Petal.Width #> # A tibble: 9 × 4 #>   Species    Sepal.Length Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>             <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 setosa              5.1          1.4         0.2 #> 2 NA                  0            0          NA   #> 3 NA                 NA           NA          NA   #> 4 versicolor          7            4.7         1.4 #> 5 versicolor          6.4          4.5         1.5 #> 6 NA                 NA           NA          NA   #> 7 virginica           0            0           2.5 #> 8 NA                 NA           NA          NA   #> 9 virginica           0            0           2.1 select_cols_zero(data_naz) #> Warning: Column(s) with 0s: Sepal.Length, Sepal.Width, Petal.Length #> # A tibble: 9 × 3 #>   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length #>          <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl> #> 1          5.1         3.5          1.4 #> 2          0           0            0   #> 3         NA           3.2         NA   #> 4          7           3.2          4.7 #> 5          6.4         3.2          4.5 #> 6         NA           3.1         NA   #> 7          0           0            0   #> 8         NA           2.7         NA   #> 9          0           0            0   select_rows_na(data_naz) #> Warning: Rows(s) with NAs: 2, 3, 6, 8 #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #>   Species Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>          <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 NA                 0         0              0          NA #> 2 NA                NA         3.2           NA          NA #> 3 NA                NA         3.1           NA          NA #> 4 NA                NA         2.7           NA          NA select_rows_zero(data_naz) #> Warning: Rows(s) with 0s: 1, 2, 3 #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   Species   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>            <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 NA                   0           0            0        NA   #> 2 virginica            0           0            0         2.5 #> 3 virginica            0           0            0         2.1  # Replace values replace_na(data_naz) #> # A tibble: 9 × 5 #>   Species    Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>             <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 setosa              5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 #> 2 0                   0           0            0           0   #> 3 0                   0           3.2          0           0   #> 4 versicolor          7           3.2          4.7         1.4 #> 5 versicolor          6.4         3.2          4.5         1.5 #> 6 0                   0           3.1          0           0   #> 7 virginica           0           0            0           2.5 #> 8 0                   0           2.7          0           0   #> 9 virginica           0           0            0           2.1 replace_zero(data_naz) #> # what: Utilities for handling with numbers and strings — utils_num_str
title: Utilities for handling with numbers and strings — utils_num_str
text: all_lower_case(): Translate non-numeric strings data frame lower case. all_upper_case(): Translate non-numeric strings data frame upper case. all_title_case(): Translate non-numeric strings data frame title case. first_upper_case: Translate first word string upper case. extract_number(): Extract number(s) string. extract_string(): Extract strings, ignoring case. find_text_in_num(): Find text characters numeric sequence return row index. has_text_in_num(): Inspect columns looking text numeric sequence return warning text found. remove_space(): Remove blank spaces string. remove_strings(): Remove strings variable. replace_number(): Replace numbers replacement. replace_string(): Replace strings replacement, ignoring case. round_cols(): Round selected column whole data frame significant figures. tidy_strings(): Tidy characters strings, non-numeric columns, selected columns data frame putting word upper case, replacing space, tabulation, punctuation characters '_', putting '_' lower upper case. Suppose str = c("Env1", "env 1", "env.1") (definition represent unique level plant breeding trials, e.g., environment 1) subjected tidy_strings(str): result c("ENV_1", "ENV_1", "ENV_1"). See Examples section examples.

title: Utilities for handling with numbers and strings — utils_num_str
code: all_upper_case(.data, ...)  all_lower_case(.data, ...)  all_title_case(.data, ...)  first_upper_case(.data, ...)  extract_number(.data, ..., pattern = NULL)  extract_string(.data, ..., pattern = NULL)  find_text_in_num(.data, ...)  has_text_in_num(.data)  remove_space(.data, ...)  remove_strings(.data, ...)  replace_number(   .data,   ...,   pattern = NULL,   replacement = "",   ignore_case = FALSE )  replace_string(   .data,   ...,   pattern = NULL,   replacement = "",   ignore_case = FALSE )  round_cols(.data, ..., digits = 2)  tidy_strings(.data, ..., sep = "_")

title: Utilities for handling with numbers and strings — utils_num_str
text: .data data frame ... argument depends function used. round_cols() ... variables round. variable informed, numeric variables data used. all_lower_case(), all_upper_case(), all_title_case(), stract_number(), stract_string(), remove_strings(), tidy_strings() ... variables apply function. variable informed, function applied non-numeric variables .data. pattern string matched. Regular Expression Syntax also allowed. replacement string replacement. ignore_case FALSE (default), pattern matching case sensitive TRUE, case ignored matching. digits number significant figures. sep character string separate terms. Defaults "_".

"This Is The Second One"    first_upper_case(gen_text) #> [1] "This is the first string." what: Utilities for text progress bar in the terminal — utils_progress
title: Utilities for text progress bar in the terminal — utils_progress
text: Progress bars configurable, may include percentage, elapsed time, custom text. progress(): Initiate custom progress bar class pb_metan. run_progress(): Run progress bar called within 'loop' statement, lapply() family purrr::map() family functional programming tools.

title: Utilities for text progress bar in the terminal — utils_progress
code: progress(   min = 0,   max = 100,   leftd = "|",   rightd = "|",   char = "=",   style = 2,   width = getOption("width"),   time = Sys.time() )  run_progress(pb, actual, text = "", digits = 0, sleep = 0)

title: Utilities for text progress bar in the terminal — utils_progress
text: min, max Numeric values extremes progress bar. Must min < max. leftd, rightd left right delimiters progress bar. Defaults "|". char character (character string) form progress bar. style 'style' progress bar. Elapsed time counted calling progress() call run_progress(). type = 1: Shows progress bar without percentage elapsed time. type = 2: default, shows progress bar percentage. type = 3: Shows progress bar elapsed time. type = 4: Shows progress bar, percentage, elapsed time. width width progress bar. Defaults number characters fits getOption("width"). time system time used compute elapsed time calling progress() call run_progress(). Defaults Sys.time(). pb object created progress() actual actual value, example, loop variable define loop index value. text optional character string shown begining progress bar. digits number significant figures percentage value. Defaults 0. sleep Suspend execution time interval Sys.sleep() within run_progress(). Defaults 0.

title: Utilities for text progress bar in the terminal — utils_progress
text: progress() returns list class pb_metan contains set parameters called run_progress().

title: Utilities for text progress bar in the terminal — utils_progress
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Utilities for text progress bar in the terminal — utils_progress

text: add_cols(): Add one columns existing data frame. specified ..columns exist, columns appended end data. Return data frame original columns .data plus columns declared .... add_cols() columns .data available expressions. , possible add column based existing data. add_rows(): Add one rows existing data frame. specified ..rows exist, rows appended end data. Return data frame original rows .data plus rows declared ... argument. add_row_id(): Add column row id first column .data. add_prefix() add_suffix() add prefixes suffixes, respectively, variable names selected ... argument. all_pairs(): Get possible pairs levels factor. colnames_to_lower(): Translate column names lower case. colnames_to_upper(): Translate column names upper case. colnames_to_title(): Translate column names title case. column_exists(): Checks column exists data frame. Return logical value. columns_to_first(): Move columns first positions .data. columns_to_last(): Move columns last positions .data. columns_to_rownames(): Move column .data row names. rownames_to_column(): Move row names .data new column. remove_rownames(): Remove row names .data. concatenate(): Concatenate columns data frame. drop = TRUE existing variables dropped. pull = TRUE concatenated variable pull vector. specially useful using concatenate add columns data frame add_cols(). get_levels(): Get levels factor variable. get_levels_comb(): Get combination levels factor. get_level_size(): Get size level factor variable. remove_cols(): Remove one columns data frame. remove_rows(): Remove one rows data frame. reorder_cols(): Reorder columns data frame. select_cols(): Select one columns data frame. select_first_col(): Select first variable, possibly offset. select_last_col(): Select last variable, possibly offset. select_numeric_cols(): Select numeric columns data frame. select_non_numeric_cols(): Select non-numeric columns data frame. select_rows(): Select one rows data frame. tidy_colnames(): Tidy column names tidy_strings().

title: Utilities for handling with rows and columns — utils_rows_cols

title: Utilities for handling with rows and columns — utils_rows_cols
text: .data data frame ... argument depends function used. add_cols() add_rows() name-value pairs. values must one element row .data using add_cols() one element column .data using add_rows(). Values length 1 recycled using add_cols(). remove_cols() select_cols(),  ... column name column index variable(s) dropped. add_prefix() add_suffix(),  ... column name add prefix suffix, respectively. Select helpers allowed. columns_to_first() columns_to_last(),  ... column name column index variable(s) moved first last .data. remove_rows() select_rows(), ... integer row value. concatenate(), ... unquoted variable names concatenated. get_levels(), get_level_comb(), get_level_size() ... unquoted variable names get levels, levels combinations levels size, respectively. ., .add_cols(), concatenate(), reorder_cols(), one-based column index column name add new columns, default: .last column. add_rows(), one-based row index add new rows, default: .last row. var Name column use rownames. levels levels factor numeric vector. prefix, suffix prefix suffix used add_prefix() add_suffix(), respectively. sep separator appear using concatenate(), add_prefix(), add_suffix(). Defaults "_". cols quoted variable name check exists .data. new_var name new variable containing concatenated values. Defaults new_var. drop Logical argument. TRUE keeps new variable new_var drops existing ones. Defaults FALSE. pull Logical argument. what: Useful functions for computing descriptive statistics — utils_stats
title: Useful functions for computing descriptive statistics — utils_stats
text: following functions compute descriptive statistics levels factor combination factors quickly. cv_by() computing coefficient variation. max_by() computing maximum values. means_by() computing arithmetic means. min_by() compuing minimum values. n_by() getting length. sd_by() computing sample standard deviation. var_by() computing sample variance. sem_by() computing standard error mean. Useful functions descriptive statistics. work naturally \%>\%, handle grouped data multiple variables (numeric variables .data default). av_dev() computes average absolute deviation. ci_mean_t() computes t-interval mean. ci_mean_z() computes z-interval mean. cv() computes coefficient variation. freq_table() Computes frequency table either numeric categorical/discrete data. numeric data, possible define number classes generated. hmean(), gmean() computes harmonic geometric means, respectively. harmonic mean reciprocal arithmetic mean reciprocals. geometric mean nth root n products. kurt() computes kurtosis like used SAS SPSS. range_data() Computes range values. n_valid() valid (NA) length data. n_unique() Number unique values. n_missing() Number missing values. row_col_mean(), row_col_sum() Adds row mean/sum variable column mean/sum row data. sd_amo(), sd_pop() Computes sample populational standard deviation, respectively. sem() computes standard error mean. skew() computes skewness like used SAS SPSS. ave_dev() computes average absolute deviations. sum_dev() computes sum absolute deviations. sum_sq() computes sum squared values. sum_sq_dev() computes sum squared deviations. var_amo(), var_pop() computes sample populational variance. desc_stat() wrapper function around ones can used compute quickly statistics .

what: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waas
title: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waas
text: Compute Weighted Average Absolute Scores AMMI analysis (Olivoto et al., 2019). function compute weighted average absolute scores, estimated follows:   \[WAAS_i = \sum_{k = 1}^{p} |IPCA_{ik} \times EP_k|/ \sum_{k = 1}^{p}EP_k\] \(WAAS_i\) weighted average absolute scores ith genotype; \(IPCA_{ik}\) score ith genotype kth IPCA; \(EP_k\) explained variance kth IPCA k = 1,2,..,p, considering p number significant PCAs, declared number PCAs. example prob = 0.05, axis significant considering probability level used. number axis can also informed declaring naxis = x. override number significant axes according argument codeprob.

title: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waas
code: waas(   .data,   env,   gen,   rep,   resp,   block = NULL,   mresp = NULL,   wresp = NULL,   prob = 0.05,   naxis = NULL,   ind_anova = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waas
text: .data dataset containing columns related Environments, Genotypes, replication/block response variable(s). env name column contains levels environments. gen name column contains levels genotypes. rep name column contains levels replications/blocks. resp response variable(s). analyze multiple variables single procedure vector variables may used. example resp = c(var1, var2, var3). block Defaults NULL. case, randomized complete block design considered. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) employed. effects, except error, assumed fixed. mresp new maximum value rescaling response variable. default, variables resp rescaled de maximum value 100 minimum value 0 (.e., mresp = NULL). must character vector length resp rescaling assumed different across variables, e.g., first variable smaller values better second one, higher values better, mresp = c("l, h") must used. Character value length 1 recycled warning message. wresp weight response variable(s) computing WAASBY index. default, variables resp equal weights mean performance stability (.e., wresp = 50). must numeric vector length resp assign different weights across variables, e.g., first variable equal weights mean performance stability assumed second one, higher weight mean performance (e.g. 65) assumed, wresp = c(50, 65) must used. Numeric value length 1 recycled warning message. prob p-value considering interaction principal component axis significant. naxis number IPCAs used computing WAAS index. Default NULL (Significant IPCAs used). values informed, number IPCAS used independently significance. Note two variables included resp, naxis must vector. ind_anova Logical argument set FALSE. TRUE within-environment ANOVA performed. verbose Logical argument. verbose = FALSE code run silently.

WgtResponse, weight response variable estimating WAASB, WgtWAAS weight stability, Ngen number genotypes, Nenv number environments, OVmean overall mean, Min minimum observed (returning genotype environment), Max maximum observed, Max maximum observed, MinENV environment lower mean, MaxENV environment larger mean observed, MinGEN genotype lower mean, MaxGEN genotype larger. augment: Information observation dataset. includes predicted values fitted column, residuals resid column, standardized residuals stdres column, diagonal 'hat' matrix hat, standard errors fitted values se.fit column. probint p-value genotype-vs-environment interaction.

what: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waasb
title: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waasb
text: Compute Weighted Average Absolute Scores (Olivoto et al., 2019) quantifying stability g genotypes conducted e environments using linear mixed-effect models. weighted average absolute scores computed considering Interaction Principal Component Axis (IPCA) Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) matrix genotype-environment interaction (GEI) effects generated linear mixed-effect model, follows:   \[WAASB_i = \sum_{k = 1}^{p} |IPCA_{ik} \times EP_k|/ \sum_{k = 1}^{p}EP_k\] \(WAASB_i\) weighted average absolute scores ith genotype; \(IPCA_{ik}\) score ith genotype kth Interaction Principal Component Axis (IPCA); \(EP_k\) explained variance kth IPCA k = 1,2,..,p, considering \(p = min(g - 1; e - 1)\). nature effects model chosen argument random. default, experimental design considered environment randomized complete block design. block informed, resolvable alpha-lattice design (Patterson Williams, 1976) implemented. following six models can fitted depending values random block arguments. Model 1: block = NULL random = "gen" (default option). model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment assuming genotype genotype-environment interaction random effects. Environments blocks nested within environments assumed fixed factors. Model 2: block = NULL random = "env". model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment treating environment, genotype-environment interaction, blocks nested within environments random factors. Genotypes assumed fixed factors. Model 3: block = NULL random = "". model considers Randomized Complete Block Design environment assuming random-effect model, .e., effects (genotypes, environments, genotype-vs-environment interaction blocks nested within environments) assumed random factors. Model 4: block NULL random =   "gen". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming genotype, genotype-environment interaction, incomplete blocks nested within complete replicates random make use inter-block information (Mohring et al., 2015). Complete replicates nested within environments environments assumed fixed factors. Model 5: block NULL random =   "env". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming genotype fixed. sources variation (environment, genotype-environment interaction, complete replicates nested within environments, incomplete blocks nested within replicates) assumed random factors. Model 6: block NULL random =   "". model considers alpha-lattice design environment assuming effects, except intercept, random factors.

title: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waasb
text: Tiago Olivoto tiagoolivoto@gmail.com

title: Weighted Average of Absolute Scores — waasb
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) #===============================================================# # Example 1: Analyzing all numeric variables assuming genotypes # # as random effects with equal weights for mean performance and # # stability                                                     # #===============================================================# model <- waasb(data_ge,               env = ENV,               gen = GEN,               rep = REP,               resp = everything()) #> Evaluating trait GY |======================                      | 50% 00:00:01  Evaluating trait HM |============================================| 100% 00:00:02   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       GY       HM #>  COMPLETE       NA       NA #>       GEN 1.11e-05 5.07e-03 #>   GEN:ENV 2.15e-11 2.27e-15 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction  # Genetic parameters get_model_data(model, "genpar") #> Class of the model: waasb #> Variable extracted: genpar #> # A tibble: 9 × 3 #>   Parameters              GY     HM #>   <chr>                <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 Phenotypic variance  0.181 5.52   #> 2 Heritability         0.154 0.0887 #> 3 GEIr2                0.313 0.397  #> 4 h2mg                 0.815 0.686  #> 5 Accuracy             0.903 0.828  #> 6 rge                  0.370 0.435  #> 7 CVg                  6.26  1.46   #> 8 CVr                 11.6   3.50   #> 9 CV ratio             0.538 0.415     #===============================================================# # Example 2: Analyzing variables that starts with "N"           # # assuming environment as random effects with higher weight for # # response variable (65) for the three traits.                  # #===============================================================#  model2 <- waasb(data_ge2,                env = ENV,                gen = GEN,                rep = REP,                random = "env",                resp = starts_with("N"),                wresp = 65) #> Warning: Invalid length in 'wresp'. Setting wresp = 65 to all the 3 variables. #> Evaluating trait NR |===============                             | 33% 00:00:00  Evaluating trait NKR |=============================              | 67% 00:00:02  Evaluating trait NKE |===========================================| 100% 00:00:03   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: REP(ENV), ENV, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: GEN #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       NR     NKR      NKE #>  COMPLETE       NA      NA       NA #>  REP(ENV) 1.00e+00 1.00000 0.999984 #>       ENV 2.84e-01 0.02314 0.003903 #>   GEN:ENV 2.03e-05 0.00242 0.000165 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction   # Get the index WAASBY get_model_data(model2, what = "WAASBY") #> Class of the model: waasb #> Variable extracted: WAASBY #> # A tibble: 13 × 4 #>    GEN      NR   NKR   NKE #>    <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 H1    69.2   42.7  33.5 #>  2 H10   35.7   53.7  49.3 #>  3 H11    9.63  58.2  47.1 #>  4 H12   63.6   35    36.8 #>  5 H13   84.6   27.0  60.0 #>  6 H2    39.7   50.8  62.8 #>  7 H3    18.4   48.4  16.0 #>  8 H4    28.4   97.6  88.1 #>  9 H5    28.5   74.0  94.0 #> 10 H6    55.8   34.5  32.2 #> 11 H7    52.0   42.0  40.9 #> 12 H8    42.1   27.3  21.9 #> 13 H9    26.4   48.2  14.9   #===============================================================# # Example 3: Analyzing GY and HM assuming a random-effect model.# # Smaller values for HM and higher values for GY are better.    # # To estimate WAASBY, higher weight for the GY (60%) and lower  # # weight for HM (40%) are considered for mean performance.      # #===============================================================#  model3 <- waasb(data_ge,                 env = ENV,                 gen = GEN,                 rep = REP,                 resp = c(GY, HM),                 random = "all",                 mresp = c("h, l"),                 wresp = c(60, 40)) #> Evaluating trait GY |======================                      | 50% 00:00:01  Evaluating trait HM |============================================| 100% 00:00:03   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, REP(ENV), ENV, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: - #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       GY       HM #>  COMPLETE       NA       NA #>       GEN 1.11e-05 5.07e-03 #>  REP(ENV) 9.91e-08 5.73e-05 #>       ENV 8.26e-17 3.55e-16 #>   GEN:ENV 2.15e-11 2.27e-15 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction  # Plot the scores (response x WAASB) plot_scores(model3, type = 3)  # }

what: Weighting between stability and mean performance — wsmp
title: Weighting between stability and mean performance — wsmp
text: function computes WAASY WAASBY indexes (Olivoto et al., 2019) considering different scenarios weights stability mean performance. fitting model functions waas() waasb() possible compute superiority indexes WAASY WAASBY different scenarios weights stability mean performance. number scenarios defined arguments increment. default, twenty-one different scenarios computed. case, superiority index computed considering following weights: stability (waasb waas) = 100; mean performance = 0. words, stability considered genotype ranking. next iteration, weights becomes 95/5 (since increment = 5). third scenario, weights become 90/10, weights become 0/100. last iteration, genotype ranking WAASY WAASBY matches perfectly ranks response variable.

title: Weighting between stability and mean performance — wsmp
code: wsmp(   model,   mresp = 100,   increment = 5,   saveWAASY = 50,   prob = 0.05,   progbar = TRUE )

title: Weighting between stability and mean performance — wsmp
text: model object computed waas(), waasb(), mps(). mresp numeric value new maximum value rescaling. default, variable resp rescaled original maximum minimum values 100 0, respectively. Let us consider specific trait, say, lodging incidence, lower values better. case, use mresp = 0 rescale response variable lowest values become 100 highest values 0. increment increment weight ratio stability mean performance. Se Details section information. saveWAASY Automatically save WAASY values weight stability saveWAASY. prob p-value considering interaction principal component axis significant. must multiple increment. assumption valid, error occur. progbar logical argument define progress bar shown. Default TRUE.

title: Weighting between stability and mean performance — wsmp
text: object class wsmp following items variable computed waas() waasb(). scenarios list model computed scenarios. WAASY values WAASY estimated weight stability loop match argument saveWAASY. hetdata, hetcomb data used produce heatmaps. Ranks values WAASY estimated different scenarios WAAS/GY weighting ratio. computed mps() hetcomb showing rank mean performance stability different weights.

title: Weighting between stability and mean performance — wsmp
code: # \donttest{ library(metan) # using the WAASB as statistic and BLUP as mean performance # the same as using waasb()  model <- mps(data_ge2,              env = ENV,              gen = GEN,              rep = REP,              resp = PH) #> Evaluating trait PH |============================================| 100% 00:00:00   #> Method: REML/BLUP #> Random effects: GEN, GEN:ENV #> Fixed effects: ENV, REP(ENV) #> Denominador DF: Satterthwaite's method #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> P-values for Likelihood Ratio Test of the analyzed traits #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #>     model       PH #>  COMPLETE       NA #>       GEN 9.39e-01 #>   GEN:ENV 1.09e-13 #> --------------------------------------------------------------------------- #> All variables with significant (p < 0.05) genotype-vs-environment interaction #> Mean performance: blupg #> Stability: waasb scenarios <- wsmp(model) # }

title: metan 0.2.0
text: first version submitted CRAN. version, deprecated functions last versions defunct. new features implemented. fai_blup() computes FAI-BLUP index (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/gcbb.12443) gge() computes genotype plus genotype-vs-environment model. plot_factbars() plot_factlines() used create bar line plots, respectively, considering one- two-way experimental design. desc_stat() computes several descriptive statistics. can_corr()computes canonical correlation coefficients. resp_surf() computes response surface model using two quantitative factors. make_mat() used create two-way table using two columns (factors) one response variable. make_sym() used create symmetric matrix using upper- lower-diagonal matrix. New evaluation text vectors now used functions AMMI_indexes() fai_blup() desc_stat(). example, indicate statistics computed desc_stat() must use now stats = c("mean, SE.mean, CV, max, min")) instead stats = c("mean", "SE.mean", "CV", "max", "min"))

title: metan 0.1.5
text: latest development version, package METAAB renamed metan (multi-environment trials analysis). Aiming cleaner coding, version, functions deprecated defunct near future. Alternative functions implemented. WAAS.AMMI(), use waas(). WAASBYratio(), use wsmp(). WAASratio.AMMI(), use wsmp(). autoplot.WAAS.AMMI(), use autoplot.waas(). plot.WAASBYratio(), use plot.wsmp(). plot.WAASratio.AMMI(), use plot.wsmp(). predict.WAAS.AMMI(), use predict.waas(). summary.WAAS.AMMI(), use summary.waas() Widely-known parametric nonparametric methods implemented, using following functions. Annicchiarico() compute genotypic confidence index. ecovalence() compute Wricke’s ecovalence. ge_factanal() compute compute stability environmental. ge_reg() compute joint-regression analysis. stratification using factor analysis. superiority() compute nonparametric superiority index.
